PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate that the Government is about to introduce into the Senate, legislation changing health insurance. These changes will increase the cost of health insurance to members of employee based funds and will do nothing to help the elderly, as is being claimed. Big public funds will increase their surpluses by taking money from more efficient funds. People will be forced back onto Medicare, which will not help to maintain private health insurance.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate reject this legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable Senate will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Beahan (from 288 citizens) and Calvert (from 171 citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the attendance of more than 1000 people at a public meeting in Canberra on the night of 31 May 1989, to protest at the excessive level of home loan interest rates;
(b) recognises that the Australian community is no longer willing or able to tolerate this interest rate burden;
(c) affirms its belief that it is the Federal Government's economic policies which are responsible for record interest rates of 17 per cent;
(d) expresses its regret that not one representative of the Federal Government attended the meeting to hear about the plight of thousands of Canberra home buyers;
(e) rejects the renewed attempts by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to play down this country's economic problems, which have given rise to its high interest rate policies;
(f) also rejects the Prime Minister's attempts to place the blame for high interest rates on the banks; and
(g) calls on the Government to immediately alter its economic policies, so as to reduce its total reliance on the maintenance of high interest rates.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Aulich-Mr President, can I seek a ruling from you? When you examine that notice of motion can you look at the quotation that is referred to by Senator Walters? TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think there is a very good case to be made for no quotations to be allowed in notices of motion. As I said earlier, I will seek a meeting of the Procedure Committee to deal with notices of motion that give excessive information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to address you on the question of notices of motion and your statement thereon.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw your attention to standing orders 104 to 114, which deal with notices of motion. Standing order 104 states how they may be given. It does not contain any description of particulars which a person may or may not set out in a notice of motion. It simply states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . shall be given by the Senator stating its terms to the Senate and delivering at the Table a copy of such Notice, fairly written, printed, or typed, signed by himself-
I presume that includes `herself'-
and showing the day proposed for bringing on such Motion.

If there are irrelevancies in it, under standing order 105 the President may instruct the Clerk to divide such a notice into two or more notices. With respect, Mr President, that does not give you the right to correct it or alter it as you may see fit. I suggest that, while you may be disturbed at the length of notices of motion, you may feel they are getting too long, and you may criticise them, until such time as the Standing Orders are corrected along those lines honourable senators are entitled to give notices of motion in the form in which they wish to give them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have been discussing this matter with the Clerk for some time and, as I have said, we are seeking an immediate meeting of the Procedure Committee. A notice of motion should be a proposed resolution of the Senate. Excessive argument should not be given in a notice of motion. I also remind the Senate of another standing order which says that the President may direct that the language of a notice be changed if it seems to him to be unbecoming or not in conformity with the Standing Orders of the Senate. As I have said, I intend to refer this matter to a committee. I do not believe that some of the notices of motion that have been given recently are strictly notices of motion.
—Mr President, will you confer with me before you alter my notice of motion?
—Of course, Senator Walters.

Senator Robert Ray-I raise a point of order, Mr President. Not only did we have this debate yesterday but also the use of the word `cowardly' in a motion is not parliamentary. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to address you about your request to Senator McGauran in the course of his reading of his notice of motion. I will be very brief.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of Senator McGauran reading his notice of motion you asked him to withdraw a particular word, and he agreed to do so. With respect, as I understand it, allegations contained in a notice of motion are not required to be parliamentary and they may be unparliamentary.
—No; Have a look at standing order 112.

—Well, I am seeking the President's ruling on this matter. Let me give the President an example. If a senator were to give a notice of motion that another senator were, say, a thief, one might say that is unparliamentary; but if he is able to establish that the senator is a thief, he is entitled to debate that issue. So I put it to you--
—That is really silly.
—It is not silly, Senator Collins.
—It would make a farce out of notices.

—That may very well be so, but until such time as the Senate Standing Orders Committee re-writes the Standing Orders in relation to notices of motion, I put it to the Senate that senators are entitled to put notices of motion in such form as they wish. The Government may bring the matter on for debate forthwith and throw it out. That is a matter for the Government to decide. But I put it to you, Mr President, that there is no requirement for language in a notice of motion to be parliamentary within the meaning of that word.
—Well, there is, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I speak for one minute on the same matter?

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis said that on this matter there is no provision in Standing Orders. Standing order 112 says; `Any Notice containing unbecoming expressions . . . (a) notes that:

(iii) female smokers face reduced fertility, double the likelihood of miscarriage, complications with IUD contraception, increasing risk of carcinoma of the cervix, earlier menopause, and osteoporosis,

DEBATE.TITLE: TELEVISION STATIONS: USE OF FILE FOOTAGE OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook, on behalf of Senator Button) agreed to:
That the Senate adopt the following guidelines to apply to recording of vision footage for file purposes and its subsequent broadcasting by television stations-
(1) Recording must take place only with the express approval of the respective Presiding Officer and following an announcement in the respective Chamber.
(2) Footage must be recorded only from Channels 1 and 2 (House of Representatives and the Senate) from the Parliamentary Audio Vision Unit.
(3) Recording must take place only during questions and answers. Any other proceedings including points of order are not available for broadcast.
(4) Footage must not be altered so as to destroy continuity.
(5) Footage must be broadcast at normal speed without use of freeze frame. A separate still frame may be used,
(6) Footage must not be used for the purposes of satire or ridicule.
(7) Footage must not be used for the purposes of political party advertising or in election campaigns.
(8) Footage shall be used only in news and current affairs programs and must be placed in context.
(9) All footage must be captioned `file footage' or words to that effect.

(10) The instructions of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives or their delegates, which are not inconsistent with these guidelines, shall be observed at all times.
(11) Access to proceedings for the purpose of recording vision footage shall be on the basis of an undertaking to observe these guidelines.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders, in respect of the consideration of General Business this day:
(a) Government Papers not be considered;
(b) only General Business, Order of the Day No. 48 (Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988), be called on; and
(c) consideration of General Business, if not sooner concluded, be interrupted after the expiration of one and a half hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not consulted about this, Mr President. Nobody consulted me about cutting down General Business. Last week we had this debate about changing business around. I do not think that this is in order. Notice of a motion should be given about changing Sessional Orders. Sessional orders require that General Business take place on Thursday afternoon and that there be a period for debate on that General Business to continue. Last week I complained about the lack of time for General Business-specific General Business-particularly in regard to legislation. Now I have slapped on my desk, without any notification whatsoever, a proposal that General Business today be cut down to 1 1/2 hours. That is a disgrace. We are senators representing constituencies, and we are entitled to be consulted by the Government about its intention to chop our time, but that has not been done.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have the relevant standing order in front of me but I always understood that to change Sessional Orders a notice of motion should be given. As I understand it, Sessional Orders require that General Business on Thursday afternoon extend certainly beyond 1 1/2 hours. From memory, it is for 2 1/2 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is papers for one hour and General Business for 2 1/2 hours.
—That is right.
—It is the same amount of time.

—No, it is not the same amount of time at all. We have a time for General Business, and that time as I understand it, is 2 1/2 hours. The Government is seeking to reduce it to 1 1/2 hours. It is suggesting that Government papers not be considered. That is fair enough. But we need to be able to consider Government papers. There are a number of Government papers on the Notice Paper which need to be considered. I am very much against not only the principle of cutting down the time but also the fact that I was not properly consulted about this question.
—Order! Senator Harradine, Ministers may move a motion in relation to the order of business at any time. They have consistently done so over the years. They are not required to give notice.

—I ask that in future any motion be handed to honourable senators in writing prior to it being moved. I feel that the terms of a motion should be put on our desks so that we know what it is all about.
—I will investigate that, Senator Walters. I believe that this was one of those normal motions and had been agreed to by the Whips at the party meeting this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I quoted from Socrates. I mentioned the fact that he had said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody is qualified to become a statesman who is entirely ignorant of the problem of wheat.

I said that after Senator Lewis moved the Opposition's amendments in this place. I believe that Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, could go some way towards becoming a statesman and lose the image that he has at the moment of a Minister who has threatened the Senate with the passage of the Wheat Marketing Bill, a Bill which we want to amend and improve. He has said that if we do not pass the Bill in the way he wants it he will let it lapse. He will let this export industry, and the wheat growers, both so vital to Australia, go to the wall or be thrown to the wolves in corrupted world markets.

The Government's performance in this whole debate has not been to its credit. As I said, I think that the Minister could become quite a statesman. The Socrates quotation is very relevant. I will quote what some of the newspapers have said about this Bill we are still debating. I quote from part of the editorial in Stock and Land of 25 May. It said:
The untidiness of the drafting required 26 amendments by Primary Industry Minister, John Kerin, in the second reading and another five on its return to the House of Representatives.
It has been a very shoddily and very badly drafted Bill that has required so many amendments just because of its bad drafting. The editorial went on:

Mr Kerin says the Wheat Board will control the fund, and it will be the Grains Council who will select the majority of the board's membership. But just for the record, Mr Kerin will have the power to veto choice of members of the selection committee, he will have the power to reject selection committee nominations, and he has the power to approve or reject the board's corporate and operation plans.
He has a lot of power over this Board, if this legislation were to go through. The editorial went on:
. . . the Coalition would be pushing for three major amendments in the Senate.
Those are three of the four that Senator Lewis has already alluded to. It continues:
. . . a higher level of underwriting, the appointment of a grower-chairman, and greater control for growers of their industry fund.
All three if adopted would put a smooth icing on a workable piece of legislation. If rejected the taste will be bitter for graingrowers.

If these amendments put forward by Senator Lewis are accepted, this Bill will make Mr Kerin a much more popular Minister. It will also enable him to say that he is moving into the statesmanlike area. I think he should sit and listen to these amendments. The editorial in the Land newspaper of Thursday, 25 May, said:
The Senate must adopt the three key amendments being sought by the Coalition, and the Government should be magnanimous enough to accommodate them in the legislation.

What the Coalition is seeking is a higher level of underwriting, the appointment of a grower-chairman for the new-look Australian Wheat Board, and greater control for growers over their industry fund-all perfectly reasonable requests.

The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is sitting at the table representing the Minister in this place, knows that they are perfectly reasonable requests. I hope that he transmits to his Minister in the other place the message that these amendments we are asking him to consider here today are reasonable requests. The editorial in the Land newspaper went on:
He-
that is, Mr Kerin-
has effectively wrested control of the wheat industry from growers and achieved his major aim of exposing the Australian Wheat Board and its State instrumentalities to competitive forces.
In so doing he has thoroughly antagonised many growers.

As a wheat grower myself-and Senator Panizza has made this point as a wheat grower-I can assure the Minister that we have been antagonised by the way that this has been foisted on us and the way that the Minister now will not listen to these amendments we are asking him to consider.

The major point that I raise is that I have been accused of working very closely with the Grains Council of Australia. Yes, I work closely with the Grains Council of Australia, because it is the peak body representing the wheat growers in Australia. I am quite sure that Mr Kerin works very closely with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor movement because they are the peak bodies, if you like, of the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the greenies in Tasmania.

—I will allude to that in a little while. One of the basic tenets to which the Government could and ought to yield is the question of underwriting. For the Government, this is a question of semantics. The 95 per cent underwriting arrangement would cost the Government nothing-I repeat: nothing. If one looks at the net pool return over the last 10 years to the time of setting the guaranteed minimum price (GMP) and at the final price achieved by the Board, one would find that only once during that 10 years has the price gone below 95 per cent. That was in 1980-81. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which sets out the estimated GMP on a one-year formula for the last 10 years.
