SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday last, in the late evening, I began the debate for the Opposition on the Government's package of superannuation taxation Bills. In the course of some 24 minutes I made several points which are the basis of the Opposition's decision to move several amendments to this package at the committee stage. Specifically, those amendments are, firstly, to effect the excise of the 15 per cent investment tax on superannuation fund income and, secondly, to raise to $125,000 the threshold of $60,000 above which a tax of 16.25 per cent will be applied.

SPEECH.PARA: The salient points I made in the course of that address were, firstly, that the 15 per cent investment tax is a disincentive to savings; at the very time when the economy is seeing a desperate need to encourage our savings ratio it is a retrograde step to have this disincentive built into the superannuation laws of this land. Secondly, this package is being introduced 13 months after it was first brought down in the May statement in 1988 by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I think any reasonable person would say that there is a degree of complexity in the legislation, which has taken 12 months to come into the Parliament for final scrutiny. It is being raced through because the Government has not been diligent in bringing the legislation on earlier so that there could be a proper assessment of it. That is a most important point. It is truly a flagrant example of government by press release.

Thirdly, the Government claimed that industry is supportive of the legislation and that others are pressing for it to be introduced somehow to give certainty in the area. The basis for the Government's claim seems to be the press release put out by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia on 5 May saying that it welcomed the legislation, while still complaining about the tax. Subsequent to that, in the days leading up to the presentation of the Bills into this chamber, industry and others became very much aware of the retrograde step that this tax imposes. So we had Coles-Myer Superannuation Fund, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the Life Underwriters Association of Australia, Mr Garry Weaven, the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and Professor Michael Porter saying that it was a disincentive. We had people from all ends of the political spectrum making statements about the effect of the introduction of this particular tax which is, we estimate, a value of somewhere between $20m and $120m to the revenue. We should bear in mind that that is a very small percentage of the revenue to be raised by the full package, which is some $1.4 billion. There is ample room for the decision the Government has made to impose this tax and actively discourage people from entering into superannuation arrangements to be reconsidered. There is ample time and opportunity for the Government to reconsider that proposal and to excise the tax.

I also raised the question of public administration and the laudable decision that various State governments were making to move towards accrual accounting generally, and specifically, to fund their own superannuation schemes. The imposition of this 15 per cent tax has directly resulted in the majority of States saying that they will not fund their superannuation schemes in the public sector for the simple reason that this tax is only attracted by funded schemes. Queensland went to the extent of passing legislation to alter the nature of the funding of its scheme so that it would not attract this tax. I think that is quite salient to recognise when we realise that the State governments have just taken a cut in their general purpose grants at the recent Premiers Conference while at the same time the Commonwealth Government is accruing to itself a rise in its own general purpose grants of some 5.5 per cent. The State governments are simply saying, `You don't get it both ways; you are cutting our general purpose grants and you want to take a further taxation benefit by imposing this tax on funds which we would otherwise fully fund'. There is an important point to be made there. It would sound a warning if the private sector decided to look at the concept of having unfunded superannuation schemes to similarly avoid this tax.

Another point I made that is important relates to the discriminatory nature of the tax. In May 1988 the Treasurer said that if fund managers chose to invest all their investments in imputed dividend equities, they could reduce the effect of this tax to make it almost negligible. That is discriminatory because of the nature of approved deposit funds and roll-over funds which are in fixed interest or capital guaranteed funds. There is $12 billion at present in those sorts of funds. The people who are in those funds would be disadvantaged by not having access to the imputed dividend scheme.

The most important point that has prompted the Opposition to move its amendments is that the Treasurer's promise in May 1988 is fallacious-it cannot be sustained. Very simply, he said that not one personal end benefit will be diminished by one cent. Quite plainly, in the examples that I gave last Tuesday evening and in the matters I have summarised here, that cannot be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has to be a classic example of how a system is messed up when the Government persists with introducing legislation by press release. This Government, in particular, has got into the habit of announcing measures that it proposes to introduce to change all sorts of things, from the social security system through to the tax system, and then a long time later, sometimes years later, actually producing the legislation that implements those proposals. In doing so, it leaves people in a state of considerable uncertainty, and in this case it looks like costing a lot of people a lot of money no matter which way this legislation goes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have been talking to the Government since July last year. Our concerns have not been about the 15 per cent contributions tax-I do not think anybody is worrying about that too much-or about the host of regulations that are going to implement other changes; we are used to dealing with regulations in this place. We are concerned about the 15 per cent earnings tax that the Government is introducing in the six tax Bills that we have before us today that have become known around the place for the last year or so as the superannuation legislation. The earnings tax is something which will leave a lot of people worse off, despite the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the contrary last year, about people not being even one cent worse off. We expressed our concern about a particular group of people who will be disadvantaged if this earnings tax goes through in this form. So far we have had no significant response from either the Treasurer or the Treasury.

The people I am talking about are those who have rolled over generally small superannuation payouts into fixed interest funds. Those people are going to be worse off. We went to the Government last July, and on almost a monthly basis since, pointing out that we wanted those people quarantined. We said that if they were not quarantined we would have no option at all but to support the Opposition's proposal to delete the earnings tax from this legislation entirely. That is not something I want to do, but it is at least one way of protecting those people who have put generally relatively small amounts of money into fixed interest deposits.

I suspect that the Government has not heeded or responded to our concerns and has not provided any assistance by drafting an amendment that will quarantine those people in fixed interest funds. I suspect it thinks that the Opposition is going to go to water on this matter. The Opposition has caved in on the health reinsurance fund legislation, it looks like caving in on the wheat legislation, and I suppose that the Government has some justification for expecting it to go to water on this legislation. I hope that the Opposition does not do so, not because I am so concerned about people who have very large lump sums in National Mutual or anywhere else but because if the only way to protect those people with small investments in fixed interest funds-that is, in very secure funds-is to oppose the earnings tax outright, that is what I am prepared to do.

Let us look at the legislation. The Bills implement the changes to the taxation of superannuation and roll-over funds which, as I said a moment ago, were announced by the Treasurer in May 1988. They came into force on 1 July 1988. They came into force before any of us, much less the people who have to try to implement these changes, had seen any legislation at all. The superannuation and roll-over funds have been operating for nearly a year under the new arrangements without the legislation giving any force to their actions. This has been an administrative nightmare for them, having to put aside the earnings tax-presumably into a separate account somewhere-in case this legislation goes through. This raises the equally awful nightmare of what they do with it and the money they have earned on it if the legislation does not go through in a way in which the Government anticipates. In any event, they had to put tax aside to meet the new taxation requirements, notwithstanding the fact that we did not see the legislation until, I think, November last year-and then only part of the legislation. They had to do that because if the legislation goes through, the first instalments of the taxes are due later this year.

As I said, some of the Bills to enact the changes announced in May last year were introduced into the Parliament in November last year. The rest were introduced a few weeks ago. It has taken the Government almost a year to draft the legislation that was supposed to come into force on 1 July 1988. Superannuation fund managers, superannuation policy-holders, people who have retired recently and those who plan to retire soon have had to make decisions on the basis of interpreting the original announcement, that is, the announcement of May last year, hoping the legislation will confirm their interpretation. This is the problem that we get when governments legislate by press release. It is bad enough in an area where there are no financial complications or implications but it is outrageous that the Government is persisting in doing this when such a financially sensitive area as the whole superannuation and life insurance industry is involved.

Even worse than all of this, of course, is the pressure which the Government, deliberately or otherwise-I suspect it is deliberately-applies to members of parliament under these circumstances. There is an implicit threat from the Government, when it proceeds through this sort of formula of making a statement and introducing legislation when it feels like it, and requiring people to comply with the original proposals from day one, that any change will cause havoc. Of course it is likely to cause havoc. But the problem is not the changes that are made in this place. The problem lies with the Government either in not getting its act together quickly enough or in assuming that, if it is complex enough, people in this place will lie doggo, roll over and have their tummies tickled or something, despite having concerns about the legislation. It is long past time the Senate in particular refused to be bludgeoned into submission by the Government, no matter what the consequences may be, if we believe that the legislation is detrimental to one group in the community or if it is seriously flawed in some way.

The point is, of course, that no one out there can act with precision when all they have is a general statement but no legislation. In this case the problem is compounded by the fact that we have now reached the stage where the first tax payments for the 1988-89 year are due after 1 July and we are debating the legislation in the first week of June. It is the last week, I might add, in which both Houses of Parliament are scheduled to be sitting simultaneously. That in itself is outrageous and I for one-and I am sure many other senators-are getting tired of the Government taking the House of Representatives off on to an early recess and leaving us here for two or three weeks to deal with the mess that the Government has left us in the legislative program, with the threat over our heads that if we do not comply with everything it wants or if we dare to move any amendments with a start date prior to the August Budget session, the House of Representatives will have to be recalled at huge cost to the taxpayer.

There is no reason why the House of Representatives has to rise tonight. There is no reason why it cannot sit tomorrow to deal with wheat legislation or with any changes that we make today to this legislation. It will not cost the taxpayer another penny if that House sits tomorrow. Its members cannot get home tonight anyway. Their allowances are paid for their overnight stay. I do not know what some of them think they are getting paid for. It is high time that the House did what the Senate does on a regular basis, that is, look at the legislation in detail and act accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —And debate it.

—Indeed. That is what I meant when I said it should look at it in detail. If it debated it to the extent we do, instead of ramming it through at two o'clock in the morning when people are less awake than usual, we might get better legislation and we might not have unintended consequences that have to be changed by amending legislation months or years later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has in fact created a situation where, if this legislation is not passed in some form before the end of this financial year, which is a matter of weeks away, there will be no legislation to enable the Government to collect the taxes legally; superannuation funds will not know exactly what form the taxes will take; and self-employed and personal superannuation contributors who have increased their superannuation contributions from $1,500 in the expectation that they will be able to claim up to the new $3,000 limit which qualifies for a tax deduction, will discover that this legislation has not been enacted in time for them to take advantage of it this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you enact that part?

—We, as a chamber, can enact whatever parts we see fit. Whether the Government is prepared to accept part of the package instead of all of the package is another matter and, of course, that is part of the blackmailing process. By and large, the ears of the journalists to whom the Government is talking are not ready to hear that the Government has the option of accepting those parts that are passed and continuing negotiations on those parts that are not passed. On the other hand, if the legislation does go through because the Government beats all or part of this place into submission, small investors will suffer and State governments, which have enormous power in this area, will change their public service superannuation schemes into unfunded ones and this Government will lose money anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the major features of the legislation, apart from a general mess-up of the area? There is, as I said, the increase from $1,500 to $3,000 on the limit for tax deductions for superannuation contributions by self-employed and other personal contributions not covered by an employer fund. This is the form of superannuation used by most small business people and people who are not in an employer-sponsored superannuation scheme. Why should they suffer if the Government does not get all of its package in the way that it wants? It is yet another example of how the Government has, in the past, discriminated against the self-employed and may well continue to do so.

There is no longer any statutory limit placed on the top deduction available to an employer for contributions to a superannuation fund on behalf of an employee other than the reasonable benefits limit. In contrast, a self-employed professional is limited at present to a $1,500 deduction and, under this legislation, to a $3,000 deduction with any additional contributions also being subject to the reasonable benefits limit. The increased deductable contribution of $3,000 is immediately subject to the 15 per cent contribution tax in the hands of the fund as part of its assessable income. So, of a contribution of $3,000, $450 is immediately lost in tax, leaving an effective contribution of $2,550. That amount is less than compensation for consumer price index increases since a deduction of $1,200 was available in 1975. It is a clear case for indexing these types of deductions so that the value of the tax deduction for superannuation contributions by the self-employed is not eroded over time until a benevolent government sees fit to amend the legislation.

The second feature of the legislation is the 15 per cent tax on deductable superannuation contributions. As I said a while ago, people do not seem to be getting their knickers in a knot over this matter particularly, and that piece of the legislation is not being challenged.

The Opposition is looking not at simply accepting the indexation of the new $60,000 threshold but at increasing that threshold to $125,000. I remind the Senate that, in 1984, the Australian Democrats moved for indexation of those thresholds. We argued that, if they were not indexed, there would be a serious erosion of real benefit to those people who were making contributions to fund their retirement years. That year we received no support from the Opposition or the Government. The move by the Opposition to more than double that threshold will benefit, in the main, only those people on high superannuation payouts and, if the Australian Taxation Office is right, it is a matter of only several hundred people who will benefit from that move by the Opposition. Certainly, far fewer people will benefit from the increase in the threshold than would benefit from the quarantining of fixed interest funds.

That brings me to the problem facing those fixed interest funds, that is, the 15 per cent tax on the investment earnings of superannuation roll-over funds. That tax, according to the Government's statement and to the legislation, can be reduced with imputation credits for franked dividends received from Australian companies. I cannot understand why the Opposition wanted to oppose this tax from day one. Our position has been to quarantine fixed interest funds from that tax because, by and large, unless they are dealing with preference shares, they will not get the imputation benefit. For some reason the Opposition wants to remove the 15 per cent earnings tax outright, notwithstanding that, in itself, it is of real benefit to the community in that it encourages the big life and superannuation funds to invest money in Australian companies instead of taking their investment dollars offshore.

While the Democrats certainly support the intention of the earnings tax, that is, to keep money in Australia to benefit Australian companies, and while we can see the sense in allowing the 15 per cent earnings tax to be reduced through imputation, the problem still remains that some funds in which people have already invested because they considered them to be secure, as they do not play around with shares or property, will not have access to imputation credits. We have received quite a number of representations from people who have retired at age 55 or over, who have rolled over their superannuation payout into funds which do not invest in shares and who now look like losing a considerable amount of money. For example, one constituent who retired at age 60 after 40 years of service rolled over his $50,000 superannuation payment into an interest-earning type of roll-over fund. He chose the fund deliberately because he wanted to put his money into a low risk investment; a secure investment; an investment that will not be caught up in another situation similar to October 1987; an investment which is a lower risk than even capital guaranteed funds, which somebody like Eric Mayer has admitted are higher risk funds than fixed interest funds.

This man put his money into an interest-earning type of fund. He knew that he had to take the money out of the fund at age 65. He set out to avoid roll-over funds which invested a high proportion of their assets in property and shares and which could-it happened in 1987-reduce in value over five years. This constituent calculated that, because his approved deposit fund will pay the full 15 per cent tax on its interest earnings, he will lose something like $4,000 over the five years that the money is in the fund. If he moves out of the fund into a capital guaranteed fund he will pay upfront and/or higher management fees of 5 or 6 per cent of his money. Furthermore, he does not want to go into capital guaranteed funds because they invest in shares, despite the impression that is given to the contrary in many advertisements. Some of them have a share exposure of 40 per cent or more. Their substantial shareholdings will enable them to reduce their earnings tax liability. However, the `guarantee' in the words `capital guaranteed fund' is the reserves they can use to support the fund in the event of a market downturn. Maybe not all of them will be able to meet that guarantee. Not everyone wants to take that risk. This particular constituent was one of those people who did not want to take the risk. I have had his figures checked by actuaries, and they are correct.

The Democrats want the legislation to be amended so that the Treasurer is kept to his word that no-one will be one cent worse off. We did not ask him to make that statement; he opened his own mouth voluntarily and, equally voluntarily, he put his own foot in it. Given that, this chamber is entitled to expect that he be kept to his word. I will move an amendment-which we have had drafted because the Government would not allow its parliamentary drafting officers to give us any assistance-to exempt interest-earning roll-overs from the earnings tax for 10 years. I pay tribute to the Clerk and the Clerk Assistants of the Senate for the tremendous amount of work they have done, especially when it comes to providing amendments to legislation, particularly legislation as complex as this, when the Government churlishly refuses to make available its resources. Over the years there have been occasions when the Senate Clerks have produced amendments that have been considerably better, and have gone to the heart of the problem in a more appropriate way, than some of the things that the Government comes up with. I think it is time that we acknowledged the work that they do.

If the Government does not like the amendment, does not think it will work, thinks that it will be administratively difficult, or thinks that it will have unintended consequences, or any of the other Sir Humphrey Appleby reasons that governments come up with, maybe in the time that is available to it before the House rises it can have more appropriate amendments drafted by Treasury and the Tax Office, although I would not hold out much hope of that occurring. If the amendment to exempt fixed interest roll-overs is not successful, the Democrats will resort to supporting the Opposition's amendment which would remove the earnings tax altogether. I do not want to do that, but we will have no choice. I would prefer that the Opposition or the Government supported our amendment simply to quarantine from harm those people who have taken the secure route of investing the exempt fixed interest roll-overs. If that does not happen, we will use the only alternative available to us to make sure that those people will not lose thousands of dollars and be considerably worse off as a result of these changes.

In the last few minutes available to me I would like to look at the revenue issue. When the Treasurer announced the changes in May last year, Treasury estimated that the combined effect of the 15 per cent tax on contributions and earnings would be $980m in 1989-90, rising to approximately $1.4 billion in subsequent years. I raise this issue because a tactic that the Government uses every time somebody in this chamber attempts to amend money legislation or legislation with revenue implications is to complain that this will be the end of the Western world as we know it, it will not have any money to do anything with, it will cost it a small fortune, and it might even have to duck into its $9.6 billion domestic surplus in order to cope. These are Treasury figures: the combined revenue for both the contributions and earnings tax, according to official figures, will be a bit less than $1 billion in the first full operating year and $1.4 billion in subsequent years. Unfortunately, that is where its helpfulness finished because it refused to disclose how much of the revenue comes from the earnings tax and how much from the contributions tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think they know?

—I am not sure it knows anything much at all about anything; certainly, it is about as useful as a hip pocket on a singlet when it comes to providing those of us who have to deal with legislation with the information that we need to make informed decisions. Given that we know how much the total is but we do not know how much each of the elements contributing to the total is, we have had to go outside Treasury to find the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Treasury has given us one other small piece of information. It has argued that most superannuation and roll-over funds will pay little or no tax on earnings. It has said, `Here is the combined total, but we will give you a hint: the earnings tax is not going to form much of it'. National Mutual has estimated that the total earnings tax would be worth $55m to the Government in 1988-89 and $130m by 1990-91. If it is true that all the earnings tax revenue comes from fixed interest roll-overs, because Treasury says that most of the funds will pay little or no earnings tax, the National Mutual figures indicate that the most the Government would lose this year would be $55m and a little over $100m in subsequent years, if the fixed interest funds were quarantined. I think it is somewhat unlikely that the fixed interest roll-over funds would be the only ones to pay the tax. In any event, the amendment we would want would cost revenue less than $55m this year. As I said earlier, it would effectively help the Treasurer to keep his promise about people not being any worse off.

The Government was quite prepared to lose $2 billion last year by cutting company tax at a time when we knew that many major companies in this country were paying little or no tax anyway. The Government and the Opposition gave companies a 20 per cent cut in tax; that is, the tax went from 49c to 39c-a cut of 10c. That $2 billion loss to government revenue is far greater than the $55m that we are looking at today. As I said earlier, we have already seen one State government pass retrospective legislation to avoid the Federal Government's legislation by making the Queensland State superannuation schemes unfunded. On 7 April this year the South Australian Labor Premier, John Bannon, threatened to do the same thing. I wonder how much money the Government will lose if all States act in that way to avoid the tax.

Finally, I wish to mention some further problems that have occurred following the Treasurer's changes last year to the taxation of superannuation. We should take note of those changes for future reference. In announcing the changes to the taxation of superannuation, the Treasurer also announced a new reasonable benefit limits scale. I understand that the scales will be dealt with by changes to regulations to impose new maximum contribution and benefit levels for lump sum and pension funds. The new limits meet some of the objections from welfare groups and the Democrats who have previously attacked inequity in earlier schemes which allowed high income earners to get massive taxpayer-funded lump sum payouts but gave no additional assistance to low income earners. So the measure goes some way to meeting those concerns. The Treasurer also recognised the need to protect benefits which have already been accrued with transitional arrangements designed to preserve the higher benefit limits available to superannuation fund members with pre-July 1988 service. So some parts of the legislation are good and some are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Before calling Senator Messner, I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of former senator and Leader of the Government in the Senate, Ken Wriedt. We welcome him to the Senate gallery and congratulate him on his recent re-election to the Tasmanian House of Assembly.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988INCOME TAX (FUND CONTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the superannuation legislation package. As honourable senators who have spoken earlier mentioned, it is over 12 months since the package was first announced by the Government. That in itself has drawn criticism from the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which drew attention to the fact that the Senate has said in a resolution that if a Bill is introduced some six months or later after the time of the original announcement by press release, the date of commencement of the legislation will be the date on which the Bill was introduced into the Parliament. That is a very rational and reasonable conclusion, given the enormous complexity of the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we must note that the terms of the Senate resolution related to a press release as distinct from what I understood the original announcement in this package to be, which was one of the now famous May economic statements emanating from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). For that reason I suspect that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's comment does not necessarily apply to the present legislation. Nevertheless, the sentiments which are expressed by the Committee are supported by me and other senators from the Liberal and National parties. It is just not good enough for a government to announce a very complicated and difficult taxation regime for a very important area of the Australian economy and then not provide the detailed legislation in a reasonable period. Just before Christmas last year the Government even introduced, after pressure from the Opposition, about one-third of the legislation and said, `Well, we'll deal with the other later. Here's a bit of it so you go away and chew on it'. That is the kind of nonsense that the Government has been going on with for far too long. The Senate has rejected that approach in the past and I hope that the Government will take note of it when it deals with future legislation involving either superannuation or other matters.

Honourable senators who have spoken so far have mentioned the details of the legislation. On this occasion I would prefer not to go too deeply into that, but rather to speak of the principles upon which the legislation has been designed. Let us start by sketching the overall need for a better and more effective retirement incomes policy in this country. Australia is one of those Western nations with a rising proportion of its population in the ageing group. It is estimated that by the year 2010, 8.6 million people, or about 40 per cent of the total population, will be aged over 45. That represents a growth of some 70 per cent in the number of people in middle and old age compared with the situation applying today. So that indicates the kind of challenge which planners, governments and the private enterprise sector need to face. Obviously the taxpayers who will have to fund retirement benefits, either through income support or the provision of aged care, will become fewer in number and, as a result, the burden per capita of those paying tax will rise.

The only answer that can possibly be advised in order to ensure that people are, firstly, looked after well in their old age and, secondly, provided with an adequate income, is to ensure that adequate retirement benefits are available. They must stem from the stimulation of private investment. We must as a nation have a comprehensive and effective retirement incomes policy. Nobody could say that we have such a policy under the Hawke Government. The Government is full of rhetoric, ideals and lofty ideas. Perhaps I should quote one of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what they are.
—Senator Bolkus wants to know what they are.
—Pretty rare.
—Yes, it is pretty rare for Senator Bolkus to take an interest in anything but his own narrow political base in the Left. In last year's May economic statement the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The basic objective of the Government's retirement incomes policy is to ensure that all members of the population have an adequate and secure level of income in retirement.
Those are marvellous words. He went on to say:
The second main objective of the Government's retirement incomes policy is to encourage self-provision for retirement.

Let us look at what the Government has done to achieve those objectives. Firstly, we know that it is all talk and no action. The present legislation does not deliver in any way an effective and comprehensive retirement incomes policy. It is ad hoc and designed to draw out of the superannuation systems some billion dollars a year to fund current consumption expenditure by tax cuts to other taxpayers. That is what the Government is doing. It is not about encouraging people to save for retirement; rather, it is about utilising the funds which people have been saving, drawing off from those funds by way of taxation, and using those funds for expenditures by the Government or to provide tax cuts. Of course, that would find its way mainly into consumption rather than into savings. That is really what the Treasurer was saying in May of last year when he brought down his statement. The Government made those changes only because it wanted the tax revenue from superannuation now rather than at a later time when people collect their retirement income or lump sum benefits. That may be 20 or 30 years down the track, but the Government says, `We can use that money now, by drawing it out of the superannuation funds, for spending and for tax cuts now'.

I turn to the other main benefit of superannuation for our society today, and that, of course, is to stimulate savings. If ever this country needed to stimulate savings, it must be now. Only yesterday we had a new set of statistics which indicated that Australia's foreign debt is now about $125 billion. That means that we have to turn to stimulating our own population's rate of savings to ensure that we rely less and less on overseas borrowings. Many of the current economic problems stemming from the balance of payments difficulties are caused by our low savings ratio. It is salutary just to run over the savings ratio as a percentage of disposable income over the last several years, to get an idea of how this has trended. In the decade from 1971 to 1980, Australia had a savings ratio of 12.4 per cent. From 1978 to 1982, it was 10.5 per cent, a fall of about 2 per cent. But between 1983 and 1987, it fell to 8.9 per cent. This came at a time when there was a similar fall in the savings ratio of many Western nations. But it is salutary to note that the relevant figures for Canada, a country with a similar economic base as our own and with a similar population level, over the same period are 11.3 per cent rising to 14.6 per cent, and settling at 12.9 per cent. The trend in Canada has therefore quite clearly been in favour of stimulating savings, whereas in this country it has been moving in exactly the opposite direction. Of course, there are other examples, Japan and West Germany, which are not typical of the Australian economy but which have similar trends. Those approaches should be adopted in this country.

Superannuation is one of the most critical ways in which we can encourage people to put sums away into funds where they can be supported by tax breaks, and where they can be accumulated and managed by experts in the private sector who can build up substantial benefits for the future for those people and, at the same time, provide a pool of funds from which borrowers and other investors can draw money to stimulate the economic growth of the country. That economic growth means jobs, not just for us but for our children and for the generations yet to come. The funds for that basic infrastructural development are critical to Australia's development, and superannuation funds provide an enormous proportion of the whole and enable stimulation of that growth. That is why we need to lay more emphasis on superannuation fund development and not less, as this legislation tends to do.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public interest which I wish to raise today relates to the Fedorczenko Legacy Fund. I would briefly like to tell the Senate about it today.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this century a man immigrated from Poland to Australia. He had just spent many years in a Russian prison camp in Poland where he was separated from his wife and his children. His family were believed to have been taken to Russia and killed. Mr Fedorczenko loved his new country; he did not want it to suffer the same kind of communist dictatorship that he himself had suffered. So when he died in 1983, at the age of 83, he bequeathed all his assets to the Commonwealth to protect his adopted country against a possible communist invasion.

After legal challenges to Mr Fedorczenko's will, the legacy was eventually received by the Department of Defence on 26 November 1985. The Chief of the Defence Force and the Secretary to the Department had many discussions about the matter and eventually decided that the money should be used solely by the Australian Defence Force Academy. It then took until March 1989 before a decision was taken to invest the money and use the income rather than to use the money at once.

I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Defence Department received this money-$100,000-on 26 November 1985. It took until March 1989 before a decision was even taken about what to do with the money. As yet, however, the money has not even been invested. It has been sitting in a trust fund earning nothing, waiting for the Department of Finance to approve an investment in a fixed term bank deposit. In actual fact, this bureaucratic dithering has meant that Mr Fedorczenko's hard earned money and generous bequest for the defence of Australia is being wasted.

The $100,048 which he left for the defence of Australia is now worth $78,285 in real terms-a waste of some $21,763 of that man's hard earned money which he hoped might contribute to the defence of Australia. If that legacy had at least been sitting in a fixed term deposit since November 1985 whilst the bureaucrats dithered, it would at least be now worth $123,654 after inflation-a gain of $26,606. There is simply no justification for such irresponsible delays and bureaucratic indecision.

That money, for example, could have been put to very good use in things like scholarships to help put students who have qualified for a place at the Defence Force Academy through their higher school certificate year in secondary school. Every year the three services select 50 students each to receive a $1,000 scholarship for their higher school certificate year. Since November 1985 an extra 23 of those students could have been funded just from the interest of the Fedorczenko legacy had it been invested properly. Alternatively, it could have been used, for example, to help cadet organisations at disadvantaged schools throughout Australia to get the equipment and the kit that this Government will not provide for them and makes them find for themselves.

So strapped for resources as Defence is at the present, one would have thought that any extra money would have been appreciated, treated properly and used for any one of a myriad of purposes relating to the defence of Australia, as Mr Fedorczenko had wished. Instead, his patriotic concerns and his kindness have met with an ungrateful procrastination of which the Department of Defence ought to be ashamed.

It does make one wonder whether there are any other trust funds sitting in the Defence Department gathering dust. If there are any other patriotic Australians who would like to contribute to the defence of Australia, I would say to them, `Beware'. Defence is clearly not too good at managing its own money-we know that well enough; it also has not done too well with the management of Mr Fedorczenko's money. So it probably is not too wise to consider leaving a legacy to the Defence Department in the future until it learns to manage its own money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention to certain problems facing thousands of Australian pharmacists-problems created by this present Federal Government and its very erratic administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The blame for these measures must be sheeted home to the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, and especially the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is responsible for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I think it is really quite extraordinary that a Commonwealth department should be making policy decisions on the run, and yet that is exactly what Community Services and Health has been doing under these Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth looking at some of the recent Government decisions in this area. Heavily prescribed drugs were suddenly made highly restricted last August, only to be restored to their former status a few weeks later because of the overwhelming protests from medical and pharmacy spokesmen throughout the country.

Let me refer to some of the people who have criticised the Government's cavalier policies on pharmaceutical benefits. The distinguished former President of the Royal Australian College of Physicians, Professor Priscilla Kincaid-Smith, CBE, stated in relation to the authority listing of ACE inhibitors:
Authority listing of ACE inhibitors is a serious blow to all who believe in preventive medicine.

The Government's response was to brand Professor Kincaid-Smith's comments as `alarmist nonsense'. I wonder whether they accuse the editor of the Medical Journal of Australia of similar nonsense for that journal making the following remarks in August 1988 regarding the placing of 53 drugs on the `authority only' list:

This decision did not include any assessment of the efficacy or cost-effectiveness of the drugs, simply their monthly cost. No discussions with medical or pharmaceutical professions took place before the decision about authority restrictions was made.

The Federal Government made a submission to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal that the Tribunal should make an absolute cut in pharmacists' national health scheme dispensing fees-something never before contemplated by any Federal government and a step which has ruptured the relationship between chemists and the Government.

The next step on the Government's chaotic course was for the Government to insist last month on the de-listing of 12 widely used brands of drugs, which are then to be restored to the PBS list on 1 August. Recently in Tasmania-and this is not surprising-there was a State-wide pharmacy strike, when 174 of the 177 pharmacies in the State were closed for more than three hours and more than 600 chemists and their staffs attended rallies in Hobart, Launceston and Burnie. This was the first ever stoppage in the history of the profession and an action which was not taken lightly.

Honourable senators would know that pharmacists are basically conservative people and that they have taken up a career path which is devoted to the service of the community. The Government in general, and regrettably Mr Staples in particular, unfortunately have tried to smear the reputation of pharmacists in Tasmania when they stopped work and, more recently, when similar action was also taken in New South Wales. The inference that the Government tries to promote is that pharmacists are wealthy and living off the system.

Let us examine some of the comments of the Minister in charge of the PBS, Mr Staples, on 9 March. The Minister described the Pharmacy Guild of Australia as running a `scare campaign' amongst the sick and elderly in order to boost members' income. On 9 May, he compounded this slander by describing the Pharmacy Guild as `the biggest spreader of misinformation of any national organisation in this country'. This is wholly incorrect and is the sort of statement that is made only behind the protection of parliamentary privilege.

The vast majority of pharmacists in Tasmania, and I am sure in all of the other States, have heavy overdrafts to carry on their businesses because of the high overheads that they have to sustain. They provide a service to the community under very rigid guidelines, both from their professional bodies such as the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, and from the pharmacy boards in each State and Territory. Most of them are earning average and, in many cases, below average weekly earnings.

The Hawke Government has taken an aggressive stance and anybody who denies this should have witnessed the comments of Mr Staples in Burnie recently when he was presented with a petition against changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Unfortunately, the situation has now been reached where no pharmacist in private practice in Australia has a great deal of confidence in Mr Staples and the current policies of the Government. This has been exacerbated by strikes, marches and even legal action in the courts.

While this Government tries to cut the returns to pharmacists, these same people have had to fund salary increases, rent increases, an impending 3 per cent superannuation award and the loss of time due to the 38-hour week. There are approximately 5,200 pharmacies in Australia. They are not only a major component of the small business sector but also a major employer of women. It is worth reminding the Government that 60 per cent of pharmacists and 99 per cent of pharmacy assistants are women. I think it is appropriate at this stage that I should comment that I do have a vested interest because my wife is a salaried pharmacist on a part time basis. Certainly these people will remember the Government's actions when they next vote.

Along with many of my colleagues, I have been inundated with letters from individual pharmacists, who have always been apolitical and have been prompted to write in protest as never before. They have drawn my attention to many aspects of the maladministration of the scheme, including a lack of adequate supply of replacement generic drugs; and the de-listing of many products-only to have them relisted subsequently, confusing both the professionals and the patients. Indeed, there has also been a lot of confusion about the availability of drugs. Other problems include the 5.2 per cent surcharge on wholesale prices and continual delays in PBS payments. Unfortunately, Tasmanian pharmacists seem to be singled out for special treatment in this area. Problems are also treated by the late payment of the national health scheme claim results. The April statement introduced by Mr Keating proposes a reduction in dispensing margins from 25 per cent to 10 per cent and a dispensing fee of $3.30 discounted by 25 per cent.

How is this Government handling the problems? It has set aside $1.1m to pay for the extra staff needed to process `authority only' forms; $2m has been earmarked to educate doctors on prescribing practices; and it has wasted thousands of dollars on sending out ridiculous red and white capsules to medical practitioners and pharmacists-a cost only revealed by Senator Cook after a probing question posed by my colleague, Senator Sue Knowles. Therefore, the Government's answer is to pour more money into an already bloated bureaucracy to administer more and more red tape while thousands of chemist shops throughout Australia shut their doors and pharmacists quite simply go bankrupt. Unfortunately, it is going to be the remote areas of Australia, the small country towns, that will lose this sort of service.

The fine print of the April statement shows that spending on the PBS will be cut by $31m in 1989-90; by $96m in 1990-91; and by $156m in 1991-92. These figures clearly demonstrate just how deliberately the Government is white-anting the scheme which has, up until now, received bipartisan support for approximately 40 years. The facts of the matter are that the administration of PBS in recent times under this Hawke Government has been quite hopeless and bad in the extreme. I am sure that members of the Government, especially Ministers, who have represented the Department of Community Services and Health in this place over the past few years, have been privately embarrassed to have to defend some of the policies-particularly policies that have been made on the run-that have come out from this Department. The coalition promises a complete review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, so as not to humble pharmacists to the point of bankruptcy, deny patients urgently needed medication and unnecessarily disrupt what was previously an efficient scheme which delivered the service for which it was established.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk about concerns expressed in Western Australia about the proposed merger of the University of Western Australia (UWA) and Murdoch University. Few on either campus actually appear to want this merger and it seems that the decision will depend entirely on the threatened consequences of not merging. The deleterious consequences of not merging have been stated orally-that is, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to the vice-chancellors-but they have never been expressed explicitly and openly. For public consumption, Mr Dawkins says it is entirely up to the universities. But a major sotto voce threat is to take away from Murdoch University the right to teach external degree programs if it does not agree to merge. Murdoch University pioneered external university studies in Western Australia and about one-third of its students are taking some or all of their units externally. The loss of external teaching would be financially crippling, even in the absence of other financial measures against Murdoch University which have been quietly threatened.

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to take away external teaching is subtly put. If Murdoch University does not merge, it is told the Western Australian College of Advanced Education (WACAE) will be given the Western Australia's Distance Education Centre, that is, the sole right to run external courses. In theory, Murdoch could continue to teach its external students through the Distance Education Centre, controlled by the WACAE. However severe rationalisation of external offerings can be expected.

The Western Australian State Minister for Education, Dr Carmen Lawrence, has repeatedly stated that only a merger voluntarily entered into by the two universities would be supported by the State Government, which has the constitutional authority to change the University Act to accommodate a merger. The Senate of Murdoch University has set out six requirements which it states are of fundamental importance to Murdoch University. Those requirements, which were published in the university magazine Changes, are:
1. That the academic staff on both campuses have equal access to research and teaching.
2. That the terms of employment shall not deteriorate.

3. That the Murdoch campus will continue to offer a wide range of disciplines, to develop its own courses and programmes at both undergraduate and graduate level, and retain its commitment to interdisciplinary study.
4. That any new academic structure continues to promote openness and to allow staff at all levels the opportunity to participate in decision making.
5. That a liberal admissions policy be retained.
6. a.) That the Vice-Chancellor of the amalgamated University should have an office and a presence on both campuses.

b.) That there should be a senior academic at Deputy Vice-Chancellor level on each campus with responsibility for the co-ordination of the academic policies on each campus supported by an appropriate administrative structure.
Any merger not containing these conditions can, therefore, only be seen as forced.

The University of Western Australia receives some $20m per annum from income on endowments, independently of government finance. It, therefore, has far less to lose from Commonwealth Government financial retribution than does Murdoch University and it is, therefore, in a position to dictate terms of any merger. Its own requirements are at odds with the Murdoch University's Senate's conditions. A merger would, therefore, destroy the educational gains to Western Australia which have been achieved by Murdoch University, some of which are indicated in the Murdoch University Senate's six conditions, which I have just read, and others of which include strong encouragement of educationally disadvantaged groups. For example, more than half of Murdoch University's students are women and about 40 per cent of students are over 30 years of age.

The University of Western Australia has already begun unilaterally appointing senior administrators who would run the combined university. Mr Jeff Gawthorne, the Pro Vice-Chancellor (Academic) of Murdoch University, wrote a letter on 4 May 1989 to school deans and heads of units in which he said:

From 1990 DEET will provide a block grant to the new University of Western Australia rather than separate grants to Murdoch an UWA. The principles and procedures that should apply to internal allocation of the funds need to be agreed between the Universities as soon as possible, so that action can be taken to advertise new positions.

In other words, it seems that the merger is presupposed. A considerable number of Murdoch University staff are not unhappy about a merger which preserves Murdoch University's distinct features but most of them, plus those which would not contemplate a merger at all in the absence of financial threats, are deeply concerned at the increasing evidence that the merger will be forced and that it will, in reality, be a takeover rather than a genuine amalgamation.

Mr Dawkins's Department, the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET), has foreshadowed that Murdoch University's funding for 1990 is to be paid directly to the University of Western Australia. DEET has covered itself with reference to current negotiations but it has been made clear to the Murdoch Vice-Chancellor that he can assume that Murdoch University will be past history by next year and that all funds will be handled by the University of Western Australia. This is in spite of the fact that neither of the university senates has decided on a merger and the State Parliament has not passed the necessary legislation. So this sweeps aside the fiction that the States are responsible for making the major decisions about university education.

I have also received a letter from a member of the academic staff at UWA who writes on behalf of other academics at the university and expresses extreme concern. I will merely pass on to the Senate some aspects of the letter. It states:

I have not seen any public arguments in favour of the merger which show any benefit to anyone. The cost of administering a merger of any type would be, and indeed already is, prodigious in terms of man hours which could be spent on teaching and research and are instead committed to bureaucratic idiocies. . . The loss to students, who would perforce have less choice. . . to the academics who would have to waste some ten per cent of their time commuting between sites in one scenario, and the taxpayer, who has to pay for turning productive academics into bad bureaucrats because the existing bureaucracy isn't big enough, has never been assessed. . . It might pass without comment in Romania and be accepted with resignation in Poland, but that Australia should have got to the point where imbecile plans can be imposed by government fiat in the face of reason it scandalous. The only people inside the Universities who favour a merger appear to be those empire builders who, like their political masters, have no interest in either research or teaching, and hope to profit from those who do. The academics who oppose the merger do so quite simply because it can only make it harder to do what they want to do-which is to do research and teach.
The letter goes on to talk about the White Paper. It states:

On the White Paper, the document is so full of internal inconsistencies that it is plainly intended to placate the credulous, while in fact, turning Universities into extensions of the bureaucracy. It is a cynical exploitation of those innocent souls who trust the government to be honourable and to do what is best for society . . . The model of the Universities as widget factories that can be improved by central administration is so manifestly silly that few advanced societies have tried it. And those that did, didn't stay advanced for very long.

If Mr Dawkins wants the Universities to be doing more applicable research, he is using the worst methods which could be devised. I suggest that the main barriers to getting Australia research into Industry are on the Industry side . . .
It also says:

We are not protesting some reforms that threaten our privileges, we are protesting that we are being diverted from doing our teaching and research in order to support the centralist bureaucratic idiocies which have such a depressing record elsewhere.

In conclusion, we need to know whether it is true that DEET has already decided, without having regard to decisions by the senates of both universities in Western Australia, that the merger will definitely take place. I would suggest to honourable senators that the merger of universities in general can be supported in any State only for good educational reasons and not for any reasons of convenience.
