TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given Australia's record foreign debt burden, the continuing balance of payments crisis, and crippling interest rates, when does the Government realistically expect that Australians will experience the improved living standards promised again yesterday by the Prime Minister?

—First, an analysis of living standards of Australians across the board over the last few years does not show some of the dire consequences that are alleged by the Opposition from time to time. That is because a lot more people have been in employment, and social welfare expenditure is being maintained. I cannot, off the top of my head, go into all the details, but that is a fact. In the light of the Government's tax cuts, which will come into force on 1 July, and the wage improvements which will come about in the next 12 months, I think it is possible to say that Australian living standards can be maintained.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 31 May 1989 headed `NSW car thefts'? Does the article carry a claim from the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA) that the rate of car theft in New South Wales, at 19.36 per 1,000 cars, is higher than that of New York, which is 12.76 per 1,000 cars? Does the Association sheet home some of the blame to Australian car manufacturers and call on them to equip cars with the type of simple locking mechanisms that are used overseas? If this criticism is found to be valid, will the Minister approach Australian manufacturers in an effort to improve both security and sales of Australian products?

—The Premier of Western Australia has had something to say on this issue. His own car was stolen last year, and after that incident he sent me a copy of the lock on the car, which I keep as a souvenir. He made some noisy complaints about the quality of locking devices on cars. I have seen the reports to which Senator Jones refers.
—It was like the lock that they had on the State Treasury.

—Well, I did say something in response to the Premier. In recent times the NRMA has been conscientious in raising public awareness of the car theft issue and I am sure that its latest efforts will contribute to a better appreciation of the problem, not only among manufacturers but in the community generally. Car theft is, of course, an issue of growing concern. It cannot be overcome by any single measure. As for the NRMA spokesman's comments on the responsibility of car manufacturers, I have to say that a more balanced view suggests that the Australian industry, like its overseas counterparts, has been active in combating the problem. That is not to say that there is not more that could be done. Any vehicle, imported or locally made, is vulnerable to theft by forced entry. Locking devices are perhaps a help but they only make entry more difficult, not impossible. The Australian car industry, in consultation with State and Commonwealth authorities, supported the introduction of new vehicle identification numbers for all new vehicles from 1 January 1989, through the Australian design rule system. That is expected to contribute to making the theft of cars much less attractive.
—This is a pretty mundane question. You have the economy in tatters, yet you are talking about locks on cars. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

—In addition, the industry's national body-the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries-has adopted a code of practice to deal with theft deterrence to help combat the problem. In this regard, I am aware that important development work is being carried out in the Australian components sector to try to address some of these issues. So Senator Jones's invitation to me to approach the car industry about the matter is not really necessary at this point. I know that this issue is not important to Senator Boswell, but it may well be very important to a number of sections of the community, and I am sure that it was in that spirit that Senator Jones asked the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Government accept that it is primarily responsible for national economic management? If so, does the Minister agree that it is the Government-not the banks, not the Opposition, not anyone else-that is responsible for the interest rates which are crushing Australian home buyers, small businesses and farmers? Just as the Labor Party, when in opposition, encouraged the growth of home interest protest groups in the early 1980s, will it ensure that Government speakers attend the meetings now being organised around Australia by similar community groups so that home buyers may hear from those who are responsible an explanation for the situation? Would it not have been a good idea if last night's meeting of a community group known as Interest Rate Protest had been attended by a Government Minister, so that the 1,000 or so angry home purchasers who were present could have heard from the Government an explanation of their plight?
—I did not know that Senator Reid's colleagues in the Liberal Party had stolen the idea of interest rate protest groups from the Labor Party. It is not unusual--
—You had no idea-period.

—The question implies that that is where the idea was obtained. I did not know that that had happened, but I am interested in the information. The Government is primarily responsible-to use the words in Senator Reid's question-for economic management. There is no doubt about that. Whether that imposes an obligation on Government spokesmen to attend rallies or conferences, or whatever, organised by any sector of the community aggrieved by some particular aspect of economic management is another matter, but I do not think that that follows at all. If one is concerned about economic management, the most important thing is to get on with it-not, as honourable senators opposite tend to do, listen to every isolated group around the place that wants to hold a rally.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen press reports concerning the intention of the United States Administration to supply arms to the non-communist resistance in Cambodia? Does the Government believe that this will help to bring about an early and lasting settlement in Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen reports in this morning's press-supplemented by material from our mission in Washington-that the United States Administration has indicated that it will seek the approval of Congress for a program to supply rifles and other lethal weapons to the non-communist resistance headed by Prince Sihanouk. This is a topic that I have discussed with Secretary of State Baker. Both I and the Prime Minister discussed it with Vice-President Quayle when he was here in Australia. In those discussions with the United States, both the Prime Minister and I counselled real caution about providing lethal aid to Prince Sihanouk and those forces working with him at a time when diplomatic efforts were in train and making obvious progress toward a Cambodian settlement.

ANSWER.PARA: While the Australian Government continues to regard Prince Sihanouk's role as absolutely crucial to any lasting settlement in Cambodia, the Government is concerned that the supply of arms to the non-communist resistance, rather than assisting the diplomatic process, which is the stated United States rationale, will work against the process of achieving agreement among the factions on an internal settlement. Accommodation among the factions is the major stumbling block at present in the way of an overall statement.

It can also be said that there is a real risk that some of the arms supplied to the non-communist resistance could find their way into the hands of the Khmer Rouge, the third partner in the forces of the CGDK-the Coalition Government of Democratic Cambodia-which is obviously something that we would deplore. In that context I should say that I do not want anything that I have said this afternoon to be taken as in any way critical of the United States position on the Khmer Rouge. Vice-President Quayle made very clear that the United States, like Australia, wants absolutely no return to the brutality of the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia. We are all determined that such a tragedy must not again befall the people of that country. As a result we are very concerned to ensure that negotiations for a resolution of the Cambodian issue will succeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOGGING OPERATIONS IN SOUTH-EASTERN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to an environmental impact statement (EIS) conducted by the Forestry Commission of New South Wales covering proposed logging operations from 1989 to 2009 for the whole of the Eden management area. This EIS is in addition to an EIS previously prepared for a portion of that area. I ask: Does the Minister or his Department have, or have access to, the complete 1989-2009 EIS or any portion thereof? If not, why not? If the Minister does not have the complete 1989-2009 EIS, will he obtain it immediately and take appropriate action to protect the National Estate? If he does have the EIS will he immediately examine the additional areas covered in the 1989-2009 EIS for prudent and feasible alternatives to logging, as he is required to do under section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act? What proportion of the entire Eden management area does the 1989-2009 EIS cover compared to the previous EIS? In view of the fact that the Jarasius decision was intended to protect forests from logging, is the Minister now perverting the intent of the Jarasius decision by citing it as an excuse for not examining feasible alternatives to logging for the entire Eden region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sanders has to be recognised as a late developer in this debate. Apart from Government senators and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Dunn must take the prize for persistence in arguing for the environmental lobby. I am getting a bit annoyed with questions which assert things which are factually wrong as if they were right and, on the basis of that, go ahead and draw conclusions. Senator Sanders's question is riddled with factual errors, the first one being that the New South Wales Forestry Commission conducted an EIS for 1989-2009. It did not. That EIS was conducted by Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd on guidelines agreed to between Harris-Daishowa, the then Department of Environment, which has been taken over by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, DASETT, and in consultation with the State department of the environment in New South Wales. Harris-Daishowa conducted the EIS, not the New South Wales Forestry Commission. I would have expected someone who puts himself forward as an expert in this issue actually to know the factual base of it, and not gloss over the facts.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go to the questions. As I have said, the EIS to which Senator Sanders has referred was not conducted by the Forestry Commission. I have explained whom it was conducted by. That EIS covers the period 1989 to 2000. I am aware of it: I have a copy of it and I have certainly read it.

The next question was about prudent and feasible alternatives. Senator Sanders should know that I have thoroughly and exhaustively considered prudent and feasible alternatives that I have put forward to the logging plan in the south-east forest. He should know that because last week I tabled in the Senate a fairly full document which was a full analysis of my consideration of those prudent and feasible alternatives. I imagine that Senator Sanders has read it. No-one has yet come forward to challenge the content of that consideration. The absence of a challenge by Senator Sanders or his question to the content of that consideration is a notable omission. The current EIS for the period 1989-2009 covers the entire Eden management area of 630,000 hectares and considers the environmental impact of Harris- Daishowa's operations beyond 31 December 1989 to 31 December 2009.

The Commonwealth plans for the south-east forests do not pervert the intention of the Jarasius decision. Since this is now a matter of contention Senator Sanders should get the Jarasius decision out and read it so that he can be satisfied on that point. That decision relates specifically to the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1980 and imposes an obligation on the Forestry Commission of New South Wales to prepare a separate environmental impact statement if the forestry activity is likely to significantly affect the environment. As a result of that decision an EIS was completed by the Forestry Commission of New South Wales. That EIS covers forestry operations in the Eden management area and adds to the information presented to the Harris-Daishowa EIS by specifically addressing those additional matters required by New South Wales law. The information provided by the Forestry Commission EIS was taken into account in the preparation of my consideration, which I tabled here, under section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

I conclude my answer by making this observation: I would be a bit more accepting of the criticism of the balanced, considered and rational proposition the Commonwealth has put forward to bring to a conclusion the dispute in the south-east forests, to enable the environmental aspects to be protected and properly studied, and to enable the industry to continue, if people such as Senator Sanders asked, `What should be the fate of the 700 families who are dependent on the industry in that area?'. These people are operating in a regional zone with twice the unemployment level of elsewhere in New South Wales. Indeed, that is a consideration of the Commonwealth as well. We should not simply argue one side of it; we should find the right balance between both sides in order to meet the objectives of both sides. I have heard this from Senator Dunn; she at least is aware of the question. I have not heard it from Senator Sanders. I would like to hear it from him some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that he cannot seek prudent and feasible alternatives except in areas in which the New South Wales Government has deigned to conduct its own EIS?

—I commend to Senator Sanders a reading of the Jarasius decision. I commend to him a reading of my full documentary consideration of how I meet section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act, which I have tabled, which is a public document and which I have not been criticised on. If he reads those two documents he will find the answers to his questions.

—My question is asked of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's attitude to the outcome of the recently concluded North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) summit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The declaration that emerged from this week's NATO summit is an important and timely document, as I would hope the Opposition would appreciate. In what has been a very balanced and responsible statement, NATO has chartered a course that is fully responsive to the unprecedented opportunities that are now available to establish a new pattern of relations between East and West characterised by cooperation, trust and peaceful competition. We applaud particularly in this respect the very constructive leadership shown by President Bush at the summit by responding with imagination and boldness in seeking a satisfactory compromise by linking progress on conventional force reductions in Europe with reductions in short-ranged nuclear forces (SNF). It is a linking such that, once implementation of a conventional arms control agreement is under way, the United States, in consultation with its allies, is prepared to enter into negotiations to achieve a partial reduction in United States and Soviet land-based nuclear forces of shorter range to equal and verifiable levels.

ANSWER.PARA: The highlights of the NATO declaration included acknowledgment of the important and welcome changes taking place in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and some Eastern European countries; a resolve to maintain viable and credible defences of the lowest possible level consistent with security requirements; the view that, based on the historic progress of recent years, the alliance can now exploit fully the potential of arms control as an agent of change; a far-reaching proposal to radically cut, as I have said, conventional forces in Europe in an ambitious timetable to reach and implement the agreement; a determination to press ahead comprehensively through the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe process to overcome the division of Europe; a resolve to develop NATO into a more mature and balanced partnership corresponding to the political and economic realities of the 1990s; and, finally, a clear acknowledgment that security has to be seen in a broader context and include such issues as environmental degradation, resources and complex and grave economic disparities.

These developments all have, in their way, important implications for Australia in that, just as we could not in the past escape the ramifications of East-West tensions over Europe, so these new developments should enhance encouraging trends that are equally apparent in our part of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the foreign debt figures for the March quarter, which show that gross foreign debt rose by almost $7 billion over the quarter to $128.6 billion while net foreign debt rose by more than $7 billion to $103.2 billion, breaking the $100 billion barrier for the first time. Given the continuing chronic deficit on the current account, which now looks like reaching $17 billion for the year and more than 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), does the Minister agree that Australia's debt level and debt servicing burden will go on increasing? Does the Minister consider that the current account deficit, the level of debt and its rate of increase are sustainable? If not, would the Minister advise the Senate and the people of Australia what this Government, which is responsible for this mismanagement, intends to do about it?

—There are a number of questions there. I will try to do justice to some of them in my answer. If the foreign debt is stated in money terms, as I have said before in this place, it is a cause of concern. However, the ratio of net foreign debt to GDP is down to 31.7 per cent from 32.4 per cent 12 months ago. That does not mean that that is any source of great comfort, but it has to be compared with the somewhat flamboyant question which I was asked by Senator Parer.
—It was not flamboyant at all; it was a genuine, simple and good question.

—Senator Parer has got full marks from the Acting Leader of the Opposition. He says that it was a good question. It is important to note the composition of Australia's foreign debt. Attention has been drawn to that in recent times by several Government and non-Government spokesmen. That has been done to counteract the somewhat nonsensical view put by some Opposition spokesmen that this debt is owned by every Australian family and so on. It is not owed by every Australian family, or by the Federal Government.
—Who is going to pay it back? Aren't we the borrowers? Aren't we, the Government, borrowers?

—You should know! When I was asked a question by Senator Jones earlier in Question Time, Senator Boswell interjected and said that it was a trivial question when this country is faced with a great crisis. Senator Boswell now indicates that he does not understand the parameters or the extent of the great crisis to which he was referring earlier in Question Time. I am just making the point that it is nonsensical for people to go round saying that this is a debt owed by the Government or on behalf of Australian families. It is essentially corporate debt and debt by State authorities. In so far as the debt level does require Government action, the Government believes that it has in place policies that will deal with these issues-not tomorrow, not next week. Even three or four years ago, when discussing this question of national debt, Government spokesmen were saying that they did not expect our national debt to stabilise until the early 1990s. That is a consistent position.
—Do you think we can wait until the debt has stabilised? The dollar is going down day by day. You have no options.

—Senator Lewis says there are no options. One can wait for the debt to stabilise and to be reversed. In so far as the Government had debt, that has been done. Alternatively, one can follow the sort of knee-jerk responses that those opposite would introduce, based on their interjections at Question Time, which would only exacerbate the situation in both the short and the long term.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister referred in his reply to comments on our side as being nonsensical. I think the Prime Minister referred to comments about our concern about the debt crisis as being scaremongering. Yet he himself said that it was an external problem that we needed to address. That was the basis of my question. If it is not the problem that the Minister says it is, what is the external problem to which the Prime Minister refers, and how does the Government intend to address it?
—Senator Parer asks an important question and does not listen to the answer. I did not say that it was not a problem. I said that it was a matter of great concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Minister see an article on petrol prices in various parts of the world which appeared in the London Economist recently? Does the information contained in that article provide support for the campaign currently being mounted in Australia by various motoring organisations complaining about the present levels of taxation on petrol in this country?

—I have seen the article, and it certainly does not provide any support for the campaign being waged by a number of motoring organisations. It gives figures of the price, converted into United States dollars at the official exchange rate, of a United States gallon of petrol in 25 different cities around the world at the end of 1988. The highest price in the world is in Tokyo with $4.10 a gallon and the lowest was in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, with 14c. Certainly, if the healthy state of its international account is taken as an indicator of how soundly its economy is managed, then Japan is obviously right at the top of the world league, but I do not think that it should be concluded that there is necessarily a correlation between the price of petrol and the health of an economy. It does not necessarily mean that, at every level, countries can be ranked in accordance with the price of petrol. But the difference in those prices, as was explained in the article, is the varying levels of taxation imposed on petrol by different governments. Of the 25 cities listed, Sydney was ranked sixteenth. It had cheaper petrol than 15 of the 25 cities listed. We are well below the general level of taxes that apply to petrol in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. It is about time the motoring organisations realised this and dropped the silly campaign they have run sporadically for as long as I can remember, and that is that whatever the tax is on fuel that amount should be spent on roads. That has never been the case in Australia, and it has never been the case, I do not think, in any overseas country, and never will be. It is about time they dropped that silly campaign.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. Does he agree that the Government's policies are directed to cutting the level of activity in the housing industry and slowing down demand generally? If that is the case, would the Government prefer to see banks and other home lenders require higher repayments rather than extended terms so that its policy of higher interest rates makes a greater contribution to the Government's policy objectives?
—I think Senator Boswell has directed the question to the wrong Minister. His question is about interest rates and that is a question that goes to an economic Minister.
—Mr President, may I direct my question to the Minister for Finance, seeing Senator Cook was not game to have a go at the question? Senator Cook has evaded his responsibility. He will not have a go.
—Senator Boswell, I will allow you to ask the question the next time I call a member of the Opposition.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Further to my question earlier this week about the plight of a Queensland rural family, has the Minister's attention been drawn to the plight of farmers in the Burnett district of Queensland following heavy rain and calls for the Commonwealth Government to make available some form of financial assistance? Is it the case that until very recently, the Burnett district was drought declared and farmers in the area were receiving Commonwealth-financed drought relief? What further action will the Government take to assist the farmers of the Burnett district?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Courtice, the hardworking and popular member for Hinkler, has written to me drawing my attention to calls for assistance from farmers in the Burnett region. I do remember seeing a number of letters addressed to me, usually from the South Burnett area, I think, with demands, claims, requests-whatever you like to call them-for more Commonwealth money for drought relief. Mr Courtice has now sent me a copy of a press release from a couple of the National Party members in the area, one of whom is Mr Slack.
—An appropriate name.
—Yes, appropriately named. I will read a couple of extracts from the press release. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: There are many farmers in the Burnett area who, following weeks of wet weather, now find themselves in a desperate financial position. . .
It has been estimated by the Burnett Graingrowers Association that over 50% of the peanuts planted will not be able to be harvested and at least 70% of navy beans may have been lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the peanuts!
—I do not know whether this applies to the other peanut growing centre of Australia, Kingaroy, but it is not that far away. The press release also states:

ANSWER.PARA: In many cases soya beans are a disaster and grain crops are sprouting in the head through delays in harvesting.
. . . it was particularly heartbreaking when the farmers' hopes for a good year this year were literally shattered by too much continued wet weather.
In the meantime, they urge growers who had suffered major crop losses and were in financial difficulties to apply for disaster relief at their nearest Q.I.D.C. Office.

It was announced in the April statement that drought had been removed from eligibility for funding under national disaster relief arrangements, but there is still, under the NDRA, provision for flood disaster relief. I am pleased that it has rained in the Burnett district. I do not expect that I will get any complaints or calls for drought assistance for probably a couple of weeks because of that. As Senator Puplick once observed, when he was President of the Young Liberals, of the then Country Party he said, `When the sun shines they want drought relief; when it rains they want flood relief; and when it grows they want a subsidy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it is funny?

—Senator Puplick obviously thought the attitude of the Country Party was one that should be publicly ridiculed, and he did publicly ridicule it. If the Queensland Government declares the Burnett district a disaster area because of the floods, the area will be eligible for Commonwealth assistance under NDRA, but I hope it makes a very careful evaluation before it does that-more careful evaluations than it has made in the past. Mr Courtice also tells me that the cattle which won the prize for fat cattle at the Townsville Show came from a drought declared property.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance in view of the fact that Senator Cook was unable and unwilling to answer a very simple question on housing. Does the Minister agree that the Government's policies are directed to cutting the level of activity in the housing industry and slowing down demand generally? If that is the case, would the Government prefer to see banks and other home lenders require higher repayments rather than extended terms so that its policy of higher interest rates makes a greater contribution to the Government's policy objectives?

—Of course the objective of a tight monetary policy is to take excessive demand out of the economy. It is widely believed, however, that that is more difficult to do in a deregulated financial system than in a regulated one. Certainly, the experience in Australia over the last six or 12 months tends to confirm that belief. But the arrangements banks and their clients make about the repayment of loans are a matter for the banks and their clients to settle and not for the Government.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of the alleged plight of about 10,000 British immigrants in Australia who were sent here as children during the postwar years under an enforced child migration program for so-called destitute or abandoned children? Has the Minister seen recent United Kingdom reports that many of these British child migrants were the victims of horrific cruelty and sexual abuse in Australia and also that now as adults they have no knowledge of or access to their family backgrounds? Given that the Australian Government apparently was a party to such migration, what action is now being taken to help those still suffering from the effects of the forced separation from close relatives, on some occasions, and from friends?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read an abridged article on those United Kingdom reports in one of the Australian newspapers. From initial research, I think many of the allegations happen to be true. It was of course a different time in the 1950s and different standards applied. Quite clearly, it was thought to be a philanthropic thing to take orphans and others and ship them off to Australia and Canada. More serious was the shipping of those children to countries in Africa, et cetera, where apparently the idea was to redress the racial balance, or implant enough of a racial balance for survival. Many of those children who came to Australia went into circumstances where they were abused, where they were exploited and where their life was made a misery which has caused social problems for them later.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that in the 1988 spring conference of the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators, a decision was made that all Australian authorities would assist those people in tracing their parents and in establishing their background. I would hesitate to say that past Australian governments were culpable in this regard. Possibly they could have ensured that there was a better form of supervision, at both State and Federal levels. I do not think they knew the conditions under which these children came out. We were talking about a period of 25-odd years. Anything we can do at a Federal level-I am sure the State governments and the United Kingdom Government feel the same-to assist these people to find out what their origins were, maybe to trace parents, if that is a feasible process, and also to counsel them and give them support services because of the traumas they have been through, will be done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a Brisbane Courier-Mail report this morning of the Treasurer's press conference in Paris yesterday, in which Mr Keating apparently said that he had no regrets about the present state of things in Australia. Mr Keating is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: If we were to take the soft option of leaving monetary conditions soft, we would have a runaway demand position, runaway inflation and a very, very hard and nasty landing after that.

With real domestic demand rising by over 11 per cent in the past 12 months, do we not already have a runaway demand position? With prices rising by almost 7 per cent in the past 12 months, and now rising even faster, do we not already have runaway inflation? With present Government policies, are we not already set for a very, very hard and nasty landing? Finally, since we already have, or at least have in prospect, all the things that Mr Keating quite rightly fears, has this come about because of having `monetary conditions soft' or have there been some failings elsewhere in the mix of Government policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come back to some of the details later, but Senator Stone is essentially asking me to indulge in a bit of economic forecasting. I am reluctant to do that. One of the reasons why I am reluctant to do it is that I have seen the horrible crashes that some people have when they do indulge in economic forecasting. I remember Senator Stone writing immediately after the October 1987 stock market crash. With his usual explicit conviction of infallibility, he wrote `There is absolutely no doubt that there will be a world-wide recession in 1988'. It did not happen. That draws attention in a pretty spectacular way to the hazards of making economic forecasts, particularly dogmatic economic forecasts. I do not intend to accept his offer to do that.

ANSWER.PARA: The other figures that Senator Stone quoted were correct or approximately correct. It is a matter of record that gross national expenditure for the March quarter of 1989 over the same quarter in 1988 grew by 11 per cent, approximately double the growth in our gross domestic product. One of the swing items in that was a big increase in imports. The Government believes that that is unsustainable. That is the reason why we are running a tight monetary policy. Everything the Treasurer said seems to me to be consistent with that. Whether inflation, which is approaching 7 per cent, is runaway inflation depends largely on what Senator Stone's expectations are. In the 1960s it would have been considered to be runaway inflation but it is certainly not runaway inflation compared to some recent experiences, in particular, in 1981 and 1982 when the coalition was in government when it managed to achieve inflation above 10 per cent, unemployment above 10 per cent and a $10 billion Budget deficit. No government in Australia has come close to matching that sort of runaway inflation with such a high level of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Despite the commendable intention of the Government to eliminate the use of rainforest timbers in Commonwealth Government projects in future, which I just heard enunciated in the other place, does the Government have a policy on rainforest logging in Australia, and, if so, what is it? To what extent does logging of rainforest timber take place on public and private land in Australia? Does the Government have any control over rainforest logging on private land in Australia? Does the Government have a policy on the importation of rainforest timber and products containing rainforest timber? What moves, if any, has the Government made towards the banning of rainforest timber imports and related products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is opposed to rainforest logging and has taken a number of pretty substantial steps to indicate that opposition.
—In north Queensland 2,500 jobs lost.

—I will get to that. I am glad that Senator Boswell mentioned that. In 1986 the Government provided over $22m for the national rainforest conservation program, which was to work with the States to implement a number of initiatives for rainforest conservation. Beyond that, in 1987 the Government established the national afforestation program to encourage State and local governments, companies, community groups and land-holders to increase their investments in hardwood plantations.
—Did you have the courage to go out and meet the loggers today?
—I am meeting a delegation of loggers this afternoon. I am very happy to meet them. I have met them in fairly spectacular confrontations all over the country, and I will be doing so in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond those initiatives, the Government has taken the initiative on World Heritage nominations for the rainforests of north Queensland and for very considerable rainforest areas in New South Wales. In the case of New South Wales, that confirmed the ban on logging in those rainforests. In the case of Queensland, it led to a ban. Our World Heritage area in Tasmania also includes some areas of rainforest. The Tasmanian Government, the Government that used to be there-the one that Senator Walters supported--

TALK.START.PARA: —And is still there.

—I admit that it is still there. It has another three weeks. The Tasmanian Government put a moratorium on all rainforest logging on public land in Tasmania. Even the Tasmanian Government, not known for its conservation stance according to the electorate in Tasmania, which has made sure that that Government no longer has a parliamentary majority, took that step.

ANSWER.PARA: While the Commonwealth is proud of its actions on the fronts I have just mentioned, it is true that some rainforest logging still goes on, particularly on private land. In north Queensland that is certainly the case. Given Senator Boswell's earlier interjection about the 2,500 jobs, the fact is that 2,500 jobs did not get lost. One of the reasons for that is that rainforest logging has kept going. The other is that before the ban the companies took so much timber out of the forest that their stockpiles were much greater than Senator Boswell had been prepared to concede. Nonetheless, it is true to say that logging does go on in small patches in Queensland. In New South wales there is virtually no logging on private land now. Since 1982 all general purpose rainforest logging on public land in New South Wales has been phased out in favour of hardwood substitution. I think that is still the case. I have a feeling that there is one rainforest logging operation which still goes on in Grafton, but I believe it will end shortly. There is not much in Tasmania. A very small amount of rainforest logging can be done on private land. Obviously rainforest logging is now confined to some very small areas and the Commonwealth has no authority over those areas. All we can do is offer as much moral persuasion as we can and use those rainforests and afforestation initiatives to which I referred.

I have announced that my Department is developing a consultancy which will attempt to identify which rainforest timbers come into Australia and how they are used. The specifications for that consultancy study have been completed and, within the next few days, tenders will be called for that consultant. The reason this is being done is so that, at the end of that consultancy, I can go to Cabinet to look at what can be done about the importation of rainforest products. I do not want to do that until I am possessed of all the information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to the statement issued by him on Commonwealth Government financial transactions for April 1989. He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Some other areas of outlays are unlikely to achieve the Budget estimate-in particular, Austudy and labour market programs, both due to lower than expected take-up rates . . .

Given the policy of his Government for a skills led recovery, which would enhance Australia's international competitiveness, can the Minister explain why the Government's policy of developing opportunities in this critical area has failed? Is it because, for instance, to get maximum Austudy as a dependent student, one's parents' joint taxable income cannot exceed $16,950?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Austudy take-up rate could vary for a number of reasons, one of which, if I heard correctly, Senator Patterson drew attention to at the end of her question-that is, a person does not get full Austudy unless the household income is below $17,000. Whether the variations that have taken place for this year or outlays being below estimate this year are due to wrong assumptions about the level of incomes in the households from which students come, I do not know. I gather that Senator Patterson is critical of the income level beyond which full Austudy is not paid. I imagine we would all like the income test to be more generous but I suggest to the honourable senator that she have a word with some of her National Party colleagues, who want to pay the full Austudy equivalent, under the assistance to isolated children scheme, to children of people with net assets in excess of $600,000. Her National Party colleagues say it is disgraceful to deny additional educational allowances to them. Should Australia be unfortunate enough to have a coalition government, the more her National Party colleagues succeed with that sort of rorting, the less they will be able to do for low income families who do not have any assets at all. The honourable senator should bear that in mind. It is not unusual for slippage to occur in the implementation of labour market programs. I do not know whether that is the reason for the below budgeted expenditure in that area. I will make inquiries.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management has identified 12 wetland complexes as appropriate for inclusion in the List of Wetlands of International Importance which is maintained under the Ramsar Convention, to which Australia became a signatory in 1974? Have nominations of these important heritage features been forwarded to the Ramsar Convention Bureau? If not, why not? When does the Minister propose to submit the nominations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The normal system that operates in these circumstances is that the States examine their wetlands and come forward with recommendations to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on which wetlands they consider worthy for nomination under the Ramsar Convention. The Western Australian Minister for Conservation and Land Management, Mr Taylor, is looking at wetlands in that State. However, to this point, he has not nominated them to the National Parks and Wildlife Service for its consideration. Obviously the Western Australian Government believes that those wetlands need some further investigation first. Once the Minister decides how many he chooses to nominate, they will be the subject of an investigation by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and, if they meet the requirements, their names will go forward as nominations to the Convention. Australia already has 29 wetlands of international importance registered with the Convention. The only two States that have so far not cooperated are Western Australia, which is about to do so, and Queensland, which is hell-bent on the destruction of wetlands, and has been for years.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister said that Western Australia has not cooperated already. Am I to believe from that that the Minister feels that Western Australia has not come forward despite, as I said in my question, the fact that these wetlands have been brought to the attention of the Government by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management? I am miffed by the words `not cooperated'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Heaven perish the thought that Senator Jenkins should be miffed. The Western Australian Government is examining these wetlands. When it has finished making that examination it will nominate however many it can to the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Western Australia is in the process of cooperating with the Commonwealth under the terms of the Convention. I might say that it is a little slow in doing so, but it is getting there. I was trying to distinguish between the efforts of Western Australia and Queensland. Queensland is doing nothing to assist, as I mentioned.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether the Government has yet made the new appointments to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) which are required to enable it legally to continue in operation beyond today. If not, when will the appointments be made and what will be the position of the IAC in the interim? If they have been made, who are the new commissioners and what are their terms of appointment? Why has the Government failed to restructure the IAC, as was originally planned to be announced in the April economic statement? Is it because senior industry Ministers, and in particular the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, are not prepared to have programs under their control examined by the IAC?
—The Minister for Finance is not in a position to comment on press reports which concern me.
—Mr Keating has taken your responsibility from you.

—Perhaps Opposition senators should have a party meeting with Senator Lewis afterwards, because he has the answers to all the questions. Two appointments to the Industries Assistance Commission have been made. I do not remember the name of the second appointee, although I can say that he is not an officer of the Treasury. The first appointee is Mr Parker, who is currently with the IAC. I saw the report about the future of the IAC disagreements between Ministers, and it is a lot of rubbish. There has been no disagreement between Ministers about this issue at all. There have been sensible and constructive discussions between Ministers.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Under what provision do you allow a Minister to whom the question was not addressed to answer the question, when you previously declined to allow Senator Boswell's question to be put to the Minister to whom it should have been directed, without penalising the Opposition a question in the process?

—On the point of order: in regard to the first point, I well recall asking former Senator Guilfoyle, in her capacity as Minister for Finance, a question in 1982 when Senator Carrick, almost like a baseball player, grabbed the ball on the way through and answered the question. That is the precedent. As to the second point, I have no comment on that. Maybe if we have to, we can give the Opposition another question after the normal run. But on the first point, there is a lot of precedent.
—On the point of order: Senator Button took the question at my request. I did not know the answer and he did. If the Opposition would rather not get an answer than get an answer, that is fine by me.
—Order! Senator Puplick, I was aware of the actions that I had taken. I believe that I have given the Opposition an additional question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I presume that I should direct it to Senator Button, in view of his extraordinary inability to allow the responsible Minister to handle the question. Honourable senators can take their pick as to which Minister will answer it. I ask whoever is going to have a bat at it why the restructuring of the Industries Assistance Commission, the details of which were to be announced in the April economic statement, has not been undertaken. If it has been undertaken, why has it not been announced?

—When Senator Short asks questions during Question Time, he either seeks information or he does not. If he seeks information-and my God, he needs it!-it is the Minister who can give it to him who is best able to satisfy his request. That is why I answered the question. With regard to the second part of his question, I do not know where on earth a commitment to make a statement in April on the restructuring of the IAC is spelled out. I do not know where on earth the honourable senator gets that from. A program for the IAC was announced last year which involved what are now termed micro-economic reform issues. There has been concern over aspects of the IAC program and the submissions, or the lack of submissions, which have been made to the IAC on various issues. It is in that context that the question of the IAC's future form and role has been examined. That is subject to present examination by the Government. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate said that the Opposition should have another question.
—I said I would consider it.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time on 6 April Senator Messner asked me a question about the Public Service early retirement scheme. I have obtained an answer. It is fairly long, so I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

On 6 April (Hansard, page 1072) Senator Messner asked me, as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, a question without notice about the Public Service early retirement scheme. I undertook to raise the issue with the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters and seek to obtain an answer as soon as possible.
The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has supplied the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

It is not true that a public servant aged 54 with at least 20 years' service could have received up to $170,000 more under the Government's one-off early retirement scheme than if he or she had retired at the age of 55 under the normal retirement benefits provisions.

The only additional benefit an officer retiring under the early retirement scheme would have received would be a severance payment based on years of service. If the officer received four weeks' pay in lieu of notice on retirement then the officer may have received a severance payment up to a maximum of 52 weeks' salary. The officer would have been entitled to elect for a lump sum superannuation benefit on retrenchment, an option that is not available to officers retiring on age grounds. This lump sum cannot be regarded as constituting an extra cash benefit; it is paid in lieu of the indexed age pension for life that is the normal option for Public Service retirees.

The maximum amount that a public servant can receive under the early retirement scheme is 48 weeks' salary as severance pay (for officers with 24 or more years of service), and 4 weeks' pay in lieu of notice. Officers also receive payment in lieu of unused recreation leave and long service leave credits, benefits which in most cases would be payable on age retirement or resignation. Benefits payable under the Superannuation Act will depend on the officer's superannuation contribution history as well as the particular superannuation option chosen by the officer.

In relation to the re-employment of retirees as consultants or in other ways, there is no legal barrier to former officers being reappointed to the Service or being engaged as temporary employees or consultants in accordance with the normal competitive merit selection process. It has been clearly recognised, however, that re-engagement may raise particular sensitivities. The former Public Service Board issued advice to departments on this matter in 1987 and the Public Service Commissioner has since written in similar terms to Secretaries indicating his expectation that re-engagement immediately or quite soon after such retirement should not occur. He has asked Secretaries to ensure that careful consideration is given to any proposal for the appointment, employment or consultant engagement of any officer who has recently been retrenched or retired.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1989 Senator Chapman addressed a question to me relating to trans-Tasman freight arrangements. The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided an answer to that question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard, subject to the deletion of the last paragraph, which is not relevant; it was relevant when the question was prepared.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

There are a number of commercial factors involved in the current New Zealand wheat trade with shipping being only one factor. Since the New Zealand wheat marketing arrangements were deregulated international wheat traders have been able to offer wheat from a number of countries including those that subsidise production. Prior to deregulation all New Zealand imports of wheat were sourced from Australia and shipping arrangements posed no apparent threat. It is not the case that trans-Tasman shipping costs are the only factor involved in the recent sales referred to by Senator Chapman nor that shipping arrangements threaten the viability of the market. In this context I am advised that the Australian Wheat Board has recently chartered a foreign crewed ship for a trans-Tasman grain shipment.

The Government has reviewed trans-Tasman shipping arrangements and Australian and New Zealand Ministers issued a joint communique on trans-Tasman shipping on 21 June 1988 (copy attached). This statement recognised the need to pursue measures to reduce the costs of shipping across the Tasman, a major element being the on-shore costs at both ends of the trade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May, Senator Chaney asked me some questions about the proposed corporate office building for Telecom Australia in Melbourne. I have further and better information from the Minister for Transport and Communications. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
In accordance with the accountability invested in the Telecom Board, the decision to construct this building was made at the April 1989 Board Meeting and advice was then forwarded to the Government.

Telecom's decision to construct a Corporate headquarters in the CBD was based on the need to resolve the present unsatisfactory situation where Telecom has its headquarters' staff located in a number of different leased buildings. It is important for Telecom to locate its headquarters in the CBD for operational efficiencies. A significant factor is the need to be able to recruit top line staff from the whole of Melbourne city and its environs. If the headquarters was located in a suburban area it would limit the pool of talent attracted to employment in Telecom because of the difficulty in travelling to a suburban location. the Honourable Senator should be aware that Melbourne has a radial transport system. Where appropriate Telecom locates components of its organisation in suburban locations. For example the Telecommunications Laboratories are at Clayton and Telecom recently established a major suburban presence at Brandon Park, Mulgrave.

Many options were evaluated before the decision to build, rather than buy or lease was taken. The options were considered exhaustively by the Board a number of times. In examining the options Telecom approached the market and sought offers for lease or purchase. Detailed evaluations were performed which demonstrated that it was financially advantageous for Telecom to construct its own building. The honourable Senator should be aware that the new Boards of the GBEs are under their Acts accountable for performance and commercial results. I again assure the Honourable Senator that the Telecom Board has been meticulous in ensuring that its decision has been taken with full regard to the fact that the Board is accountable for its decisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Tambling asked me a question about Darwin Airport. I have a further response on that. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer:
Second-hand reports have been received of comments attributed to Mr Graham McMahon, General Manager Ansett, on the lines that Ansett may consider developing its own Darwin terminal.

The Federal Airports Corporation has been consulting closely with both Ansett and Australian Airlines on facilities and lease conditions in the new Darwin terminal. The issue of separate terminal developments by Ansett has not arisen in those discussions.

I understand that negotiations are still proceeding between the Corporation and airlines on aspects of the proposed Darwin development. I have no doubt that if Ansett seriously proposed to build its own terminal, it would discuss the proposal with the Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on the question of shipping and waterfront industry reform, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented in some respects in an article in today's Age.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report referred to me and Mr Kerin as having raised a number of questions in the Cabinet structural adjustment committee about proposed changes for coastal shipping and the waterfront. The Cabinet committee had a lengthy discussion on this matter and a number of Ministers raised questions and points of view on the complex issues involved. I was certainly one of them. However, a statement will be made by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, tonight. He is responsible for these issues. I regard the contents of the statement as amounting to a very significant reform in relation to coastal shipping and the waterfront which will improve the competitiveness of the transport system in Australia and I support the approach adopted by the Minister. I regard it as an important micro-economic reform statement, consistent with other micro-economic reforms made by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In making this personal explanation I do not dispute what the journalist in question alleged were the facts-that I had raised questions and made comments about aspects of the proposed package in the context of Cabinet discussion or structural adjustment committee discussion. The implications of the article, read as a whole, were that I would not be able to make the statement I just made, namely, that I regard the contents of the statement as amounting to significant reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Do not discuss the motives. Just correct the record.
—If people heard those statements and were misled as to my view, I refer them to what I did say. In part I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there are questions of poverty which contribute to this problem but many of us can cite children, let alone wives, from very wealthy families who find themselves victims of domestic violence or homeless children. DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE VETERANS' RESIDENCES TRUST

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Royal Australian Air Force Veterans' Residences Trust was sent to the Honourable R. J. Kelly, MP, the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, on 6 December 1988 and it was tabled in this place in May. I mention this as part of my continuing campaign against the Government's incompetence. It seems incapable of getting itself into gear sufficiently to present such reports in a timely and effective way. I believe that, unless the Minister has some adequate justification, these reports should be presented to the Senate as soon as practicable after they have been received, in this case by the trustees. I would expect that the Government, having been criticised by me almost daily on this score-and quite properly criticised-would have done something about responding to defend itself. I would think that, if this continued arrogance from the Government persists, the Opposition will have to consider taking another course of action about the way the Parliament is being treated with contempt by the Government.

I mention in passing that one thing does bother me a little about the Royal Australian Air Force Veterans' Residences Trust, that is, that such a large proportion of its assets have been left in government and semi-government loans rather than invested in the land and buildings which are required to meet the demands of those people who need the assistance of the Trust-those former air men and women who are in necessitous circumstances. The annual report reveals that there is something like $844,000 in investments in government and semi-government loans and other authorised trustee loans but that the total invested in land and buildings and so on is only something like $660,000 net, or about $900,000 gross before depreciation. The return on the investments is only 11.5 per cent, whereas the return on the gross cost of the housing and other assets is something like 13 per cent. So it seems to me that the assets could be better used. Maybe there is a sound explanation. It would be nice, if there were a sound explanation, to get it in the annual report. It would be even better if we received it on time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSFER OF NURSING EDUCATION FROM HOSPITALS TO THE TERTIARY SECTOR

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Although the report is very short it concerns an important issue, that is, the transfer of the nursing education function from State hospitals to the Commonwealth tertiary education system. The program, which started on the Commonwealth's initiative and was subsequently agreed to by the States, was funded by the Commonwealth. Because of the titanic nature of the program-I do not intend any pun there; it was a big program-it was decided to phase it in because of the possibility of a loss to the work force during the life of the program. The program involved not only the State hospitals but also the repatriation hospitals because they also carried out their own nursing education. In addition, the report deals with some of the numbers involved.

The program is due to be completed by 1993. A 10-year program, it started in about 1983; so we are just over halfway through. There was a long and involved process of negotiation as to how it would be funded. An agreement was reached and the Commonwealth put in $1,500 for each student nurse involved. That figure was indexed so that as costs went up the subsidy would be sufficient. By the time the program is completed about 18,000 nurses will have been trained under it. As I have said, all the States are in agreement.

The Commonwealth was presented with a very vexed question because of the changing rule of nurses in society. I think everyone has come to realise that the Commonwealth Government took a rather enlightened role as to the changing nature of nursing. Instead of just being practical people looking after patients, nurses had to become practitioners. One of the great concerns was that if all nurses had a tertiary education qualification we would have all chiefs and no indians looking after the patients. Indeed, that could even be a concern today, and that is the point I wish to make. Many nurses do not require training to the tertiary level. The type of nurses to whom I refer are those in nursing homes and hostels who do not need the degree of training that is required under this scheme. Many nurses will be quite prepared to do that sort of work, as the number of patients increase, without going to this degree of training. If nurses need training in ordinary general nursing, by all means that training should be available to them. That should also apply to other forms of nursing because not all nurses have to be part of the transfer from the State-based system to the tertiary education system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
