DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ETHIOPIA, TANZANIA, MOZAMBIQUE AND ZIMBABWE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ethiopia, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zimbabwe, and seek leave to make a few remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This delegation took place in July of last year. I do not know of any parliamentary report that has taken so long to come before the Parliament. This is because of the serious problems that arose during this delegation's visit. This visit has been the subject of much publicity, a great deal of it unfavourable, and it has created serious concerns about the conditions under which visits like this should take place. In my view the major problem with this delegation was its leader's inability to handle a difficult situation that was created both by the different personalities on the visit and the tiring and at times depressing nature of much of the visit itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the beginning that the leader's unfortunate behaviour is evident in his introduction to the delegation's report, in which he notes in what is, frankly, a gratuitously insulting remark:

I would suggest it is important that all members of any outgoing delegation arrive together and participate in all official meetings, briefings and functions unless there are extenuating circumstances.

That is in part aimed at me. I arrived three days late because, as the leader of the delegation knows, my mother was dying and in fact did die a few days after I returned from that visit. It is grossly offensive for Mr Hollis, the leader of the delegation, to include such remarks in such a report. The other person to whom he was addressing these remarks was Mr Goodluck, who absented himself on a couple of occasions because he was ill, and he also had some blood pressure tests done. Honourable senators would be aware of the fact that recently Mr Goodluck did in fact have a heart attack. We can do without remarks of this nature in a report which deals with very serious matters.

I turn to the substance of the report. There is no disagreement in the dissenting report-I stress to the Senate that there is a dissenting report to the main report-with the main conclusions of the Government members' report that the delegation's visit did strengthen the cordial relations between Australia and the governments of the four African nations visited. These consist of the dictatorial, oppressive, Marxist governments of Ethiopia and Mozambique, the improving but still authoritarian Government of Tanzania, and the single-party Government of Zimbabwe, clearly the nearest model to a democratic state we visited but which is marred by the renewal during our visit of the 24-year-old state of emergency that has little if anything to do with any perceived or real threat from South Africa. However, the facts revealed to us during the visit raise serious questions about the merit of much of Australia's political, economic and humanitarian involvement with the nations visited and with their relationship with South Africa. Unfortunately, the delegation had no official opportunities to examine the `other side' of the contentious issues affecting these nations, such as the situation of Eritreans and other dissidents opposing the Ethiopian Government or Renamo leaders opposed to Mozambique's Frelimo Government or of South African responses to the concerns about South Africa expressed by the governments visited.

Australia's often ill-conceived and inappropriate assistance to some African governments may have deepened rather than alleviated the distress of their people by strengthening the ability of undemocratic, authoritarian and often racially oppressive governments to subjugate them and to damage their economic potential by imposing dogma-bound politico-economic systems on them that have universally failed-but where the extent of that failure has been diminished by continued foreign aid. This applies not only to misdirected development aid, but also to emergency, humanitarian food aid, particularly in Eritrea. The removal of the International Red Cross and non-governmental organisations from their distributing and monitoring role in emergency food aid in this area, which took place shortly before our arrival, raises serious questions about the ultimate beneficiaries of such aid; if it is going to help feed the armed forces engaged in this 27-year-old civil war, then it must be halted immediately as it is simply helping to perpetuate the conflict. In civil war situations, as in Ethiopia, the Australian Government must not provide direct aid to the governments or movements involved, but must make any aid conditional on it being distributed by non-government organisations, NGOs, or monitored by the ICRC-the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Any official aid should also be conditional on positive measures being taken to negotiate to end the conflict. Specifically in the Ethiopian situation, the Australian Government must apply greater international pressure to stop the conflict in Eritrea and the violations of human rights throughout the Ethiopian nation. It also should bring strong pressure to change the intolerable treatment of women in much of Ethiopia, where their role appears to be almost as beasts of burden.

There is also a problem with humanitarian aid in refugee situations in other parts of Ethiopia. Emergency food aid is still being provided to hundreds of thousands of Sudanese refugees more than three years after many of them arrived in a fertile, undeveloped area of western Ethiopia, yet there is no requirement on them to do anything from their own efforts to supplement the aid they are receiving. Rather than providing such food aid, Australia should be assisting by teaching them to provide for themselves the way the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and other agencies are assisting Mozambican refugees in Tanzania to become largely self-supporting. With developmental and other aid, it is vital that it not depend on a level of technology beyond local skill levels; in nations where labour is plentiful it is ludicrous to see aid money spent on sophisticated labour-saving devices without providing the skills or cash needed for their expensive maintenance with the result that remnants of such projects are scattered rusting throughout Africa. Australia must concentrate its activities on those matters on which it has most to offer-such as in rural skills like prevention of land degradation and reafforestation programs.

On a political level, the Australian Government's wholehearted and apparently uncritical support for the campaign by the front-line states against South Africa, which has given Australia a very high standing among governments in the region, appears to be encouraging those elements in black Africa who argue that the only solution to the South African problem is by confrontation and, if necessary, bloody revolution. At a time when President P. W. Botha was building on modest, domestic, humanitarian advances by making conciliatory diplomatic contacts with important black African leaders in the region, it was regrettable that the views expressed by Government members of the Australian parliamentary delegation, and indeed those of the Australian Government, could be taken to be both dismissive of those moves and supportive of the hard confrontationist line that would, in all likelihood, lead to a major disaster for both the black and white populations of southern Africa.

Our experience on this visit indicates to us that Australia has a duty to encourage African nations to diminish their obsessive concentration on the South African scapegoat as the excuse for all their problems and instead to address the real issues which, even given natural difficulties such as drought, are mainly of their own making. For its 25 years existence, the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) has done little other than concentrate on the South African problem, as an issue on which the Africans in member states have been diminished and in many cases destroyed, even to the extent of tribal genocide and the collapse of once-rich commodity producing nations into the status of mendicants. Now that the OAU has at last recognised, at its latest annual meeting, the need to address Africa's economic problems, Australia has a special opportunity to provide major and meaningful advisory assistance, particularly in its role as a significant commodity producer itself in a continent rich in potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I have been sitting here for some time, and Senator Michael Baume seems just to be reading from the dissenting report accompanying the report which has been tabled. Do we have to put up with the honourable senator wasting the valuable time of the Senate by reading the whole thing into Hansard?
—Senator Michael Baume may make comments in relation to the report. He is quoting from parts of the report. In those circumstances I ask him to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am reading extracts from the dissenting report. If Senator Schacht is determined that I should read the whole thing I shall do so. I have been reading limited extracts because I think that it is vital that this chamber have on its own records, and not simply tabled, some of the important points that appear never to get made here. We have not had the opportunity of debating these major issues for a very long time.
—It is important.
—I agree with Senator Hill, and I thank him for his comment. The dissenting report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: However, by closing its Embassy in Addis Ababa, where the OAU organisation is headquartered, Australia appears to have foregone any real opportunity to play such a significant role. Any re-opening would nevertheless need to be done in such a way that could not be taken as any endorsement of the Mengistu government.

It is evident that the relative poverty in which the vast majority of Africans live, despite their generally rich natural resources, has little if anything to do with the prime preoccupation of all their governments in their talks with the delegation-the South African question.

Contrary to the confrontationist propaganda, the level of economic dependence of some frontline states on trade with South Africa is such as to indicate that a withdrawal of that trade (and in the case of Mozambique, economic assistance) would have a disastrous impact on their economies. Even in civil war-torn Mozambique, a senior official of the Frelimo Government readily admitted that Renamo could not be blamed for all Mozambique's problems as Frelimo had itself made major mistakes.

It is now clear that the economic failures of East Africa have been despite enormous volumes of foreign aid and development assistance; a World Bank representative in Tanzania could not identify one `really successful' program in the nation's 28 year history of independence. It is only because of the moves away from doctrinaire Marxist models into more market-oriented societies that the World Bank now feels more confident about the prospects of new development projects in East Africa.

It should be noted that the delegation was warmly received at senior levels by all governments and wide-ranging probing questions were generally allowed and answered appropriately (except in the interview with President Mengistu of Ethiopia); there appeared to be relatively little evasion or prevarication, although delegation members did not press politically embarrassing matters.

Despite the personal and political divisions within the delegation that have been played up in the Australian media, the delegation maintained (except on two relatively unimportant occasions) an appropriate facade of unity in its dealings with host governments, none of which would have been aware of the internal problems that helped make this a very difficult visit.

It is recommended that clear and unequivocal guidelines be drawn up for the conduct of such delegations to politically sensitive areas, particularly relating to the duties and obligations of delegation leaders and deputy leaders, the rights of non-government members, the nature of relations with the local media and the prior arrangements to be made with host nations about the involvement of any accompanying spouses.

DEBATE.TITLE: SEVENTY-NINTH CONFERENCE OF THE INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Seventy-ninth Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and to make some brief comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Seventy-ninth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. The delegation from the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) which met in Guatemala on 11 to 16 April 1988, under the leadership of the Hon. Tom Uren, enjoyed a very good relationship and good fellowship, and there were absolutely no problems of any sort-unlike the situation to which Senator Michael Baume alluded. With no problems and no minority reports, I find it extraordinarily difficult to understand why it has taken from 11 to 16 April last year until 1 June this year to get a perfectly simple report before the Senate. But so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: Ninety-five countries were represented at the IPU, and there were 689 delegates. In addition to debates on peace and development and environmental issues, there was a general debate. This produced considerable hot discussion and much disagreement between the parties, and often tended to make the debate less than useful. I see the IPU as being a good organisation to broaden international understanding and cooperation, but I believe that these conferences could do a lot better. I said then, and I say now, that much more could be achieved if the effort and time were spent on areas of common concern and basic understanding and agreement, on which real progress could be made. Twelve months ago I suggested the greenhouse effect as one such issue. I have suggested it as a topic for submission and consideration subsequently. On matters like that, all countries are in complete agreement, and real progress could be made if they were discussed. Instead, we get onto matters which only bring hostility and disagreement between the parties. The IPU can be a much more useful organisation, and I urge that our delegates work towards those ends.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reports of Delegations to New Zealand and New Caledonia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the delegation reports on the Committee's recent visits to New Zealand and New Caledonia, together with the Committee's minutes of proceedings relating thereto. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
The statement read as follows-

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade's Sub-committee on the South Pacific visited eight South Pacific countries in June 1988 as part of an inquiry into Australia's relations with the South Pacific. Although New Caledonia had been included in the original itinerary for this trip, it was deferred to a later date due to continuing troubles in the Territory. The Committee remained convinced, however, that it was important to visit New Caledonia and see first hand the situation almost twelve months after the signing of the Matignon Accords. Approval was sought and obtained for the visit by a working group from the Committee, which I had the pleasure of leading, and the visit took place 22 to 26 April 1989.

The delegation's visit to New Caledonia, only three and a half days in length, was most useful in providing the participants with the chance to discuss and see first-hand political developments in the Territory. Observers of developments in New Caledonia were dismayed with the spiralling cycle of violence and civil disturbance apparent from 1984 onwards. Following the terrible violence on Ouvea, and the re-election of President Mitterand and appointment of Michel Rocard as Prime Minister in mid 1988, there was a major shift in French policy, and hope that the cycle of violence would be broken. The Matignon Accords, and the later Oudinot Accords provided a basis for some hope about the future of the Territory. Although fragile, they have so far provided a framework within which the various groups can work without the need to resort to violence.

Pockets of opposition to the Accords remain-and this was tragically brought home to the world with the assassination of Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeiwene Yeiwene. I, along with others, spoke in this place when news of this tragedy came through, and I am sure that everyone would deplore the deaths of two such great men. The people of New Caledonia, both Melanesian and French and the people of the South Pacific are poorer for their passing.

I will take this opportunity to express my thanks to the Foreign Minister Senator Evans for enabling Senator Robert Hill and myself to travel with him to New Caledonia for the funeral of Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeiwene Yeiwene. The funeral service was extremely moving and demonstrated the enormous support and affection in which both men where held by not only the Kanak population of New Caledonia but also the French community. I will always remember the very sad but moving atmosphere of the funeral. The ceremony at both the cathedral and at the airport demonstrated that the people of the South Pacific had been robbed of two outstanding leaders. The speech by the French Premier Rocard indicated that the French government and the French people had experienced an unmitigated tragedy. When Premier Rocard bowed at the feet of the two widows and made a traditional Kanak custom presentation this more than anything else demonstrated the extent of the loss of these two men to New Caledonia and the French nation.

Personally, with Senator Hill I had the opportunity the night before the funeral to visit the small chapel on the outskirts of Noumea where the bodies of the two leaders were held. Even at 2 o'clock in the morning the chapel was full of mourners and was surrounded by several hundred other Kanak mourners maintaining a vigil. The Kanaks asked both myself and Senator Hill to address them in the chapel. I found it, as I'm sure Senator Hill did too, a very emotional experience to speak to the people present, many with tears in their eyes, about the way we as Australians felt towards Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeiwene Yeiwene. I will always remember that particular event.

When the delegation left New Caledonia it was `cautiously optimistic' about the accords holding together. That optimism has now decreased significantly. The danger is that without the strong personal leadership of Jean-Marie Tjibaou and his support for the accords, they will come under increasing stress and may give way to the violence seen in the mid-1980's.

The delegation discussed a number of issues other than political developments during its visit, and these are dealt with in the report. Issues such as land ownership, trade, Australian assistance to the territory under the matignon accords and the economic future of New Caledonia were covered during the visit. There is also a section on the French University of the Pacific which the delegation was able to visit.

As we note in the report, the University has the potential to make significant cultural and educational contribution to the territory in the future. It is keen to establish contacts with other academic institutions in the region, and the delegation wholeheartedly supports such closer contacts.

In conclusion, Mr President, it remains only for me to thank the other members of the delegation-Senator Robert Hill, Mr Gary Nehl, m.p. and Mr Phillip Ruddock, m.p.-for their hard work and participation in the delegation. On their behalf I would also like to thank the Australian Government for providing funds to enable the visit to proceed; officials in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for their assistance in providing briefings and suggestions on the itinerary; Australian Diplomatic Staff at the Australian Consulate-General in Noumea for their co-ordination of the visit and expert advice to the committee during its visit; and to French authorities in Noumea who facilitated and welcomed the visit.
We hope that this visit will be the first in an on-going exchange between Australia and New Caledonia as the territory moves towards deciding its future in 1998.
I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not many things I would like to say about this report but, in view of an agreement reached, I seek leave to continue my remarks, hopefully next Wednesday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debated adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I table the first report on the Committee's current inquiry into the conduct of the 1987 Federal election and the 1988 referendums. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Late in 1987 the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters received a reference from the then Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, to inquire into all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth, including legislation governing the operation of the Australian Electoral Commission. The Committee's predecessor, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, has reported on previous elections. This report concerns the conduct of the 1987 Federal election and is the product of a committee representing both Houses of this Parliament and all shades of political opinion. The report contains over 50 recommendations which will bring about reform and improvement in Australia's electoral system. With the exception of the small number of recommendations referred to in the minority comments, the recommendations were unanimous.

I wish to mention just briefly some of the Committee's recommendations. A number of submissions received expressed concern about electoral fraud, particularly the accuracy of the rolls and the possibility of cemetery voting, multiple voting and impersonation. The Committee did not receive any factual evidence to support these allegations of organised electoral fraud but, whilst no evidence to this effect was obtained, the Committee has suggested a number of ways to improve the accuracy of the rolls. Some members of the Committee have called for the introduction of locality voting, which would allow electors to cast ordinary votes at only one polling place in their electorate. Prior to 1984, when electors had to vote within their subdivision, voters who attended a polling booth within their electorate but outside their subdivision were forced to cast a declaration or absentee vote. In the view of the majority of the Committee locality voting would result in large numbers of electors having to cast declaration or absentee votes increasing congestion at booths and dissatisfaction and confusion amongst electors.

Another suggestion was that a computerised electoral roll be introduced to prevent multiple voting. This would require an on-line terminal at every table in every polling booth in every electorate and, in our view, would be prohibitively expensive. The Cundy inquiry calculated it would cost New South Wales more than $20m to introduce such a system. Given the seriousness of allegations of electoral fraud, the Committee has recommended a substantial increase in the penalties for electoral fraud. For example, the Committee recommends that for multiple voting impersonation the penalties set at $1,000 or six months imprisonment should be increased to $12,000 and/or two years maximum imprisonment. This hike in penalties reflects the fact that electoral penalties are well overdue for review. The recommendation will also put Australia in line with other countries which have much higher penalties for electoral fraud than we do here.

Since the Commonwealth Electoral Act was amended in 1984 only Australian citizens have been eligible to nominate for election to the Commonwealth Parliament. British citizens enrolled before 1984 are eligible to vote but not eligible to nominate unless they become naturalised citizens. After being declared elected to the Senate in 1987, Mr Robert Wood was found to be in this category, although he believed he was an Australian citizen at the time of nominating.

To reduce the possibility of persons who are not Australian citizens nominating, the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Electoral Act be amended to require candidates to declare on their nomination form how they became Australian citizens-that is, by birth or naturalisation-and, if naturalised, where and when the ceremony took place. The Committee rejected a proposal to excuse aged voters from compulsory voting, as occurs in Victorian local government elections. The Committee believes that most elderly voters would take exception to the idea and supports the continuation of uniformity for Federal, State and local voting to minimise confusion.

The Committee received a submission suggesting that it was in the public interest that candidates be required to declare their political affiliations when nominating. To overcome the difficulty in determining which organisations are political, the Committee has recommended that candidates be required to declare their membership of any registered political party at the time of nominating. The Committee received from the Australian Electoral Commission a report on an audit of six divisions and was concerned at the considerable number of errors revealed in that audit. The Committee welcomes the decision of the Australian Electoral Commission to expand staff training and to conduct future audits using the strictest audit standards to ensure uniform electoral procedures are being followed throughout Australia.

Finally, on behalf of the Committee, I wish to thank the secretary of the Committee, Trevor Rowe, and other members of the secretariat who have assisted in preparing this important report-Denise Denahy, Helen Missa and Lexia Noakes. I would also wish to draw the Senate's attention to the minority comments that are contained at the end of the report, expressing some views contrary to the majority report. As was said earlier, they are small in number, but important minority recommendations nevertheless. The minority report signed by me, Mr Michael Cobb and Dr Wooldridge recommends, firstly, the introduction of a system of locality voting and, secondly, that the three months provision, which was removed from the Act in 1987, be reinstated. We disagree with the majority of the Committee in not proceeding with these because of the widespread reports of concern in the community that the electoral system is subject to abuse and manipulation and, therefore, to inaccurate or rigged election results. We believe that any long term perceptions of this nature would inevitably erode the confidence the electorate has in our democratic parliamentary system. The implications of this, of course, are obvious and would be of profound significance and concern.

Clause 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering clause 5, as amended, and the amendment moved by Senator Jenkins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is presently considering clause 5 of the Regulation of Video Material Bill, my private member's Bill, which will do two simple things: it will legislate to downgrade the violence in videos and it will abolish X-rated videos. Senator Jenkins's amendment to clause 5 of my Bill would totally destroy my Bill, because it would not only entrench X-rated videos for all time but would also liberalise quite dramatically the present guidelines, which prohibit the use of all types of extreme fetishes. Her amendment would result in allowing these extreme fetishes to be shown.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said publicly that the matter of videos rests with the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) now that it has a government. I am afraid that is totally untrue. The Prime Minister is trying to duck for cover. The situation is that it is the Federal Government alone that has control over the Customs Act. As the evidence which was given to our Committee shows, it is the importation of these X-rated and extremely violent R-rated videos that is the problem. These types of videos are not made in Australia; they are imported from overseas. As I say, the only way that they can be stopped from entering the country is by this Government. The ACT has no control over the Customs Act. The Prime Minister is trying to muddy the waters in shifting the blame to the ACT for the fact that it is the only centre in Australia that is distributing these X-rated videos and extremely violent R-rated films.

Senator Jenkins has said that she is fully aware that her amendment does indeed destroy totally my Bill, and it is her desire to do so. I do not know how the rest of the Australian Democrats will be voting on this issue. I do not know how Senator Dunn and Senator Vallentine will be voting on this issue. I only hope that they will support my Bill. I only hope that people in this chamber realise that it is the legislators of this country who are responsible for the safety and protection of the people of Australia. We know beyond any shadow of doubt that violence has increased over the past 10 years. For instance, the incidence of severe assault has gone up 224 per cent and the incidence of rape has gone up 140 per cent. It is of no use our trying to make excuses for these figures or trying to make out that they really do not exist, as members of the Government have attempted to; they do exist. Women are concerned and do feel threatened. Every women's organisation throughout Australia has written saying that they want the Government to support my Bill. I now plead with the Government to allow its members to at least have a conscience vote. If it did that, then I am very confident that my Bill would be supported.

I believe that the Democrats' amendment and clause 5 have been debated fully. I do not think there is anything left for anyone in the chamber to say. The clause has been debated for several days. I now plead with the Committee to support this particular clause, because it is this clause that is the crux of the whole Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to what Senator Walters has had to say and I respect and understand her opinion. The amendments I propose to the Regulation of Video Material Bill should be seen as a package. I am attempting to ensure that the display of video material which is rated as suitable only for those over 18 years of age should be restricted. At present that relates to X-rated and R-rated material. My amendments would also mean that promotional material relating to the current X-rated and R-rated videos would not be permitted to be displayed in public places where there may be people who are under 18 years of age. Many people find offensive the promotional material for both violent and sexually explicit movies.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. I think Senator Jenkins is debating a different amendment to that which is before the Committee. We are considering clause 5. Is not the amendment Senator Jenkins is speaking on to be moved at a later stage?
—We are debating clause 5.

—I am referring to further amendments that I propose to move in order to explain that all my amendments form a package. I wish to explain that package. Obviously, they will have to be voted on singly. I appreciate that fact.
—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: we are considering clause 5. Senator Jenkins is now debating her amendment that follows clause 5. It is not part of clause 5.

—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: I am not debating my further amendments. I am stating what they are for the information of the Committee. I believe that information is important as we debate my first amendment to clause 5.
—The amendment before the Committee is to delete `whether or not the material' and insert `and'.
—That is correct, Madam Temporary Chairman. I am not debating my other amendments; I am simply referring to them.
—I think you should explain them to the Committee, Senator Jenkins.

—My other amendments relate to a description of the material, whether `G', `PG', `M', `R' or `X', being shown clearly on the video. In other words, people who take out this video material will know precisely what to expect with regard to sexual content, violence content and language content. One of the problems at present is that when people take out X-rated and R-rated videos, they cannot be sure exactly what sexual content, violence content, or language content is in the videos.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. Senator Jenkins is now debating her next amendment. I do not believe we can proceed in this fashion. Her amendment follows clause 5 and, therefore, cannot be debated under clause 5. We really must stick to clause 5. Senator Jenkins has gone well beyond that because her next amendment is 5a. We are debating clause 5, and we cannot debate clause 5a at the same time.
—I think Senator Jenkins is trying to explain her following amendments and why it is necessary to leave out `whether or not the material' and insert `and'.

—I am debating the first of my amendments, which takes away a total ban of X-rated and R-rated videos. I am explaining that one of the problems and one of the reasons people want a total ban is that they cannot always be sure of the content of the videos. I am referring to R-rated videos also in this regard. I have been corresponding with many groups that have written to me, as they have written to every other senator who is concerned about these matters. Today I received a letter from the Chairman of the Mothers Union in Australia. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I very much appreciate the correspondence we have had and I now have a clear understanding of your view of the subject of X rated videos. We are really not very far apart in our aspirations, and if you could achieve all that you have stated in your letter, we would be much less concerned about the video industry than we now are.

One concern I have, a concern that also has been expressed by other senators, relates to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Of course one cannot catch AIDS from watching an X-rated video, but concern has been expressed that there might be some imitative behaviour. As honourable senators know, for some time now the video industry has voluntarily placed on its video material a graphic warning against AIDS-associated behaviour. On X-rated videos that warning is X-rated and on R-rated videos it is R-rated. I have been requested by the Mothers Union in Australia to bring forward amendments which would mean that those warnings would not continue to be on a voluntary basis. The Association wants those warnings included on a legislative basis. I have sought to have the amendments drafted, but they are not ready.

I would like to comment on some remarks that were made earlier about a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material-this was a majority decision-that a new category called non-violent erotica (NVE) should be instituted. The second recommendation, which was not in reality a majority decision because some of the committee members abstained from voting on it, was that the new NVE category contain material in the current X classification. Having listened to the debates we have had since the Committee's report was tabled, I am not sure that I agree with the second decision. Were we to institute a new category of NVE, just as we are trying to remove the top levels of the violent material, perhaps there should be some elements of the current X-rated material that we should also remove; in that way we would have NVE material which was clearly non-violent and labelled as such; any video marked with an X would be known to be an import from the United Kingdom or the United States of America and therefore definitely containing violent material. It would take away the confusion in the minds of the public.

Because such material would be available we would be able to do away with the possibility of criminal elements taking over the importation, hiring out and reproduction of this material, as it appears they have now done in Victoria, where X-rated videos are banned. This is a serious danger and it concerns me. This concern was expressed extremely well by Senator Macklin in his speech on the second reading debate. He explained what resulted when hard drugs were made illegal, which was done with the best of intentions. We have put the drug industry into the hands of the big criminals. There is a lot of money in it and many people fall by the wayside because they believe that they can make money out of the drug industry. Now there is a move for some of those hard drugs again to be legalised and tightly controlled. That is what I am advocating as far as non-violent erotic videos are concerned. We should be able to have control over them and not push supply underground, where the industry could fall into the hands of criminal elements. I know that is not an opinion with which everybody agrees, but I certainly believe we would be much better off if we were to do this. It is for that reason that I have moved this first amendment. I am very apprehensive that if we move a total ban on these materials now, we could be causing many more problems in the long run than we have at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins is saying that because people disobey the law regarding drugs, we should legalise them; that we should legalise heroin because, since it is illegal at present, people tend to share needles and therefore they are more likely to get acquired immune deficiency syndrome. There is therefore a push to legalise heroin. Because she is worried that these videos may go underground, she wants to legalise them. I can assure Senator Jenkins that when I was sitting on a committee which was looking into the legalisation of marijuana, every one of the witnesses who came before our committee to give evidence, including those who believed that marijuana ought to be legalised, said, `Of course, if you legalise it, then its use will be increased dramatically'.

SPEECH.PARA: If we keep these extremely violent and X-rated videos legal, this means the Government condones their use and people will use them. If they are illegal, a few will be sent underground-as are those videos that are already censored and illegal, such as those relating to child pornography. But the majority of the population will not do something illegal. The majority of the population will not go to criminal elements to try to get something illegal. The majority of the population abide by the law. It is wrong for Senator Jenkins to say that if we make something illegal, then the people will get it anyway-because generally people do not. Very few do; that will always be the case. The number of people who seek illegal child pornography is very small. Young people and adults do not go down to the shop next to the supermarket and get them. They know that they are illegal. Very few people will get videos from the illegal trade. The same thing would apply to some other videos.

We had so much evidence before our Committee which showed that the continual viewing of those videos desensitised people. As I have said in this place on so many occasions when debating the Bill, we are all well aware that when we see something that horrifies us and the next week we see something that is even worse, we are desensitised about that first view. This happens. It is natural; it is normal. I do not know how far Senator Jenkins is willing to go, bearing in mind the tremendous increase, as I have already stated, in cases of serious assault. There has been a 224 per cent increase in serious assault cases in 10 years. There has been a 140 per cent increase in rape. We have received evidence about that. As one of the legislators and one of the members of that Committee, I am not prepared to sit on a committee and be presented with all this evidence and then come into this place and say that they should be allowed legally in every shop and garage and all through the agents that are presently proliferating in the Australian Capital Territory.

We must, we are required and it is our obligation to do something about making Australia a safer place for our families. I do not understand why Senator Jenkins is not prepared to do that. I do not understand why the Government is not prepared to do that. I am quite sure that if Government senators opposite were given conscience votes, many of them would join this side of the chamber. I have been told by many of them that they would certainly do that.

I am anxious to put the matter to the vote and see just who is keen to vote for the security and safety of our families and who is willing to run the risk of continuing the problems shown up in the evidence given to our Committee, from the judges of the land and from the police and a crowd of others. As I have already said, every women's organisation throughout the country has written to the Government and pleaded with it to support my Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not participated in the committee stage debate on this Bill to date but I will do so now briefly. I did participate in the second reading debate when I brought to the attention of the Senate, as has Senator Walters, the fact that practically every women's organisation in this country is opposed to the exploitation and degradation of women through the pornographic video industry which operates out of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). As you would be aware, Madam Temporary Chairman, all the Attorneys-General of this country resolved that X-rated videos should be banned for that reason. The Attorneys-General in all States of Australia have so acted and banned the X-rated videos business from within their respective States.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was of that opinion and wished to act accordingly within the Commonwealth jurisdiction, he was overruled by his Caucus and was unable to so act. The effect of that is that there is a pornographic video industry operating out of the ACT, which, through the postal capacities of this country, has tentacles extending over the whole of this Commonwealth. Canberra has become the pornographic video capital of Australia. That is the reason why Senator Walters brought this private member's Bill to the Parliament. We commend her for that. She is acting in response to not only the views of a very large number of Australians but also the views of every Attorney-General within the Commonwealth.

We are about to vote on the first amendment of the Australian Democrats. It is important that it be absolutely clear that the effect of that amendment is to destroy the purpose of Senator Walters's Bill. Senator Walters's Bill seeks to ban X-rated videos and certain other videos, including materials which depict detailed, relished or gratuitous acts of considerable violence or cruelty. The effect of the Democrats' amendment is to so change those definitions that the Bill, as amended, would no longer have that effect. The amendment would therefore emasculate Senator Walters's Bill. It would no longer be her Bill and no longer would achieve her objectives if the amendments were passed. Clearly, that is why we will be voting against the amendments. We trust that the Government will join with us and defeat the intention of the Australian Democrats in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add very briefly in response that a lot of people are not horrified by explicit sexual depictions. They do not believe that they are necessarily harmful. But they are horrified by unnecessary censorship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because I understand an arrangement has been made to report progress after the vote on this amendment is taken. I have a number of questions that need to be raised at some time, including the distribution of X-rated material by post and postal courier service. It is important to note that, if this amendment proposed by Senator Walters is agreed to, there would be no need for my second amendment which relates to the distribution of material by post or postal courier service. Let us get that clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment moved by Senator Jenkins has, as its effect, the entrenchment of hard core pornography in the community and, therefore, I am opposed to the amendment. I was slightly heartened to hear Senator Jenkins say that she may well vote differently now in respect of the second recommendation in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. She now considers that some material at the outer end of X-rated clearly should not be classified. Frankly, I knew that all along. I have been with this now for four or five years and I have seen as many of these videos as most people have.

TALK.START.PARA: —More by the sound of it.
—Yes, more.
—Most Australians haven't seen any.
—I apologise. I am being corrected all around and I stand corrected. I have seen more than most people. The majority of the Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the majority of the Committee, strongly oppose that proposition . . .
That is the proposition that a new non-violent erotica, or NVE, category be proposed and that that contain material as defined in the current classification of X. I continue:
It would entrench X-rated video (pornography described officially as `hard core pornography' . . .) in the community under guise of the misleading title of NVE.

There is no need for me to go into what that material contains because that has been discussed in, I suppose, laundered terms in this chamber. Clearly, the material is of such a nature that, when an honourable senator tried to have incorporated in Hansard a description of some of the material, it was ruled that it could not be incorporated. Presumably it was unparliamentary.

Even if it cannot be presented here, it can be presented in newsagencies throughout the country. This type of material has been advertised as an insert in a newspaper that is circulated throughout the country. I have a copy of a document contained in a news- paper, which was bought in Tasmania by a senior lady constituent of mine. She is a racing fan and she bought the newspaper for the racing section. The insert fell out. She was disgusted, horrified and concerned that this sort of material could be advertised in a newspaper. It is disconcerting. I will not go into it. Clearly, it advertises material that, firstly, shows high risk AIDS behaviour and, secondly, promotes the view of women as being highly promiscuous and available. This problem has been described in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

Thanks to every member of the Government, thanks to the Australian Democrats thus far, this material can be distributed throughout the country through the post. One of my subsequent amendments will ensure that this material cannot be distributed through the post or courier services. So that is non-discriminatory, which counteracts the argument adopted last time by people voting against the amendment. It is non-discriminatory in that it will affect postal services and other courier services. Contrary to what Senator Evans said on the last occasion about how we would get the postal services to look at every article that looks like a video, this is enforceable. I have never heard so much nonsense in all my life. Do not law enforcement agencies ever set traps? Is it legitimate for law enforcement agencies to set traps? Is it legitimate for law enforcement agencies to have somebody ask for this type of video and then to charge with an offence the very large firms with international connections in the United States that handle this material?

This is the import of the further amendments that I have. The further amendments that Senator Jenkins has will go some way in respect of the advertising material. I agree that there should be amendments which would go to ensuring that the very violent videos are not placed side by side with videos of PG or G classifications and that there is no advertising or display of the material in areas to which persons under the age of 18 years have access. That is a fairly reasonable proposal and it would be effective. It would go some of the way towards overcoming the problems that parents and others have in respect of this material. This material can get into the hands, and inevitably does get into the hands, of children.

This is a very important debate. All clauses of the Bill ought to be considered. I acknowledge what Senator Walters has said, that is, that if the amendment moved by Senator Jenkins is carried, it will effectively gut the Bill. To my way of thinking, that is very disconcerting. It may well be that, at a particular stage, the other matters before the Committee at present should be considered on their merits to see whether half a cake is better than none at all. That is something which needs to be considered by all Opposition and Government members.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Jenkins's) be agreed to.

I think that I should plead with Senator Lewis in equal futility. However, he has chosen to do what Senator Macklin hoped this morning the Opposition would not do again, as it eventually did in 1985, and that is to cave in to blackmail which has come by way of a letter from the Minister to all senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments which we are about to vote against could stand if the Opposition would stand by its amendments, as it has said publicly it would do. However, since it has chosen not to do that, the second option would be to put the alternative amendments which Senator Lewis has just talked about which would be supported by the Australian Democrats. We could have done that before lunch. Five hours ago we could have tossed those amendments back to the House of Representatives, which is still sitting, and confronted the Minister once more in the interests of the wheat growers of Australia.

The coalition has decided not to do that. The Democrats are disappointed that that is the case because we will not be able to have a successful vote on either the full range of amendments or, it seems, any alternative that ought to have been put forward today. We should not have to listen to a plea such as `The Government has a constituency out there and the Opposition has a constituency out there', as if it makes any difference. It is the Government and the Opposition together which are deregulating the domestic wheat market and along with it-this is the soft underbelly for the Government-the transport system. Let us make that quite clear before the vote is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to detain the Committee because we have been through this issue almost exhaustively. The facts of the matter are, as stated by my colleague Senator Lewis, that the Bill having been brought back to this chamber yesterday, the Opposition, in good faith, has sought to give the Government a further period for consideration of the possibility of agreeing to the four amendments which Senator Lewis outlined yesterday. At that time I supported him in outlining them. The amendments concerned the guaranteed minimum price arrangements, the question of a grower chairman and the composition of the Board, the application of the Trade Practices Act to the intrastate trade in wheat, and the degree of grower control of funds contributed by levies on wheat growers-not government funds but funds contributed by levies on wheat growers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Ray, informed us-he did so because the Minister responsible was not present-a moment ago that this afternoon in the other place the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, gave the Government's answer by way of a response to a dorothy dix question, thereby compounding the series of discourtesies to this place of which the Minister has been guilty throughout his whole handling of this matter. That was merely another small element in the total shabby process on which the Government has embarked.

As my colleague Senator Lewis has said, the Government's principal activity in all this has been to divide the coalition parties. It will not succeed in doing so. The coalition parties will remain united for the overwhelmingly important purpose for which the people of this country want them to remain united, and that is to get rid of this Government, a task in which we propose to be successful as soon as the Government gives us the opportunity to do so. I will not pursue that point. I simply lay it very clearly on the line that that mine has been mined out as far as the Government is concerned.

Yesterday Senator Lewis, in good faith, gave the Government an opportunity to respond sensibly, and after consideration overnight, to his suggestions. The Government has told us today quite clearly that it proposes to say nothing other than to present us with two fingers on that matter and that basically, as far as the Government and Mr Kerin are concerned, the wheat growers of this country can go and jump. If that is the message which the Government wants to convey to wheat growers, we will do our best to assist it in that regard.

In light of the diversionary remarks by the Democrat speaker who preceded me, I make it clear that at this stage the debate has nothing to do with deregulation of the wheat industry. As I said yesterday, the one comment with which I agreed in the threatening letter which Mr Kerin wrote to all honourable senators was that the deregulation debate was over. It was over at the time he wrote that letter; as he said quite rightly in that respect, two weeks earlier. For Senator Powell to yap away today about deregulation and matters of that kind is simply an illustration of how out of date and far behind the times the Democrats have become in this matter. The very idea of the Australian Democrats standing up in this place and presenting themselves as the champions of the wheat farmers of Australia is almost as bizarre as having the League of Rights stand up in that categorisation. There is a resemblance between the two groups in some respects. They are both always skirmishing around the fringes of whatever issue happens to be current at the time with a view to picking up a vote or two in their usual jackal-like manner.

I join with Senator Lewis in expressing disappointment-I will refrain from using stronger words than that-at the attitude which the Government has indicated it proposes to adopt to this legislation. That having been said, I propose to sit down so we can get on with the business of getting rid of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a couple of words on the non-acceptance of some very sensible amendments that were sent to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). I would have thought he would definitely agree to them, because they were full of commonsense and they would have improved this Bill. He threatened that if we did not pass it, he was going to let it lapse and make sure that the Australian wheat growers had neither an export market through the Australian Wheat Board nor a domestic market. The wheat growers of Australia have been hoodwinked by the Minister. I am very disappointed that he has not accepted those amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to put on the record at this stage that, quite apart from the amendments that we put forward, the Government had to bring in 39 amendments to its own legislation. That is a sign of a very badly drafted Bill. It shows that the Government was drafting a Bill for political purposes and with political motives in mind rather than in the interests of the industry and the nation. I believe Mr Kerin has now put himself right up the very sharp end of any deregulation in this country. He has asked the wheat growers to pay a supreme sacrifice without fixing up those few little things that would have helped make it not so bad. He says he wants to bring efficiencies into the domestic wheat market. I say to him, and to all the people of Australia, `Make sure that you now put it right up the ginger of the Australian Labor Party to bring forward the deficiencies of the labour market, the deficiencies of the waterfront and the deficiencies that this country of ours is burdened with at the moment'.
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us see the whites of Senator Schacht's eyes. He has done some pretty smart things. I do not imagine his eyes would be too white after looking through all those keyholes that he has been looking through lately. Maybe his ears are not too full of wax, either, from what he has been hearing through those keyholes. I ask you, Mr Chairman, and everyone else to mark my words. The wheat growers have paid a sacrifice. Let us see whether the Labor Party can get its little mates to pay a sacrifice as far as the waterfront and the deregulation of the labour market are concerned.

—To ensure that the record is straight in terms of jumping on bandwagons and fiddling around the fringes of things, the Australian Democrats, including Senator Macklin, our former spokesperson for primary industry, as pointed out in this debate, have consistently supported in particular grower control of industries such as this and have a fine record in that area. I will leave judgment on our performance and that of other parties in this place to the wheat growers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning when I was speaking during the committee stage, I quoted from a speech made by the Hon. Tom McVeigh on 4 October 1984, speaking on the Wheat Marketing Bill. I would like to quote another part of his speech. When referring to Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industry-as his portfolio was called at that time-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Over recent days I have exposed the blackmail and the treachery of this spineless man . . .
It is interesting that shortly we will actually have a vote, and then we will find out who have caved into blackmail and who indeed are spineless.

The question is: That the Committee does not insist upon amendments Nos. 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 and 20 to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the end of the last round of a long debate on the future of wheat marketing in Australia-a debate highlighted, in the coalition's view, by the Government's shabby treatment of Australia's wheat growers. I did not hear Mr Kerin in the House of Representatives today when he was answering a dorothy dixer, but I have in my hand a copy of an Australian Associated Press report about what he said. I want to deny his allegations. Apparently he said:

SPEECH.PARA: the . . . new Leader of the Opposition has ratted on his mates who support deregulation and has returned to the days of Liberal toadying to the . . . National Party.

I will not read out the offensive words. I just say to the media, for what it is worth, that they have seen the vote tonight. There is no question of the Liberal Party or the National Party ratting on any decision of the former leader, Mr Howard, or on the decision of the coalition parties some time ago. I say this because the wheat industry and the effects of this Bill are so complicated that many people, including most of the media, do not understand them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially as they did not want to understand.

—Yes, especially as many of them did not want to understand. The Government kept talking about deregulation when deregulation was never at issue. The Government has exploited this in an attempt to put a wedge between the coalition partners, ignoring the legitimate grievances of the industry and its 46,000 participants. This legislation has been hailed as the Government's first piece-indeed, only piece-of micro-economic reform. It has been said that to vote against it would be to vote against deregulation. Unfortunately, the media have never been able to understand that none of the Opposition amendments have been against deregulation of the domestic wheat market, or even more complete deregulation of transport than that proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: To test the genuineness of the Government's desire for deregulation we moved an amendment to extend the use of the export power to allow greater labour flexibility and efficiency in the grain handling, transport and waterfront sectors. The Government failed the test by not even considering the proposal. This again reveals its double standards towards significant and comprehensive reform. All that we ever tried to do was improve the legislation. That would have cost the Government and the taxpayers nothing, but would have provided real value for the farmers of Australia. However, instead of looking at what is right for the wheat industry, the Government has played petty party politics, and that is something that the wheat growers of this country will not forget. Every Australian knows that this Government has made an absolute mess of the economy and that we need every dollar of export income that we can get. As the wheat industry earns more than $2 billion in export income each year, Australians will not be impressed by this Government's callous treatment of such an important industry.

Today the Government had only to decide on two relatively minor amendments which in no way would have altered the thrust of the legislation. The first would have provided a very reasonable 90 per cent underwriting guarantee for five years. The Government knows, and the Minister has said publicly, that that would not cost the Government any money. The second amendment would have provided for a grower chairman. In his second reading speech the Minister said that he would appoint a grower chairman, so we really were not asking for very much. The Government has refused these reasonable requests and will stand condemned for all time by Australia's 46,000 wheat growers.

However, there is a bright side for this industry. There is now a very clear choice for the grain growers of Australia. They can vote either for this disgraced Government, which does not care about their future, or for the coalition parties, which, on return to government, will amend this legislation to make provision for a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee; a wheat grower chairman; five of the panel-selected board members to be wheat growers; and a review of the Board's Australian trading operations to see whether trade practices exemption is required. Australian grain growers are so efficient that they are able to compete on world markets against the highly subsidised grain from the United States and the European Economic Community. The gross value of wheat this season is expected to be $2.77 billion, but this Government has completely disregarded the value of the industry as it has tried to score political points. The industry, and indeed the Australian taxpayer, should never forgive or forget this shabby treatment of such a major industry in this country.

While the Opposition is disappointed that its amendments have not been accepted, it has forced the Government to make several major changes, including: the Wheat Board remaining the sole marketer of export wheat; consultation with grain growers about the use and management of their levy funds; more flexibility in how the Wheat Board pays its staff; legislation which will lower the cost of storage, handling and transport; protection for State marketing boards; and numerous technical amendments to improve the very badly drafted legislation. We will now wait and see whether the Government has the same political deregulation drive when it comes to the waterfront, coastal shipping labour practices, and the many other things keeping farmer costs high and making our primary products less competitive overseas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want, very briefly, to support in toto the remarks that have just been made by Senator Lewis and, in particular, to underline his comments about the political implications of this Bill. After all, it has been about politics from beginning to end. It has not been about wheat marketing; it has been about politics. The Government has tried to play a very smart game but, as sometimes happens on these occasions, it has been too clever by half. Politically, the outcome of this will be that all wheat growers in this country, at the next election, will have the choice between electing parties that have agreed and undertaken, in their written coalition policies, to do the things that Senator Lewis has just told the Senate they intend to do and putting back into office the disgraced and failed Government that has brought them to the present pass by way of these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the curtain does come down on this very long and tortuous issue, I devote my final words to restating my view: for so long all that has ever stood between wheat farmers and destitution has been the Australian Wheat Board. This evening we are seeing its dismantlement and destruction. I am sure that the ghost of Black Jack McEwen will haunt this chamber this evening.
