DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988INCOME TAX (FUND CONTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this legislation was interrupted just before lunch I was making the point that superannuation conducted by private companies contributed substantially to the savings of this nation. We need savings more than we have ever needed them before because of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Government. We have a colossal overseas debt. We are not generating sufficient funds within our country to keep economic growth going. Therefore, superannuation is vital to us.

SPEECH.PARA: In that environment one would think that rather than imposing heavier taxes on superannuation, as this Government is now doing by this legislation, the Government would have been better off giving incentives to individuals to contribute to their welfare and retirement. That would seem to be the logical situation, but of course the Government has removed tax incentives for people, other than self-employed people, who want to contribute to their superannuation. In imposing a further tax on the income of superannuation funds and in other ways it has created a disincentive for people to do so.

The Government has adopted an entirely contradictory approach. It is inconsistent with its overall approach towards retirement planning, which it professed at an earlier stage, and quite obviously confuses the public as to its real intentions in retirement income policy. On the one hand, the Government says it wants to encourage people to take out superannuation but, on the other hand, it whacks three different kinds of taxes on superannuation: first, by this legislation, it imposes a tax on contributions made to the funds; secondly, it imposes a tax on investment earnings; and, thirdly, when one eventually takes the benefit out, there is a tax on it. Even if one takes the end benefit in the form of an annuity, no deduction is provided against taxable income for the cost, to a reasonable extent, of purchasing that annuity.

The Government says that these legislative changes complete its review of superannuation tax arrangements. Of course, that is absolute nonsense. This is just the latest instalment. Since 1983, when this Government was first elected, there have been no fewer than 20 changes to retirement planning. In respect of superannuation and the way in which taxation applies to it, we have pre-1983 tax rules, we have post-1983 tax rules, we have pre-1985 tax rules, we have pre-1986 tax rules, we have pre-July 1988 tax rules and we have post-July 1988 tax rules. We have had one confusing policy change after another. Is it any wonder that the population is confused about what the Government intends? The industry itself is having enormous difficulty in comprehending the legislation. That industry is vital to our future in terms of stimulating savings for economic growth.

It has to be noted that there is still a long way to go. The Government has already said that it is conducting a review of both public sector and private sector superannuation arrangements in conjunction with the Cass review of retirement planning systems. The Government has not given us a definite time but we are led to believe that further changes may well come into play some time later this year. Again, there are more changes down the track. It makes a further mockery of what this Government has been saying about certainty in people being able to plan for their futures.

The main point that I wish to bring to the Senate's attention is that there are no genuine incentives for people to participate in superannuation schemes. The longstanding view of the community has been that superannuation funds need to be expanded in order to increase retirement income. The Cass report recommended that. So did the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. This legislation quite patently does not encourage private retirement income cover. Sure, it provides some tax incentive for the self-employed in that the deduction available to them has risen from some $1,500 to $3,000. But it does not provide any incentive to employed people where funds are provided by individual employers to contribute to their own retirement.

Surely the way to encourage people to look after themselves in retirement would be to provide tax incentives. But the Government does not enter into that area at all. Instead, we have a gradual movement towards the privatisation of superannuation and imposing the cost on employers rather than encouraging a genuine partnership between employers and employees and the Government by tax incentives to share the future cost of superannuation. Surely, that ought to be the objective of the Government. It as much as admitted it when three or four years ago it introduced the 3 per cent productivity scheme. That indicated the direction the Government wanted superannuation to go but the Government failed to go further and encourage employees to contribute to those schemes by allowing them tax deductions for those contributions. If the Government were interested in the future of superannuation then it would move down that track, but it has failed to do so.

This legislation only rearranges the existing tax concessions; it does not increase the incentive for tax savings so as to encourage people to fund their own retirement income schemes. Yet that is what the Government claims it was on about in the first place. A total confusion of objectives has existed since 1983.

It is obvious that the Government had an opportunity to increase incentives but it did not do a thing about it. In fact, it is saying no to the further encouragement of self-funding. Obviously, it is jeopardising the future of these kinds of schemes.

To further demonstrate the point, if we look at the case of lower income earners we see that the equivalent of the combination of these three taxes which are now being applied to superannuation is to apply a marginal rate of 29 per cent tax to those amounts. That means that there is a disincentive for low income earners-those who are earning less than, say, $20,000 a year or thereabouts-because their marginal income tax rate is 29 per cent or less, to put their money into superannuation. If they do put it into superannuation they will be incurring a higher rate of tax than they would on their other income. Surely that kind of nonsense is what the Government ought to be seeking to redress. Its failure to do so, of course, has left its retirement income policy in an absolute shambles.

I turn to some of those who are losers in this Government's taxation scheme. There are literally hundreds of thousands of them. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his address last year promised that there would be not one cent of superannuation lost for any member of superannuation funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only in a very restricted sense.

—As it has turned out, we know that we cannot trust that. There are a number of areas where this has happened. The fact is that benefits will be lost by members of funds as a result of these new taxation measures, notwithstanding the Government's promises. Amongst other assurances, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: For most superannuation funds this will mean in practice no tax at all on investment earnings. For others the rate will be minimal, and can readily be adjusted to zero by including more Australian company shares in their investment portfolios.

Of course, that is to take advantage of the dividend imputation scheme. It is an impossibility to accommodate all the funds that are flowing through the superannuation system in the stock markets so as to take advantage of that facility. It is just not on. While the Government continues to perpetrate that little fib, of course, we will not get a proper debate about the form of this legislation. It is a nonsense, absolute codswallop. There will be a significant number of losers. Senator Haines has already drawn our attention to those who will be putting their money into approved deposit funds. Those who put their accumulated retirement savings in a so-called roll-over facility which has no investment in shares but rather in fixed interest will find that they have to pay 15 per cent tax. They are obviously going to be losers whereas previously they would not have been.

Consider the case of new members entering superannuation schemes who are, one might say, on the younger side of their careers, maybe around 30 years of age. For young people who are just commencing to participate in superannuation, the cumulative effect of the earnings tax on superannuation funds over a working lifetime will be substantial. For a 30-year-old, the loss at age 65 in a non-contributory superannuation scheme will be something like 6.5 per cent of the total sum. That means $6,500 out of $100,000. If one can project one's thinking ahead, at current rates of inflation and with what future rates may be, $100,000 in 40 years is going to be a very small amount of money. One can expect losses to be far greater than that when inflation is taken into account.

If we look at those people who have substantial prior service before 1 July 1988, they will also be net losers as a result of the new tax. This is despite the fact that, in the legislation, there is a no detriment clause to contain that situation. People in that category will include mostly those who have gained the benefit through the 3 per cent productivity contribution scheme and have invested their money in union/industry investment and superannuation schemes. Generally, they have followed a capital guaranteed approach to investments. These are the unionists, the low income earners, presumably, the blue-collar workers, the very people whom Hawke and Keating are supposed to represent; yet they are the ones who will lose most as a result of this package. Where is the sense in all this? We should be moving in the opposite direction of improving the incentives for people to invest in their own superannuation.

It is true that this legislation contains a number of technical difficulties, and many of those difficulties have been brought out already by my colleagues and the Australian Democrats during the debate. No doubt there will be further debate on those matters when we come to the committee stage. However, the number of matters which have been raised so far deserve the most thorough examination by the Government in the course of this debate. I notice that we have very few speakers from the Government side prepared to come in here and defend the Government's taxation regime. Maybe that speaks volumes for how much they feel about it in the light of representations that have come to them from ordinary folk.

I want to highlight very briefly the Opposition's commitment to vote against the new tax in respect of investment income. That is obviously the most pernicious in that it will tend to reduce substantially the accumulated amount in superannuation funds over the career of a member of the fund. I believe that will probably cost a relatively small amount of money, although the Government is unable or unwilling to tell us how much it might be. I would suggest that it is probably less than $100m across the whole community. It is surprising, though, that the Government is totally unable to give us an estimate of what that might be. In fact, the original statements by the Treasurer gave us no indication whatsoever of the breakdown of the cost between the tax on contributions to superannuation funds and the cost of tax on investment income. That is a hopeless situation for any government to be in and really does show just how intelligent its decision-making processes are.

The other thing the Opposition will be doing which I strongly support is moving to raise the lump sum tax threshold below which tax is not payable from $60,000 to $125,000. That is obviously a sensible move. The current level of $60,000 makes the point that there should be an exemption for some amount of money from a lump sum to be invested in order to generate income, and that ought to equate roughly to a reasonable standard of living. Certainly $60,000 does not do that; $125,000 is far nearer to the total amount of money that would need to be invested in order to generate an income equating with the age pension. That is certainly to be welcomed and something that this Government ought to consider favour- ably. We hope we have its support on that amendment.

Finally, I believe that there is a substantial matter that ought to be examined carefully by the Government affecting, in general terms, life companies; that is, a new regime for the taxing of life insurance companies. Obviously there are numerous anomalies here which are very difficult and technical matters. I believe the Government is examining those questions. I hope it will continue to conduct a favourable debate with the life insurance industry to gain a far more equitable approach to that which is currently in vogue so as to more carefully align the tax deductability of expenses incurred by life companies with those which are actually incurred in running the business to which they are committed. That matter needs examination. I hope that the Government is prepared to give it that in the most generous way.
Many of us on the Opposition benches have misgivings about this legislation. We shall be moving substantial amendments and opposing the vital area of tax on investment income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and cognate Bills is very clearly a revenue raising exercise. It has little to do with principles and a lot more to do with more income for the Government. I intend to spend most of my time in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989. This Bill implements changes announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May economic statement 1988. I would like to remark on just how shoddily the Government is treating the Parliament in bringing forward this package more than a year after the changes were announced.

SPEECH.PARA: Some industry observers have described the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) as a minefield. Others have described it as a maze-once you are in it is very difficult to find a path out. It is a very strange piece of legislation. It gives unusually wide powers to the Commissioner of Taxation and to the Commissioner of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC). In fact, it spells out draconian requirements for all funds which are so great that it will mean the demise of many small superannuation funds around Australia. But the big winners, as in all cases with this Government, will be the big life assurance companies-not the small funds-and those superannuation funds and roll-over funds, et cetera, associated with the major banks.

Because of legislation previously passed in this place, the cost burden of superannuation funds and the like is often disproportionate to the income earned. This is one of the sad features about occupational superannuation and in the package before us today. It does not recognise the balance between the revenue and costs. For example, only last week I heard of a closed fund which had an income of $3,000 per annum and an administrative cost of $6,000. Not all funds are geared to have high revenues, but these sorts of funds will be in significant trouble when this package of legislation is passed, as will the small funds. Inevitably, there will be a movement towards what is termed pooled funds because of all the complications that will arise from this and earlier legislation.

The timing of this legislation is simply appalling, because it comes more than 10 months after the Treasurer's press release, and it requires action to be taken by these funds before 30 June in order to get an adequate tax deductability. It does not give them much time, does it? In November last year the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) was introduced. By leaving it on the table, at least it provided some relief and an opportunity for what I would call a limited amount of consultation. But what we have before us today is the worst form of legislation by press release, because there is virtually no opportunity for us to delay its implementation. It would be desirable for its provisions to take effect not from 1 July this year but from 1 July next year. Many life offices have taken action and have transferred moneys on the basis of the press release and not of the legislation. If we decided to delay this legislation beyond 1 July 1989, it would cause acute problems. It would cause embarrassment for all those who had acted in good faith on the basis of a press release. We need a commitment from the Government that legislation will follow within less than three months of a press release, because these burdens are quite intolerable and unacceptable.

Furthermore, there is the problem of getting all the approvals and rulings from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The burdens that are being placed on the trustees of funds are quite abnormal and unreasonable; yet most of these requirements have to be met before 30 June. I say to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is in the chamber, that this cannot be done. First, the life officer has to consult the industry before he can get his regulations. There are requirements for notifications to recipients to be in a form approved by the Commission; yet naturally, we have not even got the approved form. Why not? It is because we do not have the regulations. The regulations should have been issued prior to or at the time these Bills were being debated. It is quite unfair to participants. So, we do not have the approved form, we do not have the regulations, and we do not have the signatures on these forms, and the forms have not been submitted for approval.

I now wish to comment on some curious drafting-and there is plenty of it. For example, let us take clause 275 of the Bill. This clause requires different things to be done on the last two days of receiving income. Let me turn to another example. The greatest criticism surely must be the Bill's impact on savings. It is an appropriate time to debate the impact of superannuation legislation on savings. This Bill will lessen the interest in superannuation as an investment option. Fancy a government, when it is trying to cool the economy, when it is trying to lift people's propensity to save, and when we hear stories about the need to have special legislation to lessen the impact of taxation on personal savings, deliberately putting before us a measure which will lessen the right and opportunity to save and take away some options for people to save! It is incredible.

Given that one of Australia's problems is that it has a relatively low level of savings, it is indeed strange that this Government should be putting before this Parliament, at this very time, legislation to positively discriminate against and to discourage savings, particularly so when one adds to this the second dimension-the fact that we have an ageing population whose future retirement benefits have largely been unfunded over the productive working life of the retirees. This Bill effectively discriminates against individual savings, particularly for the self-funded retirement-in particular at the level just around or below average weekly earnings. To give the Senate an example, the tax impost could be about 40 per cent on fund earnings against a lower marginal personal rate based on the earnings of the individual of less than 29 per cent. What is the incentive there? In another area the Government is telling us to try to move into superannuation. It has been built into awards. It would be far better for many of those employees to pay off their high mortgages rather than move into an area where they are now maximising their taxes as a result of being forced into superannuation where there is a higher rate of tax on the fund and on those superannuation earnings than on their personal earnings week by week. This Government has a strange level of priorities. No wonder it is being coined as a party of the rich and famous.

Let us look at another dilemma that we have. This time the dilemma relates to opposition to the Bills. We have found that the industry is not united. Some sections want amendments, others want delays. At another extreme we have a section of the industry that wants us to vote against the whole package of Bills because it thinks they are not good enough. The only thing that is certain is that the passage of this tax Bill relating to superannuation will benefit the large life offices, the actuaries and the accountants. One cynic has gone as far as saying that if Australia needs a recovery, this Bill is going to help-but in a narrow and restrictive sense because it will be an actuary led recovery, with the accountants not far behind. Why do I say this? It is because of the greatly enhanced role and responsibilities for approved actuaries.

This Bill is yet another in a whole host of legislative changes that have occurred in relation to superannuation since this Government came to office. There have been over 20 major changes in this general area. What does the Treasurer say in support of this legislation? Strangely, he is reported as saying that these changes will be implemented without diminishing any personal end benefit by one cent. He must have regretted making that commitment because it is only true in a very narrow and restricted sense. In order to make it true in that very narrow and restricted sense he had to introduce horrific legislation. In other words, to honour that commitment in any way at all, and then only in a very narrow manner, he had to introduce cumbersome procedures that are going to add hundreds of thousands of dollars to the administration of those funds. Those procedures will be so complicated in some areas that it will be necessary to set up funds within funds in order to give legislative effect to that commitment that was not thought through by the Treasurer. It is only going to operate in one area. Most people are going to be very much worse off. These complications and cumbersome legislative requirements could have been simplified by lifting the threshold and taxing the excess at 15 per cent. Instead, the Government has opted for an increased workload for fund trustees, administrators and fund managers. The administrative complexities that can be expected raise a number of questions as to whether it is even worth persisting with superannuation at all, particularly for small employer-sponsored superannuation funds.

This is an appropriate time to remind the Senate that the Treasurer has often said that tax reform will lead to simplified income tax laws. This has not been true. Tax reform has been associated with some of the most complex legislation that has ever been introduced into this Parliament. If the Treasurer insists on pursuing this notion of tax reform with so-called simplicity then it is about time we stopped this so-called reform. If honourable senators do not think that this is complicated and involves issues that counter and contradict each other, perhaps they should look at some of the anti-deterrent provisions of the Bill.

A further problem facing the funds is the lack of regulations from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. There is a responsibility for the Commission to approve past funding credits but the regulations that I mentioned before have not been drafted to enable such action to take place. The funds could be penalised because-as I have said previously-the operative date is 1 July 1989 and there may not be adequate time for the regulations and all the approvals to be put in place. It is just not good enough. The regulations have not been drafted. You might recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we had the same problem with occupational superannuation. The Government only just finished drafting the first stage. It had problems with the last Bill two or three years ago and it is now looking at stage two for further regulations in that particular area. How long are we going to have to wait for adequate regulations to be drafted in relation to the superannuation tax Bill which is before us today?

There are also problems for the actuaries themselves. After all, the actuaries are the people who are going to benefit most because of their enhanced role and responsibility. There is at least one requirement for an actuarial calculation to be based on last year's result. One does not have to be an actuary to know of the potential for wide fluctuations in the investment portfolio from year to year in superannuation funds. A prudent actuary will actually calculate his figures over a longer time frame, yet the legislation prohibits this. It prohibits a cautious and prudent approach that a normal actuary acting with care and consideration would take. There is a legislative requirement that prohibits the prudent approach; he must calculate his figures purely on the basis of what happened last year.

There is also a doubt about the definition of an actuary. It is simple for those who are members of the Institute of Actuaries but when one moves to provincial areas the problem becomes significant. If one walks into a bank building and sees the name `accountant' on the door, that does not signify that he has any particular qualifications. The Australian Taxation Office and the ISC should have been able to come up with one common return. In other words, there are responsibilities for the Tax Office and for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. One would have thought that the Government would have been able to come up with one form, maybe with addenda, to meet the requirements of the Tax Office and the Superannuation Commission. But that is too hard. The Government wants to put the responsibility, the extra work, back onto the trustees and the administrators. It could not even come up with one form. Under the provisions we are told that there will be one common instruction book. That is great. At least it is a first step. But, separate forms for the Australian Taxation Office and the ISC will be required. That is just not good enough for a government that is putting more and more responsibilities onto individuals.

Let me run through the main features of this package. There is a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds. So what initially goes into a fund will not be 100 per cent of the employer's and the employee's contributions, because the employer's contribution will be diminished by 15 per cent. Only 85 per cent of the capital will go in in the first place. There is also this iniquitous 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income. As my colleague Senator Messner mentioned earlier, this will force more and more funds into investing in fully franked dividends in order to minimise the tax payable. Probably no prudent trustee-manager would put more than say 30 per cent of his funds into such areas, because caution is needed: there must be a spread of the investment risk. There is also a 16.25 per cent tax, which includes the Medicare levy, on sums over $60,000, thereby reducing the previous post-1983 lump sum tax by 15 per cent. This is one of the few small carrots, I suppose. There is also a capital gains tax on assets bought and sold by superannuation funds after 1 July 1988. Of course, this provision is designed to avoid retrospectivity.

I now wish to summarise briefly the effect that these changes will have on different types of funds. Before moving to that, I mention that two basic types of funds are provided for: there is a complying fund and a non-complying fund-and there are severe tax disincentives associated with non-complying funds. Basically, a complying fund is one that has received a notice of compliance within the umbrella of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Acts. There will be a 15 per cent tax on complying funds and roll-over annuities. Non-complying funds holding superannuation policies will be taxed at the top marginal rate, and normal life insurance business, including accident and disability cover, will be taxed at 39 per cent. That is the situation for life insurance companies.

Non-statutory fund business will be taxed at 39 per cent. The taxation basis for registered organisations will consist of three categories: firstly, businesses associated with complying superannuation funds or roll-over annuities are to be taxed at 15 per cent. Secondly, business associated with policies held by non-complying superannuation funds will be taxed at the top marginal rate. Thirdly, business referable to life insurance as well as accident and disability insurance will be taxed at 30 per cent.

In the area of pension fund assets we find further unnecessary complications. This area is becoming increasingly important as more people opt for pensions rather than lump sum payments. Under this legislation, assets backing current pension payments will be treated differently, and investment income from these particular assets will not be subject to taxation at 15 per cent. From the second reading speech, I understand that the Government has two means of handling such situations. Firstly, one separates out those assets backing pensions in course of payment and separately accounts for them; or, alternatively, one exempts a proportion of income linked to pension liabilities in a complying fund. That is all very complicated, and it requires additional administrative effort and care.

Next there are the difficulties with the pension rebate. There will be three basic steps to calculate tax rebates on pension benefits: firstly, determining the taxable portion of the pension; secondly, determining that part of the taxable pension relating to fund membership after 30 June 1983, of all dates; and, thirdly, calculating the rebate as a percentage of the post-July 1983 portion of taxable pension. It is indeed a complicated business. How can we expect the small funds to keep up with all the legislative requirements and the separation of investments and income on this basis? Where a pension commences before the age of 55 because of death or disablement, the rebate applies. There are no other circumstances where a rebate is applicable to pensions commencing prior to age 55-not even after a person has reached 55.

There are further complications with the transfer to roll-over funds. We all know that lump sum benefits can be rolled over into approved deposit funds or deferred annuity funds, thereby deferring the tax payable. However, later withdrawals from such funds are taxed in a manner similar to that applying to superannuation fund payments. So the package of amending tax Bills which we are considering in this cognate debate will include the changes to the concessional application of capital gains tax to superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation funds. It includes also the reduction in the scales of tax on the retirement benefits paid from taxed funds.

Because my time is fairly limited, I must skip some of the more complicated features in order to highlight for the Senate some of the major problems associated with these funds. Before doing so, I must refer to what we term the `special income' category, which applies in respect of certain excluded private company dividends and non-arm's length transactions. This special income will be taxed at 49 per cent after allowance for deductions exclusively related or appropriately related to such income. While generally the taxable income of these funds will be determined in the same manner as for other taxpayers, there will be some differences in the treatment of funds' assessable income and allowable deductions. I would like to quote the words of Mr Robert Brown, who wrote in the Chartered Accountant of February this year. He said:
The new superannuation laws are unnecessarily complex-
the emphasis is on the word `unnecessarily'-
and appear to have as their aim the raising of further revenue for the Government.

That is true. So, as I mentioned earlier, this legislation clearly should be seen as an impediment to saving and a disincentive for people to invest in superannuation. Above all, this legislation is a revenue raising exercise. It has little to do with principles and a lot more to do with income for the Government. Unfortunately, the consequence of all this will be that many people will be turned off superannuation altogether-a result which the Government can ill afford.

As we debate this legislation, we know that already some unintended consequences have come to light. Why will the Government not fix them up now rather than correct them down the track in two or three years time? One of the great difficulties-and we, as the Opposition, seek to rectify this-is that the income of a superannuation fund will be reduced, through the tax on employer contributions, to a greater extent than expected by the Government. Most superannuation funds will find it almost impossible to offset the 15 per cent tax on fund earnings as the Government claims they can. I think the Government has been blinded by its own rhetoric. It has been advised of the problems by the industry, and yet there is no substantial change.

Serious unintended market distortions may be caused by the new emphasis which superannuation funds will have to give to equity investments in domestic shares which will return fully franked imputed tax credits on dividend income. This tends to push people into the highly speculative stock market at a time when perhaps people should be investing in other areas. At this time it would be far better for people in receipt of average weekly earnings or just below that level to be paying off their mortgages, the interest rates for which are at disastrous levels, and reducing their interest component rather than moving into superannuation. These Bills are an absolute disaster. They are full of unintended consequences and will be a nightmare to administer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately a package of taxation Bills which give effect to a number of proposals announced in the May 1988 economic statement and the 12 April 1989 economic statement. With the indulgence of the Senate I will address my remarks first to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Rebates) Bill 1989, which reduces personal income tax in two stages commencing on 1 July 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the tax cuts announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 12 April statement. I am sure everybody welcomes them. I particularly welcome the measures to assist families and help the elderly. There is no doubt that these tax cuts are long overdue. However, having said that, I have some difficulty following the logic of the explanation for the integrity of the tax cuts, having looked at the overall economic strategy that has been presented to us by the Government. On the one hand, we have high interest rates designed to slow down domestic consumer demand and, on the other hand, we have significant tax breaks which under normal circumstances can be assumed to do nothing less than considerably stimulate that consumer demand. I make no mention of the productivity pay-out; it is nothing more than a further wage adjustment of a uniform nature.

Mr Keating's theory, if I understand it correctly, is that the tax rates fall into a gap or a trough which will be brought about as a result of his Budget setting predictions. Of course, the truth is that without exception those predictions have been wrong. The Budget predicted that gross domestic product (GDP) growth would be 3.5 per cent; it is now 4.7 per cent. Average earnings were expected to be 6.5 per cent, according to the Budget, and they now look like being 7.3 per cent. Import volumes were expected to be 9.5 per cent, while the figure is now 28.2 per cent. Employment growth was predicted to be 2.75 per cent; it is now 4 per cent. It would seem that inflation is considerably ahead of the projections given to us by the Government. By any measure, on those calculations there is a conflict in logic between the tight monetary policy, the high interest rate policy of the Government, and the fact that it is providing tax cuts.

The truth is that the tax cuts will in many respects do very little to alleviate the deplorable financial burden faced by the vast majority of Australians who have suffered at the hands of this Government's increased taxation. It has increased taxation consistently since it came to office in 1983. Perhaps it is worth reminding ourselves of the major tax initiatives which this Government has taken since 1983. I do not raise them because they are intrinsically wrong; I raise them because they are part of the record of this Government's tax policy. We saw the introduction of lump sum superannuation payments from 1 July 1983, which raised $300m in revenue in its first year of operation. We saw the introduction of the Medicare levy on 1 February 1984, which in its first year of operation provided the Government with $1,054m in revenue. As a result of that measure, the number of people in private funds has fallen, if my memory serves me correctly, from 70 per cent to the current figure of 45 per cent. We saw the abolition of negative gearing on 1 July 1985; that went through until 1 June 1987, when the Government realised that there was a dramatic downturn in the amount of rental accommodation available. During that period of aberration the measure raised the Government $50m in revenue. We saw the application of tax-free threshold restrictions, which added $85m in revenue. A capital gains tax was introduced on 20 September 1985. In the 1987-88 financial year it returned to the Government $89.7m. As from 1 July 1986 we saw the application of a fringe benefits tax, which for the 1986-87 period provided $535m in revenue and $881m in 1988-89.

As from 20 September 1985, deductability for entertainment expenses was abolished and the revenue gain for 1986-87 was $330m. The foreign tax credits system, which applied from the 1987-88 financial year, has earned the Government $60m in revenue. The deductability of accelerated depreciation rates was abolished from 25 May 1988. It is estimated that that measure has produced a revenue gain of $190m. As from 1 January 1991 we will have the abolition of income tax exemption for the gold mining industry. On the Government's figures, it is predicted to provide an annual revenue of $70m. My judgment is that, given the present price of gold, the value of the Australia dollar and the disincentive that has created for the industry, that revenue figure is pitched far too high. This series of Bills contains a proposal to tax superannuation funds at the rate of 15 per cent. The Government calculates that it will raise approximately $980m in 1989-90.

I remind the Senate of a commitment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made by way of a taxation policy statement on 31 October 1984 when he set out nine fundamental principles which would dictate the direction the Government would take in respect of its taxation policy. He said:

There must be no increase in the overall tax burden as measured by the share of Commonwealth Government tax revenue in gross domestic product next year or through the Government's next term in office.

The Federal Government's tax to GDP ratio has risen every year since then: in 1985-86 it was 25 per cent, it rose to 25.7 per cent in 1987-88, and today the figure is 27.3 per cent. Another Government pledge was as follows:
Any reform must continue the process already begun by this Government and provide further cuts in personal income tax.

The truth is that these taxes in many respects are not for real in the context of the level of taxation paid by people since that date. Until this year we have seen an increase in the share of personal income tax within the total Commonwealth tax revenue from 55.5 per cent to 57.7 per cent in 1988. It is not without significance, of course, to note that much of the Government's estimated Budget surplus of $5,600m for this financial year is expected to come from increases in revenue as a result of increasing levels of taxation. Pay as you earn (PAYE) tax collections to the end of March were 18.2 per cent higher than collections in the first nine months of 1987-88. I understand that a new figure out inflates that 18.2 per cent figure. That should be contrasted with what occurred during the last financial year of the Fraser Government, when 17.45 per cent of average weekly earnings went into personal income tax. Under Hawke, that level rose to a height of 20.85 per cent in 1988-89. Even after the tax cuts in the coming financial year, that percentage will still be 18.6 per cent, rising by 1991-92 to 20.56 per cent.

I think that Senator Walsh admitted last year that in two previous financial years $3 billion of revenue had been collected by the Government as a result of bracket creep. Since the Government's last notional tax cut, $10 billion of additional revenue has flowed into the Government's coffers, and from that it has discharged the minute amount of $4.7 billion. In other words, slightly less than half the revenue received by way of taxation is being redistributed back. With the Senate's indulgence I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document prepared for me by the Parliamentary Library which shows the number of people who have moved into different brackets over the last three years.
Leave granted.
