TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. While an additional 2 1/2 million people in the $20,801 to $35,000 salary range will benefit from a 1c drop in their marginal tax rate in 1989-90, the following year 515,600 people will move upwards into a tax bracket where they will face an additional 8c in the dollar rise, and 316,300 new people will move into the $20,601 to $35,000 bracket. They will be faced with a punishing 10c rise in their marginal tax rate. So it is no wonder that there is out there a growing constituency of disaffected workers as they see their real take home pay not only being dissipated but also transferring itself into the Government's Consolidated Revenue. Of course, bracket creep hits hardest at ordinary Australians as their tax payments increase by much more than the rate of inflation and their after tax income falls in real terms. Naturally, as we know, bracket creep helps to produce lower living standards, higher inflation and more unemployment than would otherwise necessarily apply.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest tax cuts affect not only those on lower incomes but also those on higher incomes. The top earners-those who are in the top bracket-constitute 8.2 per cent of the total number of taxpayers. In 1986-87 they contributed $11.1 billion in tax, representing 31.6 per cent of total individual taxes paid that year. Taking into account the effects of bracket creep, it is more than likely that 11 per cent of all taxpayers will be in the top bracket by the end of this financial year. More than three-quarters of a million people will be paying a higher marginal tax rate than will Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and other major companies.

High marginal tax rates are affecting an increasing proportion of the work force. Over one million taxpayers will pay 52.5 per cent in tax in 1989-90. Unless action is taken the number will rise by 200,000 per year. Half the taxpayers already pay the marginal tax rate of 40 per cent and the number rises by 5 per cent of taxpayers each year. It is not only the very rich who are affected by high marginal tax rates-more than half of all taxpayers are affected.

The tragedy is that the tax cuts do not help to the extent that they appear to help. Under this Government there has been an enormous increase in taxation levels. This year its tax income is expected to rise by 9.9 per cent. Income tax collection from individuals is expected to rise by 13.6 per cent. I am certain that those projections are far too low, because the Government underestimated inflation levels and economic growth. Growth in GDP was anticipated to be 3.5 per cent, but it is now 5.4 per cent. Growth in average weekly earnings was expected to be 5.5 per cent but, in fact, it is closer to 7 per cent. The consumer price index was set at 4.5 per cent and at the end of 1988-89 it had reached 7 per cent. As I have said, there has been a significant increase in PAYE tax collections since the Government has been in office. In nominal terms there has been an increase of 87 per cent and in current terms an increase of 23 per cent. The gross increase in PAYE taxation since Labor has been in office is $16.5 billion.

When we contrast the levels of the tax cuts and the effects on the average Australian of housing interest rates, we see clearly that they do not provide a benefit. Let me give as an example the 16 per cent interest rate which we experienced some little time ago. As a result of the rate rising to 17 per cent, the average New South Wales mortgagor with a mortgage of $84,000 will pay over $270 a week in home loan repayments, representing an increase of $40 a week so far this year. If interest rates rise to 18 per cent later this year, as predicted, the repayment will be about $300 a week, representing a total rise of $70 a week since last June.

Recent home buyers who took out a loan at a lower interest rate either face a huge increase in their repayments or are required to extend the term of their loan to the point where they will never quite own their own home. A person with a $100,000 mortgage taken out at 13.5 per cent would pay $1,125 a month on the interest component alone. That would be well covered by the repayment of $1,166 a month. At 16 per cent the interest only cost rises to more than $1,330 a month, or about $160 a month more than the monthly repayment. So at the end of the year that person will have paid $14,000 in repayments but he will be $2,000 further behind. So the person who took out the loan at 13.5 per cent will move further away from owning his own home.

Let us consider the benefits that the weekly tax cuts and the family package will provide. A person on a single income of $35,000 with two children will receive a tax break of $25.65 a week. If that family has a mortgage of $40,000, the weekly repayment on that mortgage will increase by $25.15 as a result of the increase in interest rates from 13.5 per cent to 17 per cent. So the ordinary, average Australian person will receive a benefit of 50c a week as a result of the Government's indulgence in providing tax cuts.

I now turn to a couple of other matters. Firstly, the legislation proposes major measures relating to the taxation of superannuation. It will impose a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds, a further 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income, and a 16.25 per cent tax, which includes the Medicare levy, on lump sums of over $60,000.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the 15 per cent tax on fund income which I specifically seek to oppose, in view of its effect as a disincentive for people to enter into superannuation arrangements and thus provide for their own retirement. One of the great difficulties that the community as a whole is confronted with in relation to government retirement benefits and benefits generally is equity. Inevitably we have income tests for government paid pensions. But at the end of the day there is something to be argued for examining very carefully the gross income that a person has received over a number of years as distinct from his savings and income at that time, because there is no incentive to save.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the proposed amendments will be to reduce further the attractiveness of superannuation as an investment option. According to the superannuation funds, many of the thousands of Australians who recently joined superannuation funds will lose up to 10 per cent of their expected benefit. This is despite Mr Keating's claim in the May 1988 statement that the measures introduced would not reduce end benefits. The tragedy is that, at the very time when the Government should be doing everything in its power to encourage savings, it is introducing legislation which provides a disincentive for people to provide a saving for their retirement. In addition, the many changes to superannuation in recent years have created a climate of uncertainty and an environment where people feel dissatisfied with superannuation generally. To add to that, the rigidity of the incomes and assets test, which I referred to earlier, has forced many people off the age pension. Now, perhaps more than ever before, these people need access to superannuation and life savings if they are to make plans affecting their future with any certainty.

The real problem with this legislation is that the tax will fall heavily upon funds, such as approved deposit funds and roll-over funds, which do not have access to the same level of dividend imputation as is available in the superannuation schemes. It is the large superannuation schemes that will receive the benefit of dividend imputation, which is not available to these funds. Of course not everybody puts their money into superannuation schemes for life. Many people, when they change jobs, put their money into approved deposit funds and roll-over funds. Of course, as soon as one pulls one's money out of a superannuation fund, the full 15 per cent tax will apply. The Life Underwriters Association of Australia points out in what the amendments in this Bill will mean:
Superannuation will become an unattractive investment for the very people who most need an incentive to break away from the inevitability of a retirement on the pension.
The proposed taxation impost on fund earnings will result in effective rates of taxation nearing 40 per cent for those on lower marginal income tax rates.

I think that is a fair observation. An important point to consider in discussing retirement income is that Australia's current social welfare outlay is around 30 per cent of total Budget expenditure. Of course, that will get much worse in 10 or 20 years time, when we are likely to have at least 15 per cent of the population over the retirement age, compared to the present 8 per cent. Superannuation is the one form of saving which is specifically intended for retirement purposes. As such, it has considerable potential to reduce the demand on the Budget. If this Government were serious about reducing its Budget deficit, it would refrain from its short-sighted attacks upon self-funded retirement.

I wish to raise one other matter in the few minutes left to me, that is, the Government's commitment in October 1984, when it set out its nine-point tax review plan. When talking about the tax position, it said:
. . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily, and which therefore makes tax avoidance and evasion more difficult.

In other words, the criterion for the tax legislation and tax generally was simplicity. Let me remind the Senate of the contribution this Government has made to the Income Tax Assessment Act since it came to government in 1983. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, at its last reprint, runs to some 1,737 pages and contains 266 sections and 1,200 subsections. For those who wish to calculate it, these contain about one million words. On this basis alone one gets an indication of the complexity and the difficulty of interpretation that face not only unsuspecting taxpayers but also tax lawyers, accountants and Tax officers alike. The truth of the matter is that it is almost impossible to be interpreted by the ordinary person seeking to understand the level of taxation he or she should be paying.

The Act is almost impossible to read because we are faced with provisions numbered in the following terms-and I think these are good examples as they come from the investment in Australian films section-section 124zaga subsection (1) (a) (ii) and section 124zah subsection (1a) (c), both of which deal with deductions for capital expenditure for investment in Australian films under division 10ba. Surely that gives one an idea of the enormous difficulties the ordinary person never mind lawyers or accountants, has in interpreting the Act. Let me give a classic example from the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act. An ordinary employer, attempting to determine whether or not a food allowance he pays to an employee travelling away from home is a fringe benefit, turns for assistance to section 136, the interpretation section. It states that a `living-away-from-home food fringe benefit' is an `expense payment fringe benefit'. This latter term is defined in the same section. That employer turns to that definition and comes up with the very helpful bit of information that an `expense payment fringe benefit' means `a fringe benefit that is an expense payment benefit'. It is devastating in its clarity and certainty! That really would give comfort and succour to a poor soul reading the Act!

However, this mythical employer is persistent, so he looks at the definition of the `expense payment benefit' he has just read about. He then finds that this is in fact `a benefit referred to in section 20'. Section 20 contains another two internal definitions which basically state that, if an employer pays for something on behalf of an employee, the employer is taken to have provided a benefit to that employee. That is reasonably easy to understand. Finally, having divined this piece of information amongst the sections, the employer returns to his starting point, if of course he can remember what it was, to find that he has discovered the meaning of the first internal definition in the first line of a definition which then runs for six paragraphs.

I believe that gives an indication of the frivolity of seeking to find out what one's tax liability is. Yet in October 1984 we were told by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that one of the nine fundamental principles of this Government would be simplicity and certainty and a system which all Australians could understand more easily and which therefore would prevent avoidance. I have to say, with respect: if that is simplicity by definition from this Government, may the Lord help those of us less intelligent in seeking to work our way through Acts of the Parliament to find out what our responsibilities are in terms of certainty and consistency-two of the fundamental principles upon which the taxation law has previously stood. If we lose that certainty, we lose our ability to make judgments and our ability to pay the right amount of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it proper that before the vote is taken on these Bills I declare an interest in the matter on which the Senate is to vote. On 19 May 1989 I received an eligible termination payment from a superannuation fund following my resignation from my previous employment. I may or may not be personally affected by the legislation before the Senate. In any event, I believe that I will not be advantaged by it. I should like to indicate that my participation in the vote is not prohibited by Senate Standing Orders, and it is very unlikely that I would be prohibited from voting by the Standing Orders or rules of either the House of Representatives or the House of Commons. As a result, I do intend to participate in the vote on these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing that needs to be said about the package of superannuation and taxation Bills before the Senate is that its motivation is purely to sweep more revenue into the Government's tax coffers. It has nothing to do with equity or fairness, or with concern about our ageing population or about the vital need to increase private domestic savings. Superannuation is the major form of private savings in Australia. By discouraging people from going into superannuation-and that is what these Bills do-the Government is acting totally contrary to its own rhetoric and contrary to the national interest. Its rhetoric is to beat the drum and try to make us believe that it is taking action to encourage private savings. Nothing, however, could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: Prime Minister Hawke and Treasurer Keating, as a result of gross economic mismanagement, have already put this country into hock to the tune of nearly $130 billion. With these Bills the Government is mortgaging individual Australians' futures by tampering with their retirement superannuation incomes. These changes follow a pattern of enormous change to superannuation by the Government. If this legislation goes through, Australia will be one of the very few nations on earth to tax both part of the contributions to superannuation funds and the earnings of the funds themselves. Amongst other Western nations, Denmark certainly does; I am not sure that there are any others that do. It is proposed to levy a 15 per cent tax on the earnings of funds and on employer contributions. A 15 per cent tax on fund income and employer and self-employed contributions is equal to a tax rate of 38.8 per cent in 10 years time-that is, allowing for a very modest interest rate of 10 per cent.

The other interesting thing about this legislation is that, despite the fact that its motivation is purely to put more money into the Government's tax coffers, the changes, when viewed over the longer term, may actually increase the costs to the Government. This is due primarily to the fact that the yield earned by the superannuation funds is higher than the cost of the Government's borrowing. Hence a tax at retirement will generate more revenue in the long term than would a similar tax on contributions. So, in the longer term, it is very much a two-edged sword, so far as the Government's revenue base is concerned. It should be pointed out also that the reforms-the so-called reforms-incorporated in this legislation have not caused any greater integration between superannuation benefits and the age pension. Indeed, it could be argued that, with a lower lump sum tax at retirement, they have encouraged lump sums for most members. Until a form of integration between these two forms of retirement income is achieved, Australia will never have a rational, equitable and efficient system of providing retirement incomes.

In the taxation rip-off that is occurring through these Bills in the short term we are bringing forward tax of at least $1 billion. But that should come as no surprise to those Australians-and that is all of us-who have suffered at the hands of Labor's crushing taxes over the past six years. Since the Hawke Government came to office it has saddled the Australian community with a plethora of new and debilitating taxes. Indeed, during Labor's approximately 300 weeks in office no fewer than 300 changes have been made to increase tax. It is the ordinary workers who are footing these enormous tax hikes.

Let me run through just a few of the figures. In the first nine months of this financial year, for example, gross pay as you earn receipts are up by 16.9 per cent, against a Budget estimate of 13.8 per cent, and net pay as you earn receipts are up by 18.2 per cent. As a result of bracket creep, the community has been pushed into higher and higher income tax brackets over the last few years. An extra $10 billion-$10,000m-in tax has been paid as a result of that alone in the last four years. We see that in terms of the applications nowadays of the top marginal tax rate. Thirty years ago an income earner reached payment of the top marginal tax rate when his or her income was 18 times average weekly earnings; today a taxpayer reaches the top marginal tax rate when his or her income is less than twice average weekly earnings.

Paraded as the vehicle that would correct some of these imbalances, the April economic statement has, of course, turned out to be a complete furphy. In fact, the Government is giving back only half of that $10 billion tax creep windfall in tax cuts from July. The Australian Labor Party policy platform commits a Labor Government to `a fair and equitable taxation system'. What a sick joke that is. The reality is that Labor's crushing taxes now mean that a two-income family, with both husband and wife on respective average weekly earnings, would need at least an extra $71 a week to restore its real disposable income to the March 1983 level. With all of the resources at the disposal of the Department of Finance and the Treasury, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer have been challenged to refute our calculation that a person on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, will need an extra $56 a week to restore his or her disposable income to the March 1983 level. Significantly, they have failed completely to do so.

Small business, too, has suffered the down side of Labor's taxation policies. It, too, has been barraged with dozens of new taxes, rules and regulations. Again the figures tell the story. In the first nine months of this financial year sales tax receipts are up by 24 per cent, and receipts under the prescribed payments system are up by 38 per cent. Under Labor, sales tax has gone up by a huge 150 per cent-that is three times the increase in the inflation rate since Labor came to office, and more than double the increase in consumer expenditure. The 1987 Budget Papers stated that sales tax would rise by 14 per cent in 1987-88, but when the results came in they showed that it had gone up by 19 per cent. This followed rises of 10 per cent in 1986-87 and 15 per cent in 1985-86. This year the wholesale tax will raise a record $8,700m-an increase of nearly 15 per cent on last year. All up, this year these consumption taxes will raise a total of $21 billion.

When the Treasurer introduced, in the May 1988 economic statement, his proposals for changes to the taxation of the superannuation funds he said some truly heroic things. Let me quote a few of them. He said that as a result of these changes:
. . . the value of existing and future lump sums and pensions will not be reduced . . .
He said that the changes will:
not reduce the related end-benefits but will align the structure of superannuation taxation with other forms of savings.
He said-and this was the dolly of them all-that the changes:
. . . will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money-now lying in superannuation funds-without diminishing any personal end-benefit by one cent.
The Treasurer believed that these changes would disadvantage superannuants not one cent! To cap all that off, he said that as a result of these changes:
People can therefore plan for their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.

He omitted to tell the Australian community that in the Hawke Government's period of office there have been no fewer than 20 significant changes to superannuation arrangements and that the tax take from superannuation under the Hawke Government has gone up by 1,000 per cent-the tax take has gone up tenfold in the six years that this Government has been in office. There is no way that the changes incorporated in this legislation can be revenue neutral-no way at all. To argue that would be to argue that no-one will be disadvantaged in net terms as a result of the changes, and that is obviously quite wrong.

There are a number of difficulties arising from the measures in these Bills which were, quite patently, not properly considered by the Government. They seriously undermine any claims of revenue neutrality in terms of fund income. For example, there is a wide variety of reasons why superannuation funds do not hold a greater proportion of their assets in equities. Remember that the only funds that will not be paying any income tax are those that do not hold all their assets in equities of Australian companies which receive the full imputation tax credit on dividends. There are many funds that do not wish to hold all their assets in equities nor should they do so. The principal reason is that the value of shares is subject to wide and unpredictable fluctuations over time. The 1987 stock market crash showed that par excellence. It encouraged many funds to move more of their portfolios back into stable secure investments such as capital guaranteed bonds. Many of the superannuation funds which will be the subject of these new taxation measures have provided to their members a guarantee of the maintenance of the value of their capital. There is no way they can do that if they put all their funds into equities.

Again, for very legitimate reasons, many Australian companies have a lower effective rate than the nominal corporate rate. Therefore, their dividends are not fully franked. Companies such as Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, Pacific Dunlop Ltd, Brambles Industries Ltd, Elders-IXL and many others have a growing proportion of their operations in foreign countries. That is a very highly desirable development and one which is encouraged by virtually everyone in this country. But those overseas earnings are of course discounted for dividend franking purposes. Companies which do pay full or close to full tax rates include the three major private banks and most of the blue chip industrial companies such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Comalco Ltd and Jennings Industries Ltd. Competition for fully franked shares in companies such as those may well push up the value of stocks and create a catch 22 situation where the higher prices lead to lower yields. There is considerable doubt as to whether there are sufficient quality imputation stocks available in domestic companies to offset the tax on earnings. Some of the largest superannuation funds are already close to the 20 per cent shareholding limit and will therefore be unable to increase their holding in these companies without launching a full takeover bid.

I mentioned before capital guaranteed funds. They account for some $10 billion to $20 billion of superannuation savings. Those funds tend to include no equities or only very small amounts of equities in their investment portfolios, to minimise the risk of capital loss in the share market. Capital guaranteed funds of course aim to establish a stable and secure rate of earnings through fixed interest debentures and other forms of guaranteed returns. It has to be said at the outset and without any equivocation that the proposals in the Treasurer's tax package are not revenue neutral.

Perhaps as well as the concern with the details of these Bills, which of course is an ongoing and continuing concern, the Government is worthy of the strongest possible censure for the way it has handled this legislation. This is legislation by press release in an almost unprecedented way. It was certainly unprecedented prior to this Government coming to office. Increasingly over the last six years the Government has put out a press statement or made a statement that it will do something which will have very significant effects on the whole, or important sections, of the community. We then wait and wait and eventually the legislation comes forward.

The proposal for these changes to the taxation of superannuation funds, as I said, was announced in the May 1988 statement by the Treasurer. The new taxation arrangements were to start by 1 July 1988. So a statement was put out only five weeks in advance of the start of these fundamental tax changes. The superannuation fund managers had only that very limited period to attempt to get their act in order before the tax regime commenced on 1 July 1988. It then took six months before any legislation at all to give legal effect to these changes was introduced. That occurred in November 1988. We then had to wait a further five months before the rest of the package emerged. We are now debating that whole package. We are doing that almost one year after the Treasurer's announcements. In other words, there has been a delay of almost one year in the introduction of legislation to make legal the Government's May 1988 proposals.

Since the taxes started being collected on 1 July 1988, there has been no legal authorisation for their collection. Not only that the Bills are, at least in some respects, different from the May 1988 statement. To the extent that the legislation that we are now debating is different from the detail of the proposals announced by the Treasurer in May 1988, that then makes this legislation retrospective tax legislation. Time and again this House and this Parliament have expressed an abhorrence for retrospective tax legislation. It is perhaps the most abhorrent of all forms of legislation.

I said before that the Treasurer had said in his remarks that people can now plan for their retirement with complete certainty and confidence. I mentioned the numerous changes that have been made over the last few years. There is no guarantee at all-indeed, to the contrary-that these changes will be the last that will be seen from this Government. These 20 changes to superannuation proposals that have occurred in the life of this Government have made our superannuation system and laws the most complex system of occupational superannuation anywhere in the world. I doubt that anyone fully understands it. In fact, I was interested to see in the Australian Financial Review of 21 May that Mr Graham Carew, a former Assistant Commissioner of the Australian Taxation Office who assisted in the framing of the Government's legislation, told a seminar in Sydney:
. . . the new tax provisions were a minefield . . . (superannuation) has become too complicated and unwieldy.

What we are talking about here is something that goes to the heart of the feeling of well-being, confidence and comfort of all Australians in their ageing years. We are talking about something that is not just an economic matter; it is a very important social issue. It is one that people need to have confidence in and to understand. Here is one of the drafters of the legislation saying that superannuation has become too complicated and unwieldy. No wonder so many people in our community are feeling fear and concern for their futures.

I said earlier that the comment by the Treasurer that no-one would be disadvantaged by one cent was absolute bunkum. It is just not possible for that statement to be correct, for reasons that I have just outlined. In addition, the doubts about this legislation and what its real effects are going to be are mounting. I refer to an excellent article in the Bulletin of 16 May, just a couple of weeks ago, by Glenda Korporaal, where, under the heading `The doubts are mounting', amongst other things, she said:

Despite the promise by Treasurer Paul Keating that `no-one's end benefit would be reduced by one cent', it is hard to see how the decision to tax employers' contributions to super funds by 15% and the decision to tax super funds' investment income by 15% cannot reduce the final benefits of investing in superannuation.
She went on to say:

. . . Treasury's aim was purely to get its hands on the billions of dollars flowing into superannuation through union super funds and the greater awareness of the need to provide for retirement. The changes will reduce the cumulative amount at the end of an individual's working life which will be available to be taxed at the lower rate.

The fact is that a cent today is worth a lot more than the same one cent in 20 or 30 years after it has been eroded by inflation-which is why Treasury decided to take most of its share of the take up now rather than wait for the hereafter.

A professional analyst from one of the leading superannuation companies in Australia was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 29 May, earlier this week, as having found various quirks in the superannuation tax law. I quote the comments of Mr Ray Stevens, an actuary and superannuation consultant with Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight and certainly one of the leading specialists in this area in Australia, who at seminars around the country recently has been looking at the anti-detriment provisions of the law which are intended to ensure that no-one is worse off than before. I remind the Senate that the law says that where a person receives a benefit after age 55 and, as a result of contributions tax, would pay more tax under the new arrangements than under the previous tax regime, the person may receive a rebate for the excess tax. According to Mr Stevens, the anti-detriment provisions have serious limitations. They cannot take into account any loss resulting from the taxation of investment income. Only compensation for the 15 per cent contribution tax is intended. They apply only to lump sum benefits paid after age 55.

In determining whether any detriment has occurred, the unrealistic assumption must be made that the threshold for the old tax rates would always have remained at $55,000, whereas an indexed threshold starting at $60,000 is used for the new tax calculation. He also points out that it is up to the taxpayer to provide evidence to satisfy the Commissioner that detriment has occurred. It appears that the Commissioner will not initiate application of the provisions. If that is not so, then I hope that the Minister, in summing up at the end of this debate or in the committee stage, will clarify that situation, because it is a very important point indeed. It has also been pointed out by leading accountants, actuaries and tax experts that there are a number of quirks which need to be very closely watched by superannuation fund members if they are not to end up worse off than before. I commend to honourable senators the article in the Australian Financial Review of 29 May.

It is also a fact that the April 1989 economic statement has again taken the edge off superannuation as a form of investment. The recent April statement has made superannuation less attractive. When people are on a less than 30 per cent marginal tax rate, as will apply to incomes of less than $20,600 a year, the combined effect of these taxes will make other investment avenues more tax effective and more flexible. Again, that is a matter that was not taken into account, I am sure, when the May 1988 statement was made.

There are some very considerable concerns about this legislation. A great deal of pressure has been put on the coalition to reverse its announced decision to vote against the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). That is the Bill that will tax the income of formerly exempt superannuation funds and approved deposit funds at 15 per cent. That has in fact been occurring in practice since 1 July 1988. I believe that it would be quite wrong for the Liberal and National parties to let that legislation go through unchallenged. There are some major defects in that legislation which will have the effect of greatly disadvantaging many superannuants in this country. They will have the effect of discouraging savings, people will be less attracted to putting their savings into superannuation and, therefore, into superannuation funds, and the pool of private savings available in this country will be lessened as a result. The decline in private savings that we have seen in Australia in recent years is one of the prime reasons why we have the overwhelming economic problems we now have on our external account. Any measures that are taken which will have the effect of worsening the situation for private savings in this country are to be avoided unless there are overwhelming reasons for their introduction. There are not overwhelming reasons for the introduction of this legislation, particularly the tax on the income of superannuation funds. I urge the Senate in the strongest terms possible to reject this piece of legislation. Not only will it hurt every Australian superannuant but it will also hurt the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills we are discussing contains a variety of titles but it is loosely referred to as the superannuation package. It is a very significant package of Bills which will have an impact on the lives of a large number of Australians, perhaps not immediately but certainly in the years to come. I, too, like the previous speaker, Senator Short, cannot believe the assurance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that these Bills will not really affect anybody. That is really not credible.

SPEECH.PARA: The main features of the package are to impose a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds, to impose a 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income, and to impose a capital gains tax on assets bought and sold by superannuation funds after 1 July 1988. It is now 1 June 1989 and we are bringing in this legislation. I have never actually worked in this area but how on earth one conducts a business buying and selling, and so on, on that mere phrase `There will be a capital gains tax on assets bought and sold by funds after 1 July 1988' I do not know. It is an impossible situation.

The Government will impose a 16.25 per cent tax on lump sums over $60,000, which includes the Medicare levy. This was announced in the May economic statement of 1988. Part of it was announced in the statement of 12 April 1989, but no legislation was introduced into the Parliament until last November. Even then, only about half of it was introduced. We took the view that it was impossible enough trying to manage with a press statement announcement rather than legislation, but to be dealing with the legislation in parts was almost completely impossible. It was our view that we should have had the whole package before us before it was considered. We now have that and we are able to debate it. One of the reasons for that was that we felt we ought to be able to look at the whole range of changes that the Government was making to superannuation arrangements. There have been 20 changes since this Government was elected. How accountants, lawyers and financial advisers have managed to inform their clients and to give advice during this period is beyond me. It must have been a very difficult time indeed. I believe it still continues to be so. We cannot be certain that these will be the last changes the Government will make in the area of superannuation. There has been so much done to date but, hopefully, there will be some stability and it will not change the rules again.

There are 3.6 million Australians who belong to superannuation schemes, 325,000 being compulsory members, as are Commonwealth employees. When about 63 per cent of those compulsory members retire they receive only a very low amount from the superannuation scheme. They receive the balance of their income by way of age pension. They are in a particularly difficult situation. We only need to talk to them to find out how financially disadvantaged they are. We can have two retirees living next door to each other, one receiving all the benefits of a full age pension, having never contributed to a superannuation scheme and therefore not getting anything out of one, and next door a former Commonwealth employee who gets part Commonwealth superannuation, which he cannot surrender because he is forced to take it, and a part pension, but who receives none of the benefits. The latter is badly off indeed. He never seems to get any consideration or any benefits. When we look at pension entitlements and benefits, it is time we gave far more consideration to Commonwealth employees in that situation. These two retirees might go off to bowls together, one with the full pension and his bus pass, which enables him to travel, and the other without. There are so many areas to be looked at. While the actual fortnightly income of the full pension against superannuation and the part pension may appear to be the same, the difference in the spending capacity is enormous. It is an area that nobody ever seems to think about but it is certainly significant for those who are trying to live on the scheme that I referred to.

These days much more attention is being paid to the provision of secure retirement income. That is rightly so, as the population is ageing. The inadequacy of government pensions is something that is referred to frequently but it is unlikely that the economy can go on providing support to an ageing pensioner population unless something is done to encourage people to take more care for their own security. It is worth looking at some of the statistics.

The Australian Institute of Family Studies puts it into perspective when it tells us that over the next 35 years the number of elderly people in Australia will grow at twice the rate of the population as a whole. The fastest growing segment of the population will be those aged over 85 years. By the year 2021 there will be three times as many people over the age of 85 as there are today. Life expectancy at birth has increased dramatically over the past 100 years. For males it has increased from 47 then to 73 now, and for females it has increased from 51 to 79. The labour force participation rates for males over the age of 65 has declined from 23.3 per cent to 9.4 per cent since 1966. That has been a dramatic change in the percentage who are contributing and are productive. It must have made an enormous impact on the economy.

There is a tendency towards earlier retirement. My view would be that rather than force people out of work at 65 we should be adopting policies which would encourage them to remain productive for as long as possible. We adjust the superannuation schemes and retirement policies to fit in with that; and make it attractive for people to give up work at 55, a much younger age. The whole attitude does not make sense to me.

In 1986 there were 221,700 men aged 55 to 64, too young for the age pension, in receipt of Commonwealth income support. Since 1975 numbers of men in that group receiving unemployment benefits increased by 275 per cent, sickness benefits by 217 per cent, service pension by 182 per cent and the invalid pension by 116 per cent. If we do not take a very close look at those statistics and draw some very hard conclusions from them, we are going to make life more and more difficult for the younger group in the community-the taxpaying public. These are statistics that warrant debate on their own for the implication they have. They indicate to me that we have a large number of people in the community with not a great deal to do who are probably feeling that they are not productive and generally costing more in sickness benefits and other things than would actually be necessary if they were able to lead a different life. To be aged 55, feeling that no-one really wants them and that they do not have a chance of getting a job is very serious, especially when we look back to the increase in the life expectancy figures that I referred to a moment ago. These are men who for 10 years prior to eligibility for an age pension have been reliant in one way or another on the Commonwealth for income support.

The number of age pensioners per 1,000 population, or per 1,000 of the labour force, and age pension outlays as a proportion of the gross domestic product, is at the lowest point for over a decade. Of those people retired from full time work in 1986 aged 45 years and over, 8.6 per cent had superannuation, life assurance or similar schemes, and 11.5 per cent had investments as their main source of income. Three-quarters of the 361,000 people included in the Australian Bureau of Statistics Superannuation Australia Survey in 1983 who had received lump sum payments had in fact received less than $20,000. Thirty-six per cent had received less than $5,000, 20 per cent between $5,000 and $10,000 and 18 per cent between $10,000 and $20,000. Three-quarters of the women had received less than $10,000 and only 8.5 per cent received $20,000 or more. One cannot do a great deal to provide for oneself with those sums of money.

These are very revealing statistics and they should reinforce a number of things: the burden of supporting a mushrooming ageing population cannot continue to be borne by taxpayers; individuals need to be encouraged to make provision for their own income security beyond their working lives-and clearly at present that is not occurring on as large a scale as it ought to be and needs to be; and in order to encourage individuals to provide for their retirement, it would be at least useful-and I think essential-if the Government offered some incentive to people to provide for their own retirement, or at the very least refrained from putting up disincentives for people to make such arrangements for their future. But if we are to encourage people to save through the mechanism of superannuation one would expect there to be a steady, consistent regime whereby the end benefits would not be jeopardised by constant changing of the rules, which I say has been happening up until now.

The Government cannot ignore the fact that these changes-including those in this latest package-create doubts in the minds of those who are in superannuation schemes, and those contemplating taking up superannuation, about whether in 10, 20 or 30 years from now the scheme will in fact deliver them for their retirement what they expect it to deliver. As a consequence, of course, they have doubts about whether they should embark upon providing for themselves or not. Last year when this package was announced a number of comments were made about it that reinforced that view. I refer particularly to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser by Malcolm Newell. It commenced by saying:
Confronting another quagmire of superannuation tax changes is a nightmare.
The article continued:

The Treasurer Keating's words, `together these changes complete the Government's review of superannuation taxation arrangements. People can therefore plan for their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.'
Can any government, in all seriousness and in the context of recent years, sustain public credibility by making such a claim?

Other comments of a similar nature were made in other media and industry publications. They all reinforced the need for certainty when planning long term superannuation. It is important to encourage people to embark upon it at an early age. Unless there is credibility, they will not do so; they will be frightened to do so and will not bother to spend the money on it at that time. We need schemes that will be seen to be effective for a period of up to 30 years before people receive moneys from them. The Government cannot expect people to choose this course and enter into a scheme when their retirement is decades away and when there is as much uncertainty as there is at present. I believe that this Government has contributed significantly to the climate of uncertainty as far as superannuation is concerned, and that is most regrettable indeed.

In most cases where changes have occurred-indeed, in the case of these Bills-the motivation of the Government has had nothing to do with the security that people ought to be able to find in their superannuation schemes; rather the motivation has been merely the revenue from taxation-money grabbing. We know this Government is a high taxing government. We have come to live with that. But this package is the latest of its money grabbing schemes, and the uncertainty it has created in the industry is, I think, most regrettable indeed. The changes have not been initiated to encourage additional participation. I refer to a letter which I know has been referred to previously in this debate, written by the Life Underwriters Association of Australia. I suspect it was written to all senators. It said that the Association remains `deeply concerned over the potential impact of the proposed taxation arrangements outlined in this Bill on the attractiveness of superannuation as an investment option'. The letter went on to indicate that the Association believes the Government is actively discriminating against superannuation investment based savings. I think the Government ought to listen to the advice of a group such as that which is so heavily involved in this industry. I think it is incredible that the Government takes such a short-sighted view of providing for an ageing population. Everybody knows that the statistics indicate that the population is ageing and will continue to age, and that the proportion of pay as you earn taxpayers will fall in relation to the number of people who may otherwise be looking for age support, or age pensions, if they are not able to provide for themselves.

Many of the institutions which deal with superannuation have indicated that they would welcome changes-they are not saying there should not be changes-but they think that such changes should lead to greater participation in the superannuation schemes and should not merely produce revenue for the Government while discouraging people from being in them. The recent National Australia Bank Quarterly Summary said that changes to the superannuation and taxation systems are vital if we are to provide for our ageing population. It predicted that outlays for age pensions would rise from 2.8 per cent of the gross domestic product in 1985 to nearly 4.5 per cent by the year 2025. That is a dramatic increase. It described participation by Australian workers in superannuation schemes as poor compared with other countries. Only 28.3 per cent of women in the work force are in schemes compared with 50.9 per cent of men. But the legislation we are looking at now will not encourage women to embark on superannuation schemes for themselves.

The National Australia Bank called for new schemes to be developed which were specifically attractive to women to enable them to contribute to superannuation while they are in the work force. It also called for enhanced incentives for young people, such as vesting and portability, to correct the situation of nearly 60 per cent of people with no superannuation being under the age of 35. As the law is at present, I cannot imagine how one could go about persuading people under the age of 35 to embark on a superannuation scheme when in fact they should be better off in the long run the earlier they do so. To me, the philosophy of this is quite wrong. Young people are those most at risk. By the time they reach retirement age the pension as we know it today may not be available to them.

There are those, as I said, who wish to see changes, but they wish to see changes for the better. While the Government seems determined to use this measure as a means of revenue raising and creates uncertainty and reluctance in the minds of those who belong to a scheme or are thinking about going into a scheme-causing people to feel that their superannuation, after the many years of paying into it, may not in fact meet their needs in their retirement-the situation will only get worse.

This legislation is not the way to encourage people to provide for their retirement. I believe that the Government must know that. I cannot imagine why it cannot devise a scheme that would encourage people to provide for themselves. I hope that if we see any more changes to superannuation they will be changes for the better that will encourage people to be in schemes. I certainly hope, for the sake of lawyers, accountants and those involved in this industry, that there will not be any further changes, because if there are the nightmare they have suffered so far will only become worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of taxation Bills before the Senate relates to a number of changes which the Government proposed in its May 1988 and April 1989 economic statements in relation to superannuation laws. The main features of this legislative package are a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds, a 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income, a 16.25 per cent tax on lump sums over $60,000 and a capital gains tax on assets bought and sold by superannuation funds after 1 July. These changes are just further discouraging Australians to save at a time when we are taking another step down the Argentine road. Our foreign debt, which is over $100 billion, is a fair indication of that. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has taken one more step towards his famous Paris option-that option of selling one's antique clocks and leaving the country to live in Paris. That was a well-mooted option, a well-known joke around the Cabinet. One media commentator, Paul Lyneham of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, asked the Treasurer before he left, `Are you coming back?'. He took a couple of seconds to answer. I am not sure whether he gave the right answer, but he gave the impression to Australians that he was coming back. I wish he would hurry back and fix up the mess.
—He does a fair amount of damage when he is here.

—Senator Haines is quite right. I am a bit worried by the number of times I find myself agreeing with the Australian Democrats, at least today. Senator Haines makes the clear point that when the Treasurer does come back he will do some damage. Perhaps he should stay there. It really does not matter any more. The whole economic system is so far out of hand that he cannot take hold of the levers.

SPEECH.PARA: Encouraging Australians to invest in a superannuation scheme is of the utmost importance in these bleak economic times. Superannuation is the only real form of savings for the great majority of Australians that is designed specifically to provide income for people in their retirement. It plays a role in the welfare of those who enter retirement as well as reducing the very heavy costs of government provided welfare. Nobody should underestimate the desire of Australians to have a secure income, a nest egg in their retirement, and their preference for their own scheme rather than a government provided welfare scheme in their retirement. It gives the elderly both financial and psychological security, and that is of the utmost importance as people enter their later years. Given the right incentives, most would retire from the work force. As I said, they would rather have their own security than being dependent upon a government welfare system. The Bills before the Senate do not improve that prospect one iota.

Contrary to the Treasurer's commitment that no-one's end benefit will reduce by one cent, the Government has heightened the risk of returns to superannuation funds. That is the real essence of the Bills before the Senate this evening. The critical element in the package before the Senate is the ability to offset the new 15 per cent tax on fund earnings by use of fully franked dividends. The Treasurer's claim of revenue neutrality in these changes is based upon the proposition that the superannuation funds will start to flow to what he called the quality end of the Australian share market. Quite frankly, the Treasurer fails to understand the market system. In fact, it has been a gross failing on the part of the Treasurer for some time. He has no grasp of market reality and all it is made up of: its drive, its risks, its psyche, its knowledge and its limits. He has no understanding of the market.

There are many reasons why the superannuation funds will not suddenly flow into the so-called quality end of the share market to take advantage of the tax credits. Risk and security are the prime reasons. Since the 1987 crash many funds have moved more of their portfolios away from the share market and back into secure investments such as guaranteed bonds. Most capital guaranteed funds, approved deposits or roll-over funds, which account for as much as $10 billion to $20 billion of superannuation savings, tend to include no equities, no shares, or at least a very minimal amount, for the simple reason of minimising the possibility of being wiped out in a share market crash. That is always possible under this Government's economic strategy. These types of funds aim to achieve a stable and secure rate of earnings through fixed interest debentures and other forms of guaranteed returns. Is the Treasurer suggesting that Australians forgo their retirement security-something that is very important to them-and start a rush on the share market just to get some tax credit? Quite frankly, the risk of entering the share market outweighs the benefit of the tax credit. That is something the Government must understand and come to grips with. It makes false the claim that nobody will be worse off under this superannuation package.

The coalition proposes amendments to address the situation. One amendment will effectively excise that 15 per cent tax on investment funds so as to ensure that the end benefits of millions of superannuants will not be reduced and to ensure that superannuation remains a viable savings alternative for retirement. Another amendment is designed to ensure that supernnuation remains a viable savings alternative for retirement. That amendment would increase the present tax free limit on lump sums from $60,000 to $125,000. That is part of coalition policy. The coalition policy would index that $125,000 limit. That policy is related to our retirement incomes policy. I recommend that the Government read the coalition's policy. Perhaps it could come to grips with one itself-one that is worthy of the respect of elderly Australians.

Superannuation is very important to Australians for two reasons: first, as I said, to provide for the welfare of older Australians in their retirement years and, secondly, because superannuation is a significant contribution to the macro-economic need for increased private savings. Superannuation, coupled with the pension system for the needy, forms a national retirement incomes policy. That is something which the Opposition, unlike the Government, as I said, has carefully prepared and published. The issue of financing the future welfare of Australians in retirement is becoming increasingly crucial to the nation as the age distribution of our population becomes older.

The ageing of Australia's population is shown by the changing relative proportions of different age groups in the population. The trend in recent years has been for the 45 years and older age group to increase as a proportion of the population. In 1987 there were 1.7 million Australians over the age of 65. By the year 2011 this figure will have risen to three million. At the same time, the proportion of the young-that is, up to 14 years-will decline significantly because of the declining birth rate. To highlight that statistic, I refer to the fact that the immigration contribution to total population growth in this country outweighs the natural increase contribution. I refer also to the increasing life expectancy due to advances in modern medicine, as well as the greater level of health consciousness in the community. These trends of a lower natural increase and higher life expectancy together mean that in the future there will be proportionately fewer and fewer taxpayers in the prime of their working lives and income producing potential and more and more retired people. The old age dependency ratio is expected to double in the next five decades.

This increase in the ratio of retired people to working people has a clear message: the public purse can no longer be expected to finance the retirement of all. The Economic Planning Advisory Council has estimated that if pension rates increase in line with general living standards age pension outlays will increase by 50 per cent and, as a percentage of gross domestic product, from 2.5 per cent to 4.5 per cent by the year 2025. So we can no longer maintain a system of financing current pensions from taxation revenue alone. That imbalance between those working and those retired will become far too great. The imbalance underlines that encouraging superannuation-people saving for their own retirement-is absolutely essential now.

Increased superannuation is just as essential to meet an equally urgent need-the need to increase private savings, particularly by households, to arrest the foreign debt explosion arising from Labor's economic mismanagement. Australia's private savings are not only low; they are falling. Household savings have fallen from 15 per cent of disposable income in 1975 to 8 per cent today. Australia must borrow because national savings are inadequate to finance national investment. The importance of encouraging a greater savings level in Australia can no longer be ignored by the Government. It is, in fact, the most vital economic lever to steer Australia out of its pending economic collapse. It is the lever that the Government has yet to pull.

The major crisis facing Australia today is the ever increasing foreign debt, now standing at over $100 billion net and fuelled each month by the billion dollar-plus current account deficits. As has been said many times in this House, the foreign debt has quadrupled under the present Government. When the Hawke Government first came into office it was $32 billion; it is now $120 billion. That represents an increase of $1m every 1.5 hours. Seventy-five per cent of that debt has a maturity of less than three months-90 days. The short average maturity means that the economy is not liquid: it is vulnerable to a liquidity crisis. Indeed, we are heading into a liquidity crisis with interest rates alone to meet that debt burden at $12 billion, which is about $1 billion per month, the greater part of the monthly current account deficit. We are reaching the stage that Italy faced in the 1970s-borrowing to meet interest payments; interest on interest.

The payment of interest on foreign debt is now the largest single component of the current account deficit. This problem has been a major contributor to Australia's record high current account deficit and record high interest rates. Interest rates are higher because funds must be attracted from overseas to plug the gap of the savings shortfall in this country. Foreign investors have reacted to a widening current account deficit and rising foreign debt by demanding higher interest rates. Enter Moody's Investor Services Inc. Higher interest rates are demanded by foreign investors to cover what they perceive to be a greater and greater risk that Australia will not be able to sustain the servicing of the foreign debt.

Australia has become trapped in a vicious cycle of higher interest rates, a widening current account deficit and a rising foreign debt, which in turn leads to higher interest rates. The only way to break up this cycle is to increase domestic savings. That is why increased savings via superannuation or incentive by way of tax incentive for interest on domestic savings is utterly vital. Increased savings would mean lower consumption and a lower demand for imports, which would lead to less and less pressure on the current account front. Increased savings would also increase the supply of loanable funds for industry, local business and housing, thereby lowering domestic interest rates from their current crippling levels.

Superannuation as a major part of the savings mix has the virtue of providing long term savings that can be invested long term to business to the benefit of the economy and society. In other words, because superannuation represents savings not to be drawn upon until retirement, many decades after the initial contributions have been made, superannuation is a pool of savings that can be invested long term. If the economy is to ride out the current account crisis and to invest, to restructure in the long term, superannuation must be encouraged as part of a national effort to boost savings.
