PROCTEXT.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my speech in the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats intend to move amendments to this clause with regard to those people who have rolled over their lump sums into fixed interest investments-that is, those people who will not get any benefit at all from the Government's allowance of imputation to run back the 15 per cent earnings tax to a lesser percentage. I said during my speech that we were concerned that some very ordinary wage earners who had retired at 55 or 60 years of age on small superannuation pay-outs would be disadvantaged by this legislation, notwithstanding the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had indicated that no-one would be 1c worse off under this legislation. Indeed, a large group of people will be hurt.

SPEECH.PARA: The 15 per cent tax on the investment earnings of superannuation roll-over funds is a maximum. It can be reduced by those companies which spread their investments into the share market. Those people who retired early on small superannuation payments, however, still remember October 1987; they still remember the fact that the share market got a significant jolt and that there was a ripple effect through to other financial areas. We certainly support the Government's aim of encouraging the big life and superannuation funds to invest in Australian companies, if they are going to invest in companies at all, rather than taking their money offshore. Using imputation as a way of reducing the 15 per cent tax on earnings is one way of getting those people to invest in Australian companies. But overriding that is our concern that some people are going to be significantly worse off.

As I said during my speech in the second reading debate, we have been contacted by a number of constituents. I cited one who retired at the age of 60, after something like 40 years in the work force. He rolled over his $50,000 superannuation payment into an interest earning type of roll-over fund. He chose this fund deliberately, he said, because he wanted to put his money in a low risk investment. He knew he had to take the money out of the fund at age 65, so he set out to avoid roll-over funds which invested a high proportion of their assets in property and shares which could reduce in value over that five-year period. He wanted a secure investment. He was not even prepared to go as far as putting his money into capital guaranteed funds, because he either guessed or knew that some of those have quite a commitment in the share market-in some cases up to 40 per cent.

He then calculated that under the new legislation, because his approved deposit fund will pay the full 15 per cent tax on its interest earnings, he would lose some $4,000 over the five years that the money is in the fund. He has some options, of course. He can leave it there and lose that money or he can take it out of that fund and move it into a capital guaranteed fund. But if he does the latter he will have to pay up-front fees and/or higher management fees, perhaps something of the order of 5 to 6 per cent of his money. As I said, he is concerned about moving it to capital guaranteed funds because of their investment in shares and their higher risk.

If this legislation goes through unamended, this man and others like him-and some women, although still very few women have access to superannuation-will lose thousands of dollars over the next five years. People who have retired at 55 and who have acted similarly with the intention of withdrawing their money at 65 will lose even more if the legislation is unamended. For that reason, we want some alterations to the legislation. The Government cannot argue that it has been caught short on this one. We spoke to it last July about this; we have spoken to it on an almost monthly basis ever since. We have asked for assistance from the parliamentary draftspeople so that we can get amendments drafted that will satisfy the Government. Nothing has eventuated; so we have had our own amendments drafted, partly to make the Treasurer keep his word but more importantly to protect those people who could lose thousands of dollars because of these changes-changes made after they had taken the decision to invest in safe roll-over funds. Our amendments 1 and 2, which are connected amendments, will seek to assist people who have put their money into secure funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you seek leave to move those two amendments together?
—I think it would save everybody a lot of time and save me making a second speech on the same issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 15, clause 9, proposed subsection 278 (1), line 3, leave out ``The trustee'', insert ``Subject to subsection (3), the trustee''.
(2) Page 15, clause 9, proposed subsection 278 (2) add the following new subclauses:
(2) ``(3) Subsection (1) does not apply to income of a fund where 90% of the assets of the fund are in interest earning investments.

If this attempt by the Australian Democrats to provide quarantining for people in those two sorts of funds fails-that is, if it is opposed by both the Government and the Opposition-we will have no alternative but to oppose the earnings tax outright; that is, to support the Opposition amendment that will delete that part of the legislation which imposes a 15 per cent tax on earnings in these and other funds. Of course, that applies not only to our first two amendments but also to those which follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said at the end of the second reading debate, none of the amendments are acceptable to the Government. Senator Haines will move six amendments in all. Nos 1 and 2, Nos 3 and 4, and Nos 5 and 6 apply, I think, to superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts which have 90 per cent or more of their investments earning fixed interest. They do not apply to the superannuation business of life assurance companies or registered organisations, including friendly societies.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Opposition's amendments have not been moved yet, it would be appropriate for me at this stage to make some comments about them as well and on the way in which they differ from the Australian Democrats' amendments. The Opposition amendments are to abolish the tax on fund earnings. But they do not apply to the superannuation business of life offices or of pooled superannuation trusts. So the amendments to be moved by the Opposition and those already moved by the Democrats are defective in that, even if one conceded that the objectives in either case were valid-which the Government does not; it firmly rejects that assertion-they are selective in the area to which they have been applied, or to which it is sought that they apply. The Opposition's amendments are more selective, that is, embracing a narrower range of the whole field, than the Democrats' amendments-but none of them embrace the whole field. The Democrats' amendments would be most generous to banks, because most fixed interest funds are in fact approved deposit funds run predominantly by banks. I think it is somewhat incongruous, with the criticisms that the Democrats have been making over some time of banks and their allegedly high profits, to be bringing in an amendment which would selectively-although, as I said, less selectively than the Opposition's-advantage banks.

Most superannuation funds, moreover, have substantially less than 90 per cent of their assets in fixed interest securities, which is true even for the so-called capital guaranteed funds. Those that have not, of course, have the option of increasing the amount of equities and therefore of franked dividend income which they receive. Giving tax preference to a particular segment of the superannuation industry, as both the Opposition's amendments and the Democrats' amendments would do, would encourage other parts of the industry to restructure so as to obtain the tax preference. For example, a fund with, say, 80 per cent of its assets in fixed interest securities would almost certainly do better under the Democrats' amendments if it sold off some of its shares and acquired additional interest bearing assets.

It appears that neither the Opposition nor the Democrats have considered what effect that could be expected to have on the domestic share market, although I understand they have been inundated with stockbrokers' views on that subject. Moreover, there is of course a cost to revenue. Most importantly of all, all of the Democrats' amendments and the proposed Opposition amendments act against the fundamental rationale of the changes that the Government is seeking to make, that is, to remove the bias in the existing system in favour of debt rather than equity.

The Opposition's amendments, of course, go very much further, since they propose to abolish the tax absolutely for all but pooled funds and the superannuation business of life offices. Therefore, they would be far more damaging to the underlying objective of the Government's policy than the Democrats' amendments. Both parties' amendments are unacceptable for the reasons I have given. I will make some more detailed comments about the Opposition's amendments at the time they are moved. I have made the comments I have up to now because there are some similarities between both lots of amendments which would have an effect unacceptable to the Government and, of course, which are in both cases selective and, I suppose, internally inconsistent in the sense that they do not extend what the Opposition or the Democrats might see to be a good idea to all the players in the field.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 15, clause 9, proposed section 281, lines 30 and 32, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:
`` `281. Subject to section 275, the assessable income of a complying superannuation fund of a year of income shall comprise only taxable contributions made to the fund in a year of income.'.''.
(2) Page 17, clause 9, proposed section 290, lines 13 to 15, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:
`` `290. Subject to section 275, the assessable income of a complying ADF of a year of income shall comprise only the taxable contributions made to the fund in a year of income.'.''.

In moving these amendments to clause 9, the Opposition is proposing that the 15 per cent tax on investment income be excised. We did not support the Democrats' amendments because they did not go far enough and because their nature was such that they would have made the legislation fraught with technical difficulties and definition problems. But the overriding thrust, very simply, was that they did not go far enough effectively to excise the whole of the 15 per cent investment tax in the hands of the fund.

In the second reading debate, I and other senators made the point very strongly that we consider this tax to be a disincentive to savings. We have said also that it is a discriminatory tax in that it purports to allow certain types of funds to make investments in equities on the stock market to take advantage of imputed dividends to lower their rate of tax, whereas the approved deposit funds and the roll-over funds would not have access to that lowering of tax because approximately only 25 per cent of investment of total funds of that nature would be in the equities market. The reason for that is very simple: the people who are using those funds are seeking secure fixed interest investments or capital guaranteed investments.

Senator Walsh, in replying to the debate on the Democrats' amendments, and in foreshadowing remarks that he will make about our amendments, talked about there being a cost to the revenue. I think we have made the point very clearly that the cost to the revenue is probably only between $20m and $120m, depending on the decision that various fund managers would choose to make in their investment portfolios. At this stage it is not possible to be more precise, but we know that that part of the superannuation market which comprises approved deposit funds and roll-over funds is in the vicinity of $12 billion. So in this package of Bills there is ample room for the Government to forgo this particular slice of the revenue because the total package will afford to it, in toto, $1.4 billion, of which it is losing only something between $20m and $120m.

At the time the May statement was brought down, the Treasurer gave a commitment that no end benefit to any superannuant would be diminished by 1c. That is clearly not the case. In the second reading debate I gave a particular example of somebody who had taken early retirement and received a payment of $100,000. For the purposes of making it a more simple proposition, let us take a simple sum of $1,000 that an employer has contributed to a superannuation fund for an employee in this financial year. The employee, who is under 55 years of age, leaves the employment and becomes entitled to the benefit. The following would be the total tax package under the proposals. There would be 15 per cent in the fund, plus 27 per cent as an eligible termination payment when the benefit was paid to the employee. Thus, a total of 42 per cent would be paid under the proposed scheme, whereas under the existing tax regime the total tax payable would be only 37 per cent on the eligible termination payment.

Further complications arise out of these packages but, as I have said, the Opposition's main concern is about this particular tax, which we say is a disincentive to savings. Earlier I pointed out, too, that it had a public administration implication. I referred to States of Australia which had decided to fund their superannuation schemes. They were avoiding putting future generations into hock by setting aside the money for the superannuation payments within this generation-a sensible practice. Because of this particular tax a majority of those States that intended to fund their superannuation schemes have now declined to do so. Indeed, the Queensland Government has actually enacted legislation to ensure that the 15 per cent tax on its superannuation funds will not be paid to Canberra. I think that the Queensland Government is demonstrating that it is doubly incensed at having its general purpose grants cut by the Federal Government at the Premiers Conference, and that it is not prepared to give even more hard earned money to the Federal Government.

Earlier I made the point that such disparate people as Garry Weaven of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and Professor Michael Porter had said that the proposed tax was a disincentive. Professor Porter said:
. . . the present taxation of superannuation and means testing of the government pension significantly penalises many Australians saving for their own retirement relative to spending income today.
Mr Weaven said:
The fact is that to get people to prefer a future lump sum or income stream to current cash in hand requires a very major incentive.
Speculation and uncertainty about future government policy in the area only increases the preference for current cash rather than preserved savings.

Clearly that, together with industry views which have come to the surface in the latter days of this debate-industry, too, acknowledges that the tax is a disincentive-should convince the Government, if it were of a mind to be reasonable and to judge the situation fairly 12 months after the May statement was brought down in 1988 by way of press release, that circumstances have perhaps changed, that there is a desperate necessity to have policies which encourage savings and do not discourage them.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated a little while ago, with the defeat of our attempt to quarantine simply the fixed interest funds, we will be supporting the Opposition attempt to remove the 15 per cent earnings tax absolutely. It somehow slipped past me, when I was moving back to my place after the previous division, that Senator Bishop was moving her amendments to proposed section 281, which came after my first two amendments, and to proposed section 290. I know that the honourable senator sought leave and that leave was granted. However, this means that my amendments to proposed section 289 slid past. I am not going back to them-for the simple reason that they attempted to do to approved deposit funds and to pooled superannuation trusts the same sort of thing as our first two amendments would have done to another group of fixed interest funds. I would just like it on the record that we are not proceeding with our amendments 3 and 4 and 5 and 6 as two groups because they will meet the same fate as amendments 1 and 2 and because we are now supporting Senator Bishop's-that is, the Opposition's-amendments that slotted neatly in between all of those. Just to get over that confusion, the Democrats are supporting the Opposition's two amendments. We will not be proceeding with the rest of ours.
—I understand your position. There will be no procedural difficulty about moving the amendments if you wish to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's proposal is to abolish the 15 per cent tax on the earnings of most funds. It would not apply to the superannuation business of life offices-they would continue to be subject to the 15 per cent tax-or pooled superannuation trusts. So, technically, it is very defective. It is difficult to believe that the Opposition is actually serious about this. I personally believe that to be the case. The Opposition believed it would be a good stunt to pull but, having done that, it has been hoist with its own petard and it believes it has to proceed with it. It is very difficult to believe that the Opposition is serious.

SPEECH.PARA: The 15 per cent tax on the earnings can be, providing a fund has the correct investment mix, offset or more than offset by the imputation of credit from franked dividends. It is part of an indivisible package. If this part of the Government's total legislation on superannuation funds were knocked out, the rest of it really would not be defensible and would not proceed. I would not go so far as to say that it would make the whole imputation system indefensible, but it would very seriously flaw the imputation system to the point where the Government, should these amendments actually be put into the legislation, might even have to look at the legislation again.

The essential purpose of the whole superannuation package, of which this Bill is a vital part, is to remove the bias which exists under the present arrangements for debt financing rather than equity financing. I am astounded that, on this issue, the Australian Democrats, who have for many years been lecturing the Senate and others on the alleged evils of debt financing as compared with equity financing, are in this instance contemplating voting for a proposition which unambiguously favours debt financing over equity financing and which will cause, without any doubt, should it be adopted, a continuing distortion and a growing problem in that way.

The Opposition's amendments are difficult to understand for other reasons as well. They are clearly inconsistent with the Opposition's retirement income policy, launched only last November, which stated that the Opposition would:
Continue to provide company tax imputation credits to superannuation funds on franked dividends.

It is a repudiation of that policy if the Opposition proceeds with these amendments. Several representatives of the superannuation industry have stated publicly that, in practice, the tax will have no effect on the investment earnings of most superannuation funds. Those upon which it will have some effect can rearrange their investment portfolio in favour of equity rather than interest bearing securities. In some cases, superannuation funds expect to have excess imputation of credits, which they can use to offset the tax on contributions. The net result is significantly improved end benefits for those investing in major superannuation funds.

For other funds, including many approved deposit funds, the earnings tax either will be minimal or could be readily reduced by an adjustment to their investment portfolios-not only by adjustments to shift the portfolio in favour of investment in shares but also by investments in assets which provide a return in the form of capital gain-property obviously being one. Moreover, in those cases where some net earnings tax would be payable, it does not follow that after tax end benefits would be lower. The reason for that is that the reduction of the tax on end benefits intentionally exceeds that which is necessary to offset the new tax on deductable contributions.

In conclusion, I stress again that these amendments are absolutely unacceptable to the Government. If the Opposition persists with them, the whole superannuation package, including the reduction of the lump sum tax, falls to the ground. It is an indivisible package. This Bill is an essential component of that package. Under no circumstances will the Government consider allowing this amendment to pass but still proceed with the package. I say again that I really am astounded that the Democrats, who have been, if one takes their remarks seriously and at face value, very strongly committed to equity financing instead of debt financing, could even contemplate supporting this amendment which restores the bias in favour of debt financing and, on the way through, destroys the rationale for the whole imputation of credit policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly take the point made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) about debt versus equity financing. I indicated during the second reading debate and again a little while ago that it gives me no joy to support the Opposition's amendment. I certainly would prefer not to support the removal of the earnings tax absolutely. But the fact is that we also have to concern ourselves with those people who are vulnerable, who made a conscious decision to invest in a secure fund which now looks like leading to their losing about $3,000 or $4,000 over the next five years, through no fault of their own, except an excess of caution.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is quite right. It is disappointing that we have to go against our traditional attitude to the relative merits of debt and equity financing in this piece of legislation. But the Government has to bear some of the responsibility for that as we told Government members of our concerns last year. In the intervening period they must have been able, with the genius at their disposal, to come up with some alternative route to protect those people without pulling the rug out from underneath this part of the legislation altogether.
Having said that, I move on to another point that the Minister made, that is, that the Opposition's amendment is flawed because it does not cover pooled super trusts. I think I heard that correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pooled super trusts or the superannuation business of life offices.

—The Minister is making the claim that the Opposition's removal of the earnings tax absolutely will not exempt pooled super trusts from the earnings tax. Does that mean that I get the opportunity to come back to the third pair of our amendments following this exercise, which aim to exempt from this tax predominantly interest earning pooled superannuation trusts. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In his remarks, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said that he did not believe the Opposition was serious in pursuing these amendments. I can assure him that the Opposition is serious. He said that the fundamental thrust of this part of the package was to encourage investment in imputed dividend shares. One of the concerns the Opposition has is that the superannuation area must have a prime reason for legislation to be passed, that being that we want more people to enter superannuation funds, with a larger percentage of Australian citizens being involved. There is a need for more people to be attracted into superannuation in order that they can be more self-reliant in retirement. One of the groups of people who have to be attracted in if this is to be achieved are those on the lower marginal tax rates. The figures speak for themselves. We have 3.6 million Australians in superannuation funds. In the private sector only 39 per cent of employees are in superannuation funds whilst in the public sector some 67 per cent of people are in superannuation funds. As I have already pointed out, it is possible for the public sector to avoid paying that 15 per cent investment tax simply by not funding its schemes. If the private sector tried a similar sort of system, then there could be great problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Going back to the point I was making previously, there is a need to attract into superannuation schemes those people who are on the lower marginal tax rates. This package simply does not do that. A tax advantage is needed to make the package attractive. People are being asked to forgo the enjoyment of spending money that is in their hands today and to put it aside for their retirement, in the meantime making those funds available for savings and investment. The decision to do that has to be encouraged by giving people a tax advantage. For people on the lower marginal rate that advantage is simply not great enough. Excising this 15 per cent tax we believe will make superannuation more attractive to this group of people.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bishop's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In light of the comments made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) with regard to an alleged deficiency within the Opposition's amendment and not wanting to take the risk that one of the types of superannuation providers that we are concerned about slips through the exemption net, I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 18, clause 9, proposed subsection 296 (1), line 7, leave out ``The trustee'', insert ``Subject to subsection (4), the trustee''.
(6) Page 18, clause 9, after proposed subsection 296 (3), add the following new subsections:
``(4) Subsection (1) does not apply to income of a fund where 90% of the assets of the fund are in interest earning investments.
``(5) Subsection (4) ceases to have effect on 30 June 1999.''.

We have moved three pairs of amendments relating to our exemption attempt. They would have exempted from the earnings tax for a period of 10 years three groups of funds: complying superannuation funds whose assets are 90 per cent invested in interest earning investments; complying approved deposit funds which are 90 per cent invested in interest earning investments; and predominantly interest earning pooled superannuation trusts. We were defeated in a combined vote of the Government and the Liberal and National parties in the first of those amendments. I understand that approved deposit funds are picked up under the Liberal Party amendment which was supposed to be a general exemption. However, I also understand that there is at least a strong belief on the part of the Minister and his advisers that pooled superannuation trusts will not be gathered up under the Liberal Party's amendment to exempt funds from the earnings tax. I would not like the legislation to leave this place and go back to the House of Representatives for consideration without absolutely ensuring that all of the groups of superannuation trusts were covered. It would be better for the Opposition's amendment and our amendment to pass this place, rather than for the Opposition's amendment to go through and our third pair of amendments to be defeated and a significant group of fixed interest funds to be left outside the earnings tax exemption and forced to pay 15 per cent tax with no capacity for a significant imputation offset.

Given that the leading financial lights in the Liberal Party are currently having a discussion and given that I have talked this out for as long as is possible, even for me, to go on repeating the same thing over and over again, I would like to get some indication from the Opposition as to whether it is prepared to support these amendments at least pro tem. We should not kid ourselves; this Bill will come back from the House of Representatives, which is waiting breathlessly to get it tonight. We will probably receive it again on Monday, at which stage we can sort it out. I do not want to risk having the Bill leave this place with over half the Senate concerned about the earnings tax and its effect on a range of people but not covering one significant group. I do not know whether the Opposition wants to report progress so that it can consult its spokesperson in the other place or whether it is prepared to take a punt on this one and see what happens after it has been to the House of Representatives. If the Opposition is serious about removing the earnings tax, I urge it not to leave, however inadvertently, a loophole with regard to pooled superannuation trusts. In order that the Opposition not do that, I ask it to support our amendments 5 and 6 relating to those groups of superannuation trusts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that has been raised by Senator Walsh only reflects the complete complexity of this whole area of legislation. When we realise that the size of this package of Bills is about the size that the Tax Act used to be, it is not surprising that the Government has managed to place some seeds of concern in the minds of the Australian Democrats. It is no wonder that the May economic statement on superannuation with the acronym `MESS' is how this package of Bills is known in the industry. The question that has been raised by Senator Walsh as to whether there is complete coverage of all aspects, as he alleges, is but one example of the difficulties and complexities that are comprised in the whole package.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Committee's attention to one of the other difficulties that are contained in various parts of the package of legislation. For instance, the contribution tax of 15 per cent, which is only payable on contributions which are tax deductable and payable by the fund, poses a whole ream of problems, considering the 600,000 people who are in private superannuation funds. Let us look at the way this problem might present itself.

First, the legislation is not clear as to who a prescribed person will be who can state whether or not a contribution tax ought to be paid on all contributions received where, for instance, somebody who is in a private fund might also be in a fund where there is an employer contribution. Thus, fund managers who have to pay the tax are concerned to know whether or not a contributor to a private superannuation fund who would normally attract a tax deduction is in a second or more fund to which an employer makes a contribution in excess of 3 per cent. If such a contributor to a private fund is in a second or more fund, then his personal contribution will not attract a deduction. Therefore, the fund will not need to pay the 15 per cent contribution tax. The funds will probably be advised by employers of names of persons in respect of whom they are contributing in excess of 3 per cent, but there will be those people whose names will not appear and to whom a communication will be required to be made in order to determine whether their contribution is subject to tax deductability. If that person chooses not to respond to the inquiry, then there has to be a presumption that the contribution is deductable and therefore the tax is payable.

The relevant question of the contribution of the employer being over 3 per cent is relevant because originally it would have been if no contribution were made that the tax deductability question was relevant, but because of the 3 per cent productivity funds, it was considered to be unjust if somebody who went into one of the funds was penalised of the right to have his or her ordinary superannuation payment deduction. Thus we have a further complication. As I said, this whole package of Bills is the size the tax Act used to be prior to the whole matter becoming more and more complex, so that even the simplest person with the simplest income now needs professional advice to comply with all the filling out of forms and laws and regulations which are part of our horrendously complicated system. It is no wonder that the Minister has posed a doubt in the minds of the Democrats.

I go back to fundamentals. Senator Haines has said that the Democrats are very concerned about people who are in approved deposit funds and roll-over funds and who through no fault of their own would be disadvantaged and lose some thousands of dollars. Our concern equally is with those people and, as I said, the total sum of investment in those funds stands at around $12 billion. Again as I have said, there is a need to attract more people into superannuation funds, particularly people on the lower marginal tax rates. Indeed, the Opposition's retirement policy looks to the situation whereby people who are in employment only part time and then opt out-perhaps women who seek to have children and leave the work force for some time and come back in-are afforded the advantage of being able to join a superannuation fund and maintain continuity. After all, women live longer than men-on average, nine years longer-and therefore, in a way, superannuation for women is of fundamental importance. Of course, by and large, it is women who are on those lower marginal tax rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are at present, I thought, debating whether or not to support two Democrats' amendments that relate quite specifically to one section of the legislation dealing with one of the types of superannuation funds which, according to the Government, may escape the net of the Opposition's general exemption amendment. I do not need to be patronised by Senator Bishop; nor would I have thought it appropriate for an honourable senator to discuss the discrimination against women in the superannuation field. I would have thought that this was more appropriate to a speech at the second reading stage. What I want to know is whether or not our amendments with regard to these funds will be accepted by the Opposition-as a safety measure-and, if not, why not.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I wish to speak to the point of order. I am under the assumption that Senator Bishop has been directing her remarks to the matters which are, as Senator Haines has said, before the Chair, and that she will indeed continue to do so if she is allowed to continue to speak without being interrupted by points of order.
—Senator Bishop, will you please relate your remarks to the amendments moved by Senator Haines and now before the Chair.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. Senator Haines directed her attention to a doubt put in her mind by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, as to whether or not there is a need for a different class of superannuation funds to be looked at. Indeed, Senator Haines makes the presumption that, in the event that the Minister was correct, her amendments would deal with the doubt that he raises. The remarks I was making with regard to superannuation generally and the reasons for the Opposition's concern and support for a system of superannuation which encourages savings are just as relevant to Senator Haines's amendments as they were to my own amendments. Therefore, I feel that the point of order that was raised was not relevant to what I had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was in the process of saying, there is a need to encourage women-who, by and large, are on the lower marginal tax rates and, as I said, live on average nine years longer than men-into superannuation schemes. In our view, the Opposition's amendments to excise the tax on superannuation investment funds are an attractive proposition to enlarge the number of people entering into superannuation funds so that the superannuation figures grow from the 39 per cent figure for the private sector and the 67 per cent figure for the public sector. I also raised the point that there is a need-which we acknowledge in our policy-to cater for the whole group of people in the community who work for a period of years within the paid work force, then leave it for a time and return to it. There is a need for continuity so that they may enjoy the benefits of superannuation as well.

When dealing with our own amendments I dealt with the question of confusion within the industry about how satisfactory the Bills were. I mentioned that the Life Underwriters Association of Australia had urged the Opposition to disregard calls from some sections of the life insurance industry for the immediate passage of this Bill, regardless of its faults, in order to avoid administrative inconvenience. Certainly the question of administrative inconvenience is a relevant one, for the simple reason that the statement was made in May 1988 and we are only now dealing with the package of Bills. Indeed, it is not surprising that we are having to deal with the area of doubt raised by the Minister, for the simple reason that the boffins of Treasury have taken some 12 months to prepare this massive and complicated package of legislation. Yet the industry, let alone the poor person who is contributing to the superannuation funds, has been given only days to try to absorb the complexity of the Bills and deal with their full ramifications.

It is very important that a stand be taken with regard to this particular tax which, as I said earlier, on our estimates is worth only between $20m and $120m of revenue in a package which in total is worth $1.4 billion. We should look at the whole rationale of the Government in saying that it is entitled to acquire early the tax on this money which it would normally receive when the benefit fell due to the person who has made this long term commitment to savings. The Government is saying, `Oh, no. We want to have that money now. We want the benefit of that money which is lying in superannuation funds to be paid up front instead of at the end'. So the whole thrust of this whole package of Bills is really to achieve a simple tax take.

I think it was significant that when we listened to the speeches at the second reading stage we heard the point made that during the six years that this Government has been in office there have been some 20 alterations to superannuation provisions, which is hardly conducive to making people feel safe and secure in the investment of their hard-earned long term savings. In fact, this history, including this package, has seen taxation of superannuation generally increase by some 1,000 per cent. That is a tremendous indictment of a government whose policies fit into an economy in decline at a time when we have concerns about whether we will be able to create a more substantial savings ratio in this country and see a more healthy domestic economy develop. I find that the amendments moved by the Democrats would not solve the problems they purport to solve. Accordingly, the Opposition will not be supporting them. However, we will, as I said, pursue the matter of the need to have policies in place which will generate--

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government agree with recommendation 40 of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report Australia's Relations with the South Pacific that: `The Australian Government to appoint a junior Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade with the responsibility for Australia's relations with the South Pacific'; if so, what action has been undertaken with respect to this recommendation; if not, why not.

(2) Does the Government agree with recommendation 41 of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report Australia's Relations with the South Pacific that: `Australia to establish a small consulate in French Polynesia'; if so, what action has been undertaken with respect to this recommendation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is now considering most carefully the interesting and useful report on Australia's Relations with the South Pacific which was recently presented by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and will respond to all the recommendations made in the report when its consideration is complete.
